<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt5" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Redirect-several","href":"./Template:Redirect-several"},"params":{"dab":{"wt":"off"},"1":{"wt":"Mammalian (film)"},"2":{"wt":"Mammalia (journal)"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBg"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt5" id="mwBw">Several terms  redirect here. For other uses, see <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammalian_(film)" title="Mammalian (film)">Mammalian (film)</a><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>and<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammalia_(journal)" title="Mammalia (journal)">Mammalia (journal)</a>.</div>
<p about="#mwt22" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Good article","href":"./Template:Good_article"},"params":{},"i":0}},"\n",{"template":{"target":{"wt":"pp-semi-indef","href":"./Template:Pp-semi-indef"},"params":{},"i":1}},"\n",{"template":{"target":{"wt":"pp-move-indef","href":"./Template:Pp-move-indef"},"params":{},"i":2}},"\n",{"template":{"target":{"wt":"EngvarB","href":"./Template:EngvarB"},"params":{"date":{"wt":"June 2022"}},"i":3}},"\n",{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Use dmy dates","href":"./Template:Use_dmy_dates"},"params":{"date":{"wt":"June 2022"}},"i":4}},"\n",{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Automatic taxobox\n","href":"./Template:Automatic_taxobox"},"params":{"name":{"wt":"Mammals"},"fossil_range":{"wt":"{{Fossil range|167|0|[[Late Triassic]] – Recent; 225 or 167–0 Ma| earliest=225|PS= See [[#variations|discussion of dates]] in text}}\n&lt;!-- Ambondro, Amphilestes and Amphitherium are dated about 167 Ma, providing the date for the monotreme-therian divergence. Adelobasilius and Tikitherium are dated 225 Ma, the date used for the first known mammals as determined morphologically . -->"},"image":{"wt":"&lt;imagemap>\nFile:Mammal Diversity 2011.png|300px\n\nrect 0 0 176 125 [[common vampire bat]]\nrect 0 120 176 240 [[Tasmanian devil]]\nrect 0 240 176 380 [[fox squirrel]]\nrect 0 380 176 500 [[platypus]]\nrect 0 500 176 600 [[humpback whale]]\nrect 0 760 176 620 [[giant armadillo]]\n\nrect 355 0 176 125 [[Virginia opossum]]\nrect 355 120 176 240 [[human]]\nrect 355 240 176 380 [[tree pangolin]]\nrect 355 380 176 500 [[colugo]]\nrect 355 500 176 600 [[star nosed mole]]\nrect 355 760 176 620 [[plains zebra]]\n\nrect 530 0 350 125 [[eastern grey kangaroo]]\nrect 530 120 350 240 [[northern elephant seal]]\nrect 530 240 350 380 [[African elephant]]\nrect 530 380 350 500 [[elk]]\nrect 530 500 350 600 [[giant panda]]\nrect 530 760 350 620 [[black and rufous elephant shrew]]\n&lt;/imagemap>"},"display_parents":{"wt":"3"},"taxon":{"wt":"Mammalia"},"authority":{"wt":"[[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], 1758"},"subdivision_ranks":{"wt":"Living subgroups"},"subdivision":{"wt":"* [[Monotremata]]\n* [[Theria]]\n** [[Marsupialia]]\n** [[Placentalia]]"}},"i":5}}]}' id="mwCA"><link typeof="mw:Extension/indicator" about="#mwt11" data-mw='{"name":"indicator","attrs":{"name":"good-star"},"body":{"extsrc":"[[File:symbol support vote.svg|20x20px\n |link=Wikipedia:Good articles\n |\n |This is a good article. <p id="mwIQ">A <b id="mwIg">mammal</b> (<span about="#mwt27" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"etymology","href":"./Template:Etymology"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"la"},"2":{"wt":"{{wikt-lang|la|mamma}}"},"3":{"wt":"breast"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwIw">from</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt27"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Latin_language" title="Latin language" about="#mwt27" class="mw-redirect">Latin</a><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt27"> </span><i about="#mwt27"> <i lang="la"><a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mamma#Latin" title="wikt:mamma" class="extiw">mamma</a></i></i><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt27"> </span><span about="#mwt27">'breast'</span>)<sup about="#mwt32" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-1"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-1" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 1;" id="mwJA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwJQ">[1]</span></a></sup> is a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate" id="mwJg">vertebrate</a> animal of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Class_(biology)" title="Class (biology)" id="mwJw">class</a> <b id="mwKA">Mammalia</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap" about="#mwt28" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"IPAc-en","href":"./Template:IPAc-en"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"m"},"2":{"wt":"ə"},"3":{"wt":"ˈ"},"4":{"wt":"m"},"5":{"wt":"eɪ"},"6":{"wt":"l"},"7":{"wt":"i"},"8":{"wt":"."},"9":{"wt":"ə"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwKQ"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'m' in 'my'">m</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'m' in 'my'">m</span><span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">eɪ</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/./: syllable break">.</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span></span>/</a></span></span>). Mammals are characterized by the presence of milk-producing <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammary_gland" title="Mammary gland" id="mwKg">mammary glands</a> for feeding their young, a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neocortex" title="Neocortex" id="mwKw">neocortex</a> region of the brain, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fur" title="Fur" id="mwLA">fur</a> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hair" title="Hair" id="mwLQ">hair</a>, and three <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ossicles" title="Ossicles" id="mwLg">middle ear bones</a>. These characteristics distinguish them from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Reptile" title="Reptile" id="mwLw">reptiles</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bird" title="Bird" id="mwMA">birds</a>, which they <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genetic_divergence" title="Genetic divergence" id="mwMQ">diverged</a> from in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carboniferous" title="Carboniferous" id="mwMg">Carboniferous</a> Period over 300<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwMw"> </span>million years ago. Around 6,400 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Extant_taxon" title="Extant taxon" class="mw-redirect" id="mwNA">extant</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Species" title="Species" id="mwNQ">species</a> of mammals have been described and divided into 29 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Order_(biology)" title="Order (biology)" id="mwNg">orders</a>. </p>

<p id="mwNw">The largest orders of mammals, by number of species, are the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rodents" title="Rodents" class="mw-redirect" id="mwOA">rodents</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bats" title="Bats" class="mw-redirect" id="mwOQ">bats</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eulipotyphla" title="Eulipotyphla" id="mwOg">Eulipotyphla</a> (including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hedgehog" title="Hedgehog" id="mwOw">hedgehogs</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mole_(animal)" title="Mole (animal)" id="mwPA">moles</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shrew" title="Shrew" id="mwPQ">shrews</a>). The next three are the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Primate" title="Primate" id="mwPg">Primates</a> (including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Human" title="Human" id="mwPw">humans</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Monkey" title="Monkey" id="mwQA">monkeys</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lemur" title="Lemur" id="mwQQ">lemurs</a>), the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Even-toed_ungulate" title="Even-toed ungulate" id="mwQg">even-toed ungulates</a> (including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pig" title="Pig" id="mwQw">pigs</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Camel" title="Camel" id="mwRA">camels</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Whale" title="Whale" id="mwRQ">whales</a>), and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnivora" title="Carnivora" id="mwRg">Carnivora</a> (including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Felidae" title="Felidae" id="mwRw">cats</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Canidae" title="Canidae" id="mwSA">dogs</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pinniped" title="Pinniped" id="mwSQ">seals</a>).</p>

<p id="mwSg">Mammals are the only living members of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Synapsid" title="Synapsid" id="mwSw">Synapsida</a>; this <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Clade" title="Clade" id="mwTA">clade</a>, together with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sauropsida" title="Sauropsida" id="mwTQ">Sauropsida</a> (reptiles and birds), constitutes the larger <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Amniote" title="Amniote" id="mwTg">Amniota</a> clade. The early synapsids were <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sphenacodontia" title="Sphenacodontia" id="mwTw">sphenacodonts</a>, a group that included the famous <i id="mwUA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dimetrodon" title="Dimetrodon" id="mwUQ">Dimetrodon</a></i>. The synapsids split into several diverse groups of non-mammalian synapsids—traditionally and incorrectly referred to as mammal-like reptiles or by the term <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pelycosaur" title="Pelycosaur" id="mwUg">pelycosaurs</a>, and now known as stem mammals or protomammals—before giving rise to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Therapsida" title="Therapsida" class="mw-redirect" id="mwUw">therapsids</a> during the beginning of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Guadalupian" title="Guadalupian" id="mwVA">Middle Permian</a> period. Mammals originated from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cynodont" title="Cynodont" id="mwVQ">cynodonts</a>, an advanced group of therapsids, during the Late <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Triassic" title="Triassic" id="mwVg">Triassic</a>-Early <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jurassic" title="Jurassic" id="mwVw">Jurassic</a>. The modern mammalian orders arose in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paleogene" title="Paleogene" id="mwWA">Paleogene</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neogene" title="Neogene" id="mwWQ">Neogene</a> periods of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cenozoic" title="Cenozoic" id="mwWg">Cenozoic</a> era, after the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cretaceous–Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event" id="mwWw">extinction of non-avian dinosaurs</a>, and have been the dominant<link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:All_Wikipedia_articles_needing_clarification" about="#mwt33" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Vague","href":"./Template:Vague"},"params":{"date":{"wt":"July 2022"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwXA"/><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Wikipedia_articles_needing_clarification_from_July_2022" about="#mwt33"/><sup class="noprint Inline-Template " style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;" about="#mwt33" id="mwXQ"><span typeof="mw:Entity">[</span><i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wikipedia:Vagueness" title="Wikipedia:Vagueness"><span title="This information is too vague. (July 2022)">vague</span></a></i><span typeof="mw:Entity">]</span></sup> terrestrial animal group from 66<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwXg"> </span>million years ago to the present.</p>

<p id="mwXw">The basic mammalian body type is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Quadruped" title="Quadruped" class="mw-redirect" id="mwYA">quadruped</a>, and most mammals use their four extremities for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Terrestrial_locomotion" title="Terrestrial locomotion" id="mwYQ">terrestrial locomotion</a>; but in some, the extremities are adapted for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Marine_mammal" title="Marine mammal" id="mwYg">life at sea</a>, in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aerial_locomotion" title="Aerial locomotion" class="mw-redirect" id="mwYw">the air</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arboreal_locomotion" title="Arboreal locomotion" id="mwZA">in trees</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fossorial" title="Fossorial" id="mwZQ">underground</a>, or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bipedalism" title="Bipedalism" id="mwZg">on two legs</a>. Mammals range in size from the <span about="#mwt34" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"30"},"2":{"wt":"–"},"3":{"wt":"40"},"4":{"wt":"mm"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwZw">30–40</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt34"> </span><span about="#mwt34">mm (1.2–1.6</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt34"> </span><span about="#mwt34">in)</span> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bumblebee_bat" title="Bumblebee bat" class="mw-redirect" id="mwaA">bumblebee bat</a> to the <span about="#mwt35" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"30"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwaQ">30</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt35"> </span><span about="#mwt35">m (98</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt35"> </span><span about="#mwt35">ft)</span> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Blue_whale" title="Blue whale" id="mwag">blue whale</a>—possibly the largest animal to have ever lived. Maximum lifespan varies from two years for the shrew to 211 years for the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bowhead_whale" title="Bowhead whale" id="mwaw">bowhead whale</a>. All modern mammals give birth to live young, except the five species of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Monotreme" title="Monotreme" id="mwbA">monotremes</a>, which are egg-laying mammals. The most species-rich group of mammals, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cohort_(taxonomy)" title="Cohort (taxonomy)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwbQ">cohort</a> called <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Placentals" title="Placentals" class="mw-redirect" id="mwbg">placentals</a>, have a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Placenta" title="Placenta" id="mwbw">placenta</a>, which enables the feeding of the fetus during <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gestation" title="Gestation" id="mwcA">gestation</a>.</p>

<p id="mwcQ">Most mammals are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_cognition" title="Animal cognition" id="mwcg">intelligent</a>, with some possessing large brains, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Self-awareness" title="Self-awareness" id="mwcw">self-awareness</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tool_use_in_animals" title="Tool use in animals" class="mw-redirect" id="mwdA">tool use</a>. Mammals can communicate and vocalize in several ways, including the production of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ultrasound" title="Ultrasound" id="mwdQ">ultrasound</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scent-marking" title="Scent-marking" class="mw-redirect" id="mwdg">scent-marking</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Alarm_signal" title="Alarm signal" id="mwdw">alarm signals</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Singing#Singing_animals" title="Singing" id="mweA">singing</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_echolocation" title="Animal echolocation" id="mweQ">echolocation</a>. Mammals can organize themselves into <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fission-fusion_society" title="Fission-fusion society" class="mw-redirect" id="mweg">fission-fusion societies</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Harem_(zoology)" title="Harem (zoology)" id="mwew">harems</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hierarchy" title="Hierarchy" id="mwfA">hierarchies</a>—but can also be solitary and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Territory_(animal)" title="Territory (animal)" id="mwfQ">territorial</a>. Most mammals are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polygyny_in_animals" title="Polygyny in animals" id="mwfg">polygynous</a>, but some can be <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Monogamy_in_animals" title="Monogamy in animals" id="mwfw">monogamous</a> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polyandry_in_nature" title="Polyandry in nature" id="mwgA">polyandrous</a>.</p>

<p id="mwgQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Domestication" title="Domestication" id="mwgg">Domestication</a> of many types of mammals by humans played a major role in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neolithic_Revolution" title="Neolithic Revolution" id="mwgw">Neolithic Revolution</a>, and resulted in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Agriculture" title="Agriculture" id="mwhA">farming</a> replacing <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer" id="mwhQ">hunting and gathering</a> as the primary source of food for humans. This led to a major restructuring of human societies from nomadic to sedentary, with more co-operation among larger and larger groups, and ultimately the development of the first <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Civilization" title="Civilization" id="mwhg">civilizations</a>. Domesticated mammals provided, and continue to provide, power for transport and agriculture, as well as food (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Meat" title="Meat" id="mwhw">meat</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dairy_product" title="Dairy product" id="mwiA">dairy products</a>), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fur" title="Fur" id="mwiQ">fur</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Leather" title="Leather" id="mwig">leather</a>. Mammals are also <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hunting" title="Hunting" id="mwiw">hunted</a> and raced for sport, and are used as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Model_organism" title="Model organism" id="mwjA">model organisms</a> in science. Mammals have been depicted in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Art" title="Art" id="mwjQ">art</a> since <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic" id="mwjg">Paleolithic</a> times, and appear in literature, film, mythology, and religion. Decline in numbers and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Extinction" title="Extinction" id="mwjw">extinction</a> of many mammals is primarily driven by human <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Poaching" title="Poaching" id="mwkA">poaching</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Habitat_destruction" title="Habitat destruction" id="mwkQ">habitat destruction</a>, primarily <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deforestation" title="Deforestation" id="mwkg">deforestation</a>.</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt36" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"TOC limit","href":"./Template:TOC_limit"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"4"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwkw">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-4" about="#mwt36" id="mwlA"><meta property="mw:PageProp/toc"/></div>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="1" id="mwlQ"><h2 id="Classification">Classification</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt39" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Mammal classification"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwlg"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt39" id="mwlw">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammal_classification" title="Mammal classification">Mammal classification</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt42" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"List of placental mammals"},"2":{"wt":"List of monotremes and marsupials"},"3":{"wt":"List of mammal genera"},"4":{"wt":"List of mammal species"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwmA"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt42" id="mwmQ">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_placental_mammals" title="List of placental mammals">List of placental mammals</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_monotremes_and_marsupials" title="List of monotremes and marsupials">List of monotremes and marsupials</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_mammal_genera" title="List of mammal genera">List of mammal genera</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_mammal_species" title="List of mammal species" class="mw-redirect">List of mammal species</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwmg"><a href="./File:Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwmw"><img resource="./File:Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg/300px-Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="482" data-file-height="482" data-file-type="drawing" height="300" width="300" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg/450px-Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg/600px-Mammal_species_pie_chart.svg.png 2x" id="mwnA"/></a><figcaption id="mwnQ">Over 70% of mammal species come from the orders <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rodent" title="Rodent" id="mwng">Rodentia</a>, rodents (blue); <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chiroptera" title="Chiroptera" class="mw-redirect" id="mwnw">Chiroptera</a>, bats (red); and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Soricomorpha" title="Soricomorpha" id="mwoA">Soricomorpha</a>, shrews (yellow).
<table id="mwoQ">

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt54" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#4ee257"},"2":{"wt":"[[Primates]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwqw"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt54" id="mwrA"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#4ee257; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Primates" title="Primates" class="mw-redirect">Primates</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt57" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#6711ff"},"2":{"wt":"[[Carnivora]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwrQ"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt57" id="mwrg"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#6711ff; color:white;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnivora" title="Carnivora">Carnivora</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt60" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#fea746"},"2":{"wt":"[[Artiodactyla]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwrw"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt60" id="mwsA"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#fea746; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Artiodactyla" title="Artiodactyla" class="mw-redirect">Artiodactyla</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt63" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#865357"},"2":{"wt":"[[Diprotodontia]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwsQ"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt63" id="mwsg"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#865357; color:white;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diprotodontia" title="Diprotodontia">Diprotodontia</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt66" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#a2bd90"},"2":{"wt":"[[Lagomorpha]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwsw"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt66" id="mwtA"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#a2bd90; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lagomorpha" title="Lagomorpha">Lagomorpha</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt69" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#00ccff"},"2":{"wt":"[[Didelphimorphia]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwtQ"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt69" id="mwtg"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#00ccff; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Didelphimorphia" title="Didelphimorphia" class="mw-redirect">Didelphimorphia</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt72" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#ccffff"},"2":{"wt":"[[Cetacea]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwtw"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt72" id="mwuA"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ccffff; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cetacea" title="Cetacea">Cetacea</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt75" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#ccffcc"},"2":{"wt":"[[Dasyuromorphia]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwuQ"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt75" id="mwug"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ccffcc; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dasyuromorphia" title="Dasyuromorphia">Dasyuromorphia</a></div></td>
<td style="width:150px; vertical-align:top" id="mwuw">
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt78" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#ffff99"},"2":{"wt":"[[Afrosoricida]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwvA"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt78" id="mwvQ"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ffff99; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Afrosoricida" title="Afrosoricida">Afrosoricida</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt81" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#99ccff"},"2":{"wt":"[[Erinaceomorpha]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwvg"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt81" id="mwvw"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#99ccff; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Erinaceomorpha" title="Erinaceomorpha" class="mw-redirect">Erinaceomorpha</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt84" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#ff99cc"},"2":{"wt":"[[Cingulata]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwwA"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt84" id="mwwQ"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ff99cc; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cingulata" title="Cingulata">Cingulata</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt87" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#cc99ff"},"2":{"wt":"[[Peramelemorphia]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwwg"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt87" id="mwww"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#cc99ff; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Peramelemorphia" title="Peramelemorphia">Peramelemorphia</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt90" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#ffcc99"},"2":{"wt":"[[Scandentia]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwxA"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt90" id="mwxQ"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ffcc99; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scandentia" title="Scandentia" class="mw-redirect">Scandentia</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt93" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#3366ff"},"2":{"wt":"[[Perissodactyla]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwxg"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt93" id="mwxw"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#3366ff; color:white;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Perissodactyla" title="Perissodactyla" class="mw-redirect">Perissodactyla</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt96" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#33cccc"},"2":{"wt":"[[Macroscelidea]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwyA"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt96" id="mwyQ"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#33cccc; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Macroscelidea" title="Macroscelidea" class="mw-redirect">Macroscelidea</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt99" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#99cc00"},"2":{"wt":"[[Pilosa]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwyg"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt99" id="mwyw"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#99cc00; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pilosa" title="Pilosa">Pilosa</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt102" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#ff6600"},"2":{"wt":"[[Monotremata]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwzA"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt102" id="mwzQ"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ff6600; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Monotremata" title="Monotremata" class="mw-redirect">Monotremata</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt105" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#003366"},"2":{"wt":"[[Sirenia]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwzg"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt105" id="mwzw"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#003366; color:white;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sirenia" title="Sirenia">Sirenia</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt108" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#00aa55"},"2":{"wt":"[[Proboscidea]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mw0A"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt108" id="mw0Q"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#00aa55; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Proboscidea" title="Proboscidea">Proboscidea</a></div></td></tr>
</tbody></table></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mw0g">Mammal classification has been through several revisions since <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carl_Linnaeus" title="Carl Linnaeus" id="mw0w">Carl Linnaeus</a> initially defined the class, and at present, no classification system is universally accepted. McKenna &amp; Bell (1997) and Wilson &amp; Reeder (2005) provide useful recent compendiums.<sup about="#mwt116" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-2"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-2" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 2;" id="mw1A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw1Q">[2]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./George_Gaylord_Simpson" title="George Gaylord Simpson" id="mw1g">Simpson</a> (1945)<sup about="#mwt120" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Simpson-1945_3-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Simpson-1945"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Simpson-1945-3"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Simpson-1945-3" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 3;" id="mw1w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw2A">[3]</span></a></sup> provides <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Systematics" title="Systematics" id="mw2Q">systematics</a> of mammal origins and relationships that had been taught universally until the end of the 20th<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mw2g"> </span>century.
However, since 1945, a large amount of new and more detailed information has gradually been found: The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fossil_record" title="Fossil record" class="mw-redirect" id="mw2w">paleontological record</a> has been recalibrated, and the intervening years have seen much debate and progress concerning the theoretical underpinnings of systematization itself, partly through the new concept of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cladistics" title="Cladistics" id="mw3A">cladistics</a>. Though fieldwork and lab work progressively outdated Simpson's classification, it remains the closest thing to an official classification of mammals, despite its known issues.<sup about="#mwt125" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Szalay_4-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Szalay"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Szalay-4"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Szalay-4" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 4;" id="mw3Q"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw3g">[4]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mw3w">Most mammals, including the six most species-rich <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Order_(biology)" title="Order (biology)" id="mw4A">orders</a>, belong to the placental group. The three largest orders in numbers of species are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rodent" title="Rodent" id="mw4Q">Rodentia</a>: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mouse" title="Mouse" id="mw4g">mice</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rat" title="Rat" id="mw4w">rats</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Porcupine" title="Porcupine" id="mw5A">porcupines</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Beaver" title="Beaver" id="mw5Q">beavers</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Capybara" title="Capybara" id="mw5g">capybaras</a>, and other gnawing mammals; <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chiroptera" title="Chiroptera" class="mw-redirect" id="mw5w">Chiroptera</a>: bats; and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Soricomorpha" title="Soricomorpha" id="mw6A">Soricomorpha</a>: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shrew" title="Shrew" id="mw6Q">shrews</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mole_(animal)" title="Mole (animal)" id="mw6g">moles</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Solenodon" title="Solenodon" id="mw6w">solenodons</a>. The next three biggest orders, depending on the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biological_classification" title="Biological classification" class="mw-redirect" id="mw7A">biological classification</a> scheme used, are the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Primate" title="Primate" id="mw7Q">Primates</a>: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ape" title="Ape" id="mw7g">apes</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Monkey" title="Monkey" id="mw7w">monkeys</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lemur" title="Lemur" id="mw8A">lemurs</a>; the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cetartiodactyla" title="Cetartiodactyla" class="mw-redirect" id="mw8Q">Cetartiodactyla</a>: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Whale" title="Whale" id="mw8g">whales</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Even-toed_ungulates" title="Even-toed ungulates" class="mw-redirect" id="mw8w">even-toed ungulates</a>; and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnivora" title="Carnivora" id="mw9A">Carnivora</a> which includes <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cat" title="Cat" id="mw9Q">cats</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dog" title="Dog" id="mw9g">dogs</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Weasel" title="Weasel" id="mw9w">weasels</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bear" title="Bear" id="mw-A">bears</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pinniped" title="Pinniped" id="mw-Q">seals</a>, and allies.<sup about="#mwt133" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MSW3intro_5-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MSW3intro"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-MSW3intro-5"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-MSW3intro-5" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 5;" id="mw-g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw-w">[5]</span></a></sup> According to <i id="mw_A"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammal_Species_of_the_World" title="Mammal Species of the World" id="mw_Q">Mammal Species of the World</a></i>, 5,416<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mw_g"> </span>species were identified in 2006. These were grouped into 1,229<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mw_w"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genus" title="Genus" id="mwAQA">genera</a>, 153<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAQE"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Family_(biology)" title="Family (biology)" id="mwAQI">families</a> and 29<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAQM"> </span>orders.<sup about="#mwt134" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MSW3intro_5-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MSW3intro"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-MSW3intro-5" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 5;" id="mwAQQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAQU">[5]</span></a></sup> In 2008, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./International_Union_for_Conservation_of_Nature" title="International Union for Conservation of Nature" id="mwAQY">International Union for Conservation of Nature</a> (IUCN) completed a five-year Global Mammal Assessment for its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./IUCN_Red_List" title="IUCN Red List" id="mwAQc">IUCN Red List</a>, which counted 5,488<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAQg"> </span>species.<sup about="#mwt138" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-6" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-6"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-6" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 6;" id="mwAQk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAQo">[6]</span></a></sup> According to research published in the <i id="mwAQs"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Journal_of_Mammalogy" title="Journal of Mammalogy" id="mwAQw">Journal of Mammalogy</a></i> in 2018, the number of recognized mammal species is 6,495, including 96<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAQ0"> </span>recently extinct.<sup about="#mwt142" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-7" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-7"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-7" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 7;" id="mwAQ4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAQ8">[7]</span></a></sup></p>

<section data-mw-section-id="2" id="mwARA"><h3 id="Definitions">Definitions <span class="anchor" id="variations" about="#mwt143" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Anchor","href":"./Template:Anchor"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"variations"}},"i":0}}]}'></span></h3>
<!-- This section is linked from the fossil_range parameter in the taxobox -->
<p id="mwARE">The word "<a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mammal" title="wikt:mammal" class="extiw" id="mwARI">mammal</a>" is modern, from the scientific name <i id="mwARM">Mammalia</i> coined by Carl Linnaeus in 1758, derived from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Latin_language" title="Latin language" class="mw-redirect" id="mwARQ">Latin</a> <i id="mwARU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mamma#Latin" title="wikt:mamma" class="extiw" id="mwARY">mamma</a></i> ("teat, pap"). In an influential 1988 paper, Timothy Rowe defined Mammalia <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phylogenetics" title="Phylogenetics" id="mwARc">phylogenetically</a> as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crown_group" title="Crown group" id="mwARg">crown group</a> of mammals, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Clade" title="Clade" id="mwARk">clade</a> consisting of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Most_recent_common_ancestor" title="Most recent common ancestor" id="mwARo">most recent common ancestor</a> of living <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Monotreme" title="Monotreme" id="mwARs">monotremes</a> (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Echidna" title="Echidna" id="mwARw">echidnas</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Platypus" title="Platypus" id="mwAR0">platypuses</a>) and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Theria" title="Theria" id="mwAR4">Therian</a> mammals (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Marsupial" title="Marsupial" id="mwAR8">marsupials</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Placental" title="Placental" class="mw-redirect" id="mwASA">placentals</a>) and all descendants of that ancestor.<sup about="#mwt151" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-8" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-8"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-8" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 8;" id="mwASE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwASI">[8]</span></a></sup> Since this ancestor lived in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jurassic" title="Jurassic" id="mwASM">Jurassic</a> period, Rowe's definition excludes all animals from the earlier <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Triassic" title="Triassic" id="mwASQ">Triassic</a>, despite the fact that Triassic fossils in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Haramiyida" title="Haramiyida" id="mwASU">Haramiyida</a> have been referred to the Mammalia since the mid-19th century.<sup about="#mwt155" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-9" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-9"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-9" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 9;" id="mwASY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwASc">[9]</span></a></sup> If Mammalia is considered as the crown group, its origin can be roughly dated as the first known appearance of animals more closely related to some extant mammals than to others. <i id="mwASg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ambondro_mahabo" title="Ambondro mahabo" id="mwASk">Ambondro</a></i> is more closely related to monotremes than to therian mammals while <i id="mwASo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Amphilestes" title="Amphilestes" id="mwASs">Amphilestes</a></i> and <i id="mwASw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Amphitherium" title="Amphitherium" id="mwAS0">Amphitherium</a></i> are more closely related to the therians; as fossils of all three genera are dated about <span class="nourlexpansion plainlinks" style="white-space:nowrap;" about="#mwt147" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"ma","href":"./Template:Ma"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"167"},"2":{"wt":"million years ago"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAS4"><a rel="mw:ExtLink nofollow" href="https://geoltime.github.io/?Ma=167" class="external text">167</a> million years ago</span> in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Middle_Jurassic" title="Middle Jurassic" id="mwAS8">Middle Jurassic</a>, this is a reasonable estimate for the appearance of the crown group.<sup about="#mwt159" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-10" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-10"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-10" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 10;" id="mwATA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwATE">[10]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwATI">T.S. Kemp has provided a more traditional definition: "<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Synapsid" title="Synapsid" id="mwATM">Synapsids</a> that possess a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dentary" title="Dentary" class="mw-redirect" id="mwATQ">dentary</a>–<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Squamosal_bone" title="Squamosal bone" id="mwATU">squamosal</a> jaw articulation and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Occlusion_(dentistry)" title="Occlusion (dentistry)" id="mwATY">occlusion</a> between upper and lower molars with a transverse component to the movement" or, equivalently in Kemp's view, the clade originating with the last common ancestor of <i id="mwATc"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sinoconodon" title="Sinoconodon" id="mwATg">Sinoconodon</a></i> and living mammals.<sup about="#mwt167" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-11" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-11"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-11" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 11;" id="mwATk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwATo">[11]</span></a></sup> The earliest known synapsid satisfying Kemp's definitions is <i id="mwATs"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tikitherium" title="Tikitherium" id="mwATw">Tikitherium</a></i>, dated <span class="nourlexpansion plainlinks" style="white-space:nowrap;" about="#mwt163" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"ma","href":"./Template:Ma"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"225"},"2":{"wt":"Ma"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAT0"><a rel="mw:ExtLink nofollow" href="https://geoltime.github.io/?Ma=225" class="external text">225</a> Ma</span>, so the appearance of mammals in this broader sense can be given this <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Late_Triassic" title="Late Triassic" id="mwAT4">Late Triassic</a> date.<sup about="#mwt171" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-12" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-12"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-12" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 12;" id="mwAT8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAUA">[12]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt175" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-13" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-13"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-13" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 13;" id="mwAUE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAUI">[13]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="3" id="mwAUM"><h3 id="McKenna/Bell_classification"><span id="McKenna.2FBell_classification" typeof="mw:FallbackId"></span>McKenna/Bell classification</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt176" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Mammal classification#McKenna/Bell classification"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAUQ"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt176" id="mwAUU">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammal_classification#McKenna/Bell_classification" title="Mammal classification">Mammal classification §<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>McKenna/Bell classification</a></div>
<p id="mwAUY">In 1997, the mammals were comprehensively revised by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Malcolm_McKenna" title="Malcolm McKenna" id="mwAUc">Malcolm C. McKenna</a> and Susan K. Bell, which has resulted in the McKenna/Bell classification. The authors worked together as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paleontologist" title="Paleontologist" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAUg">paleontologists</a> at the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./American_Museum_of_Natural_History" title="American Museum of Natural History" id="mwAUk">American Museum of Natural History</a>. McKenna inherited the project from Simpson and, with Bell, constructed a completely updated hierarchical system, covering living and extinct taxa, that reflects the historical genealogy of Mammalia.<sup about="#mwt181" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Szalay_4-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Szalay"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Szalay-4" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 4;" id="mwAUo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAUs">[4]</span></a></sup> Their 1997 book, <i id="mwAUw">Classification of Mammals above the Species Level</i>,<sup about="#mwt185" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-McKennaBell1997_14-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"McKennaBell1997"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-McKennaBell1997-14"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-McKennaBell1997-14" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 14;" id="mwAU0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAU4">[14]</span></a></sup> is a comprehensive work on the systematics, relationships and occurrences of all mammal taxa, living and extinct, down through the rank of genus, though molecular genetic data challenge several of the groupings.</p>

<p id="mwAU8">In the following list, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Extinct" title="Extinct" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAVA">extinct</a> groups are labelled with a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dagger_(typography)" title="Dagger (typography)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAVE">dagger</a> (†).</p>

<p id="mwAVI"><b id="mwAVM">Class Mammalia</b></p>
<ul id="mwAVQ"><li id="mwAVU"><b id="mwAVY">Subclass <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Prototheria" title="Prototheria" id="mwAVc">Prototheria</a></b>: monotremes: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Echidna" title="Echidna" id="mwAVg">echidnas</a> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Platypus" title="Platypus" id="mwAVk">platypus</a></li>
<li id="mwAVo"><b id="mwAVs">Subclass <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Theriiformes" title="Theriiformes" id="mwAVw">Theriiformes</a></b>: live-bearing mammals and their prehistoric relatives
<ul id="mwAV0"><li id="mwAV4">Infraclass †<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Allotheria" title="Allotheria" id="mwAV8">Allotheria</a>: multituberculates</li>
<li id="mwAWA">Infraclass †<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eutriconodonta" title="Eutriconodonta" id="mwAWE">Eutriconodonta</a>: eutriconodonts</li>
<li id="mwAWI">Infraclass <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Holotheria" title="Holotheria" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAWM">Holotheria</a>: modern live-bearing mammals and their prehistoric relatives
<ul id="mwAWQ"><li id="mwAWU">Superlegion †<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kuehneotheria" title="Kuehneotheria" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAWY">Kuehneotheria</a></li>
<li id="mwAWc">Supercohort <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Theria" title="Theria" id="mwAWg">Theria</a>: live-bearing mammals
<ul id="mwAWk"><li id="mwAWo">Cohort <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Marsupialia" title="Marsupialia" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAWs">Marsupialia</a>: marsupials
<ul id="mwAWw"><li id="mwAW0">Magnorder <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Australidelphia" title="Australidelphia" id="mwAW4">Australidelphia</a>: Australian marsupials and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Monito_del_monte" title="Monito del monte" id="mwAW8">monito del monte</a></li>
<li id="mwAXA">Magnorder <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ameridelphia" title="Ameridelphia" id="mwAXE">Ameridelphia</a>: New<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAXI"> </span>World marsupials. Now considered <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paraphyly" title="Paraphyly" id="mwAXM">paraphyletic</a>, with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shrew_opossum" title="Shrew opossum" id="mwAXQ">shrew opossums</a> being closer to australidelphians.<sup about="#mwt190" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-15" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-15"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-15" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 15;" id="mwAXU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAXY">[15]</span></a></sup></li></ul></li>
<li id="mwAXc">Cohort <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Placentalia" title="Placentalia" id="mwAXg">Placentalia</a>: placentals
<ul id="mwAXk"><li id="mwAXo">Magnorder <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Xenarthra" title="Xenarthra" id="mwAXs">Xenarthra</a>: xenarthrans</li>
<li id="mwAXw">Magnorder <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Epitheria" title="Epitheria" id="mwAX0">Epitheria</a>: epitheres
<ul id="mwAX4"><li id="mwAX8">Superorder †<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Leptictida" title="Leptictida" id="mwAYA">Leptictida</a></li>
<li id="mwAYE">Superorder <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Preptotheria" title="Preptotheria" id="mwAYI">Preptotheria</a>
<ul id="mwAYM"><li id="mwAYQ">Grandorder <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Glires" title="Glires" id="mwAYU">Anagalida</a>: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lagomorpha" title="Lagomorpha" id="mwAYY">lagomorphs</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rodent" title="Rodent" id="mwAYc">rodents</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Elephant_shrew" title="Elephant shrew" id="mwAYg">elephant shrews</a></li>
<li id="mwAYk">Grandorder <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ferae" title="Ferae" id="mwAYo">Ferae</a>: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnivora" title="Carnivora" id="mwAYs">carnivorans</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pangolin" title="Pangolin" id="mwAYw">pangolins</a>, †<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Creodont" title="Creodont" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAY0">creodonts</a> and relatives</li>
<li id="mwAY4">Grandorder <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lipotyphla" title="Lipotyphla" id="mwAY8">Lipotyphla</a>: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Insectivora" title="Insectivora" id="mwAZA">insectivorans</a></li>
<li id="mwAZE">Grandorder <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Archonta" title="Archonta" id="mwAZI">Archonta</a>: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bat" title="Bat" id="mwAZM">bats</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Primate" title="Primate" id="mwAZQ">primates</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Colugo" title="Colugo" id="mwAZU">colugos</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Treeshrew" title="Treeshrew" id="mwAZY">treeshrews</a> (now considered paraphyletic, with bats being closer to other groups)</li>
<li id="mwAZc">Grandorder <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ungulata" title="Ungulata" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAZg">Ungulata</a>: ungulates
<ul id="mwAZk"><li id="mwAZo">Order <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tubulidentata" title="Tubulidentata" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAZs">Tubulidentata</a> <i id="mwAZw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Incertae_sedis" title="Incertae sedis" id="mwAZ0">incertae sedis</a></i>: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aardvark" title="Aardvark" id="mwAZ4">aardvark</a></li>
<li id="mwAZ8">Mirorder <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eparctocyona" title="Eparctocyona" id="mwAaA">Eparctocyona</a>: †<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Condylarth" title="Condylarth" id="mwAaE">condylarths</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Whale" title="Whale" id="mwAaI">whales</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Artiodactyla" title="Artiodactyla" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAaM">artiodactyls</a> (even-toed ungulates)</li>
<li id="mwAaQ">Mirorder †<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Meridiungulata" title="Meridiungulata" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAaU">Meridiungulata</a>: South American ungulates</li>
<li id="mwAaY">Mirorder <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Altungulata" title="Altungulata" id="mwAac">Altungulata</a>: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Perissodactyla" title="Perissodactyla" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAag">perissodactyls</a> (odd-toed ungulates), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Elephant" title="Elephant" id="mwAak">elephants</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Manatee" title="Manatee" id="mwAao">manatees</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hyrax" title="Hyrax" id="mwAas">hyraxes</a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="4" id="mwAaw"><h3 id="Molecular_classification_of_placentals">Molecular classification of placentals</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAa0"><a href="./File:OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAa4"><img resource="./File:OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg/300px-OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="1674" data-file-height="1481" data-file-type="drawing" height="265" width="300" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg/450px-OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg/600px-OrthoMaM_v10b_2019_116genera_circular_tree.svg.png 2x" id="mwAa8"/></a><figcaption id="mwAbA">Genus-level molecular phylogeny of 116 extant mammals inferred from the gene tree information of 14,509 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coding_region" title="Coding region" id="mwAbE">coding DNA sequences</a>.<sup about="#mwt195" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Scornavacca2019_16-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Scornavacca2019"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Scornavacca2019-16"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Scornavacca2019-16" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 16;" id="mwAbI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAbM">[16]</span></a></sup> The major clades are colored: Marsupials (magenta), Xenarthrans (orange), afrotherians (red), laurasiatherians (green), and euarchontoglires (blue).</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAbQ">As of the early 21st century, molecular studies based on <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./DNA" title="DNA" id="mwAbU">DNA</a> analysis have suggested new relationships among mammal families. Most of these findings have been independently validated by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Retrotransposon" title="Retrotransposon" id="mwAbY">retrotransposon</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Retrotransposon_marker" title="Retrotransposon marker" id="mwAbc">presence/absence data</a>.<sup about="#mwt201" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kriegs2006_17-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kriegs2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Kriegs2006-17"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Kriegs2006-17" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 17;" id="mwAbg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAbk">[17]</span></a></sup> Classification systems based on molecular studies reveal three major groups or lineages of placental mammals—<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Afrotheria" title="Afrotheria" id="mwAbo">Afrotheria</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Xenarthra" title="Xenarthra" id="mwAbs">Xenarthra</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Boreoeutheria" title="Boreoeutheria" id="mwAbw">Boreoeutheria</a>—which <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Speciation" title="Speciation" id="mwAb0">diverged</a> in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cretaceous" title="Cretaceous" id="mwAb4">Cretaceous</a>. The relationships between these three lineages is contentious, and all three possible hypotheses have been proposed with respect to which group is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Basal_(phylogenetics)" title="Basal (phylogenetics)" id="mwAb8">basal</a>. These hypotheses are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atlantogenata" title="Atlantogenata" id="mwAcA">Atlantogenata</a> (basal Boreoeutheria), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Epitheria" title="Epitheria" id="mwAcE">Epitheria</a> (basal Xenarthra) and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Exafroplacentalia" title="Exafroplacentalia" id="mwAcI">Exafroplacentalia</a> (basal Afrotheria).<sup about="#mwt205" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Nishiharaetal2009_18-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Nishiharaetal2009"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Nishiharaetal2009-18"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Nishiharaetal2009-18" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 18;" id="mwAcM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAcQ">[18]</span></a></sup> Boreoeutheria in turn contains two major lineages—<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Euarchontoglires" title="Euarchontoglires" id="mwAcU">Euarchontoglires</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Laurasiatheria" title="Laurasiatheria" id="mwAcY">Laurasiatheria</a>.</p>

<p id="mwAcc">Estimates for the divergence times between these three placental groups range from 105 to 120<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAcg"> </span>million years ago, depending on the type of DNA used (such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nuclear_DNA" title="Nuclear DNA" id="mwAck">nuclear</a> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mitochondrial_DNA" title="Mitochondrial DNA" id="mwAco">mitochondrial</a>)<sup about="#mwt211" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-19" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-19"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-19" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 19;" id="mwAcs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAcw">[19]</span></a></sup> and varying interpretations of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paleogeographic" title="Paleogeographic" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAc0">paleogeographic</a> data.<sup about="#mwt212" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Nishiharaetal2009_18-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Nishiharaetal2009"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Nishiharaetal2009-18" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 18;" id="mwAc4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAc8">[18]</span></a></sup></p>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1129740115" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt213" data-mw="{&quot;parts&quot;:[{&quot;template&quot;:{&quot;target&quot;:{&quot;wt&quot;:&quot;clade&quot;,&quot;href&quot;:&quot;./Template:Clade&quot;},&quot;params&quot;:{&quot;style&quot;:{&quot;wt&quot;:&quot;font-size:100%;line-height:100%&quot;},&quot;label1&quot;:{&quot;wt&quot;:&quot;'''Mammalia'''&quot;},&quot;1&quot;:{&quot;wt&quot;:&quot;{{Clade\n   |1=[[Monotremata]] [[File:Genera mammalium Ornithorhynchus anatinus.jpg|50 px|''Ornithorhynchus anatinus'']]\n   |label2=[[Theria]]\n   |2={{Clade\n      |1=[[Marsupialia]] [[File:A monograph of the Macropodidæ, or family of kangaroos (9398404841) white background.jpg|50 px|Macropodidæ]]\n      |label2=[[Placentalia]]\n         |2={{Clade\n            |label1=[[Atlantogenata]]\n            |1={{Clade\n               |1=[[Afrotheria]] [[File:Indian elephant white background.jpg|50 px|''Elephas maximus'']] [[File:Manatee white background.jpg|50 px|''Trichechus'']]\n               |2=[[Xenarthra]] [[File:Nine-banded-Armadillo white background.jpg|50 px|''Dasypus novemcinctus'']] [[File:Natural history of the animal kingdom for the use of young people (Plate XV) (Myrmecophaga tridactyla).jpg|50 px|''Myrmecophaga tridactyla'']]\n               }}\n            |label2=[[Boreoeutheria]]\n            |2={{Clade\n               |label1=[[Euarchontoglires]]\n               |1={{Clade\n                  |1=[[Euarchonta]] [[File:Die Säugthiere in Abbildungen nach der Natur, mit Beschreibungen (Plate 8) (white background).jpg|50 px|''Cebus olivaceus'']] [[File:Bechuana of Distinction-1841 (white background).jpg|50 px|''Homo sapiens'']]\n                  |2=[[Glires]] [[File:Ruskea rotta.png|50 px|''Rattus'']] [[File:Bruno Liljefors - Hare studies 1885 white background.jpg|50 px|''Lepus'']]\n                  }}\n               |label2=[[Laurasiatheria]]\n               |2={{Clade\n                  |1=[[Eulipotyphla]] [[File:Mole white background.jpg|50 px|Talpidae]]\n                  |label2=[[Scrotifera]]\n                  |2={{Clade\n                     |1=[[Chiroptera]] [[File:Vampire bat white background.jpg|50 px|Desmodontinae]]\n                     |label2=\n                     |2={{Clade\n         |label1=[[Euungulata]]\n                        |1={{Clade\n                           |1=[[Artiodactyla]] [[File:Walia ibex illustration white background.png|50 px|''Capra walie'']] [[File:Eubalaena glacialis NOAA.jpg|70 px|''Eubalaena glacialis'']]\n                           |2=[[Perissodactyla]] [[File:Equus quagga (white background).jpg|50 px|''Equus quagga'']] [[File:Rhino white background.jpg|50 px|''Diceros bicornis'']]\n                           }}\n                        |label2=[[Ferae]]\n                        |2={{Clade\n                           |1=[[Pholidota]] [[File:FMIB 46859 Pangolin a grosse queue white background.jpeg|50 px|Manidae]]\n                           |2=[[Carnivora]] [[File:Cynailurus guttata - 1818-1842 - Print - Iconographia Zoologica - Special Collections University of Amsterdam - (white background).jpg|50px|''Acinonyx jubatus'']] [[File:Zalophus californianus J. Smit (white background).jpg|50 px|''Zalophus californianus'']]\n                           }}\n                        }}\n                     }}\n                  }}\n               }}\n            }}\n         }}\n      }}&quot;}},&quot;i&quot;:0}}]}" id="mwAdA">.mw-parser-output table.clade{border-spacing:0;margin:0;font-size:100%;line-height:100%;border-collapse:separate;width:auto}.mw-parser-output table.clade table.clade{width:100%;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output </span><table class="clade" style="font-size:100%;line-height:100%" about="#mwt213">

<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"><b>Mammalia</b></td>
<td rowspan="2" class="clade-leaf">
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129740115" about="#mwt238" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles" data-mw='{"name":"templatestyles","attrs":{"src":"Template:Clade/styles.css"},"body":{"extsrc":""}}'/>
<table class="clade">

<tbody><tr>
<td class="clade-label first"></td>
<td rowspan="2" class="clade-leaf">

(2016)<sup about="#mwt253" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-20" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-20"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-20" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 20;" id="mwAdQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAdU">[20]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="5" id="mwAdY"><h2 id="Evolution">Evolution</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt254" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Evolution of mammals"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAdc"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt254" id="mwAdg">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Evolution_of_mammals" title="Evolution of mammals">Evolution of mammals</a></div>

<section data-mw-section-id="6" id="mwAdk"><h3 id="Origins">Origins</h3>
<p id="mwAdo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Synapsida" title="Synapsida" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAds">Synapsida</a>, a clade that contains mammals and their extinct relatives, originated during the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pennsylvanian_(geology)" title="Pennsylvanian (geology)" id="mwAdw">Pennsylvanian subperiod</a> (~323<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAd0"> </span>million to ~300<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAd4"> </span>million years ago), when they split from the reptile lineage. Crown group mammals evolved from earlier <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammaliaformes" title="Mammaliaformes" id="mwAd8">mammaliaforms</a> during the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Early_Jurassic" title="Early Jurassic" id="mwAeA">Early Jurassic</a>. The cladogram takes Mammalia to be the crown group.<sup about="#mwt261" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Liaoconodon2011_21-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Liaoconodon2011"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Liaoconodon2011-21"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Liaoconodon2011-21" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 21;" id="mwAeE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAeI">[21]</span></a></sup></p>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129740115" about="#mwt262" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"clade\n ","href":"./Template:Clade"},"params":{"label1":{"wt":"[[Mammaliaformes]]"},"1":{"wt":"{{clade\n            |1=[[Morganucodontidae]] [[File:Morganucodon.jpg|50px]]\n            |2={{clade\n                 |1=[[Docodonta]] [[File:Docofossor NT flipped.jpg|50px]]\n                 |2={{clade\n                           |1=&apos;&apos;[[Haldanodon]]&apos;&apos;\n                           |label2=&apos;&apos;&apos;Mammalia&apos;&apos;&apos;\n                           |2={{clade\n                                |1=[[Australosphenida]] (incl. [[Monotremata]]) [[File:Steropodon BW.jpg|50px]]\n                                |2={{clade\n                                  |1=&apos;&apos;[[Fruitafossor]]&apos;&apos;\n                                  |2={{clade\n                                     |1={{clade\n                                         |1=&apos;&apos;[[Haramiyavia]]&apos;&apos;\n                                         |2=[[Multituberculata]] [[File:Sunnyodon.jpg|50px]]\n                                   }}\n                                     |2=&apos;&apos;[[Tinodon]]&apos;&apos;\n                                     |3=[[Eutriconodonta]] (incl. [[Gobiconodonta]]) [[File:Repenomamus BW.jpg|50px]]\n                                     |4=[[Trechnotheria]] (incl. [[Theria]]) [[File:Juramaia NT.jpg|50px]]\n                               }}\n                         }}\n                    }}\n               }}\n          }}\n     }}"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAeM"/><span about="#mwt262">
</span><table class="clade" about="#mwt262">
