</tbody></table>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="7" id="mwAeQ"><h3 id="Evolution_from_older_amniotes">Evolution from older amniotes</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAeU"><a href="./File:Skull_synapsida_1.png" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAeY"><img resource="./File:Skull_synapsida_1.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Skull_synapsida_1.png/220px-Skull_synapsida_1.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="568" data-file-height="260" data-file-type="bitmap" height="101" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Skull_synapsida_1.png/330px-Skull_synapsida_1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Skull_synapsida_1.png/440px-Skull_synapsida_1.png 2x" id="mwAec"/></a><figcaption id="mwAeg">The original synapsid skull structure contains one <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Temporal_fenestrae" title="Temporal fenestrae" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAek">temporal opening</a> behind the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eye_socket" title="Eye socket" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAeo">orbitals</a>, in a fairly low position on the skull (lower right in this image). This opening might have assisted in containing the jaw muscles of these organisms which could have increased their biting strength.</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwAes">The first fully terrestrial <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate" id="mwAew">vertebrates</a> were <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Amniote" title="Amniote" id="mwAe0">amniotes</a>. Like their amphibious early <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tetrapod" title="Tetrapod" id="mwAe4">tetrapod</a> predecessors, they had lungs and limbs. Amniotic eggs, however, have internal membranes that allow the developing <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Embryo" title="Embryo" id="mwAe8">embryo</a> to breathe but keep water in. Hence, amniotes can lay eggs on dry land, while <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Amphibian" title="Amphibian" id="mwAfA">amphibians</a> generally need to lay their eggs in water.</p>

<p id="mwAfE">The first amniotes apparently arose in the Pennsylvanian subperiod of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carboniferous" title="Carboniferous" id="mwAfI">Carboniferous</a>. They descended from earlier <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Reptiliomorpha" title="Reptiliomorpha" id="mwAfM">reptiliomorph</a> amphibious tetrapods,<sup about="#mwt294" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-AhlbergMilner1994OriginOfTetrapods_22-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"AhlbergMilner1994OriginOfTetrapods"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-AhlbergMilner1994OriginOfTetrapods-22"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-AhlbergMilner1994OriginOfTetrapods-22" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 22;" id="mwAfQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAfU">[22]</span></a></sup> which lived on land that was already inhabited by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Insect" title="Insect" id="mwAfY">insects</a> and other invertebrates as well as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fern" title="Fern" id="mwAfc">ferns</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Moss" title="Moss" id="mwAfg">mosses</a> and other plants. Within a few million years, two important amniote lineages became distinct: the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Synapsid" title="Synapsid" id="mwAfk">synapsids</a>, which would later include the common ancestor of the mammals; and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sauropsid" title="Sauropsid" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAfo">sauropsids</a>, which now include <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Turtle" title="Turtle" id="mwAfs">turtles</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lizard" title="Lizard" id="mwAfw">lizards</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Snake" title="Snake" id="mwAf0">snakes</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crocodilian" title="Crocodilian" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAf4">crocodilians</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur" title="Dinosaur" id="mwAf8">dinosaurs</a> (including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bird" title="Bird" id="mwAgA">birds</a>).<sup about="#mwt298" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-23" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-23"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-23" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 23;" id="mwAgE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgI">[23]</span></a></sup> Synapsids have a single hole (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Temporal_fenestra" title="Temporal fenestra" id="mwAgM">temporal fenestra</a>) low on each side of the skull. Primitive synapsids included the largest and fiercest animals of the early <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Permian" title="Permian" id="mwAgQ">Permian</a> such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dimetrodon" title="Dimetrodon" id="mwAgU">Dimetrodon</a>.<sup about="#mwt302" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-24" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-24"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-24" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 24;" id="mwAgY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgc">[24]</span></a></sup> Nonmammalian synapsids were traditionally—and incorrectly—called "mammal-like reptiles" or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pelycosaurs" title="Pelycosaurs" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAgg">pelycosaurs</a>; we now know they were neither reptiles nor part of reptile lineage.<sup about="#mwt303" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kemp2006_25-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kemp2006"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Kemp2006-25" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 25;" id="mwAgk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgo">[25]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt304" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Bennett1986_26-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Bennett1986"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Bennett1986-26" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 26;" id="mwAgs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgw">[26]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAg0"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Therapsid" title="Therapsid" id="mwAg4">Therapsids</a>, a group of synapsids, evolved in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Guadalupian" title="Guadalupian" id="mwAg8">Middle Permian</a>, about 265<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAhA"> </span>million years ago, and became the dominant land vertebrates.<sup about="#mwt311" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kemp2006_25-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kemp2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Kemp2006-25"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Kemp2006-25" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 25;" id="mwAhE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAhI">[25]</span></a></sup> They differ from basal <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eupelycosauria" title="Eupelycosauria" id="mwAhM">eupelycosaurs</a> in several features of the skull and jaws, including: larger skulls and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Incisor" title="Incisor" id="mwAhQ">incisors</a> which are equal in size in therapsids, but not for eupelycosaurs.<sup about="#mwt312" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kemp2006_25-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kemp2006"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Kemp2006-25" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 25;" id="mwAhU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAhY">[25]</span></a></sup> The therapsid lineage leading to mammals went through a series of stages, beginning with animals that were very similar to their early synapsid ancestors and ending with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Probainognathia" title="Probainognathia" id="mwAhc">probainognathian</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cynodont" title="Cynodont" id="mwAhg">cynodonts</a>, some of which could easily be mistaken for mammals. Those stages were characterized by:<sup about="#mwt316" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kermack1984_27-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kermack1984"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Kermack1984-27"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Kermack1984-27" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 27;" id="mwAhk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAho">[27]</span></a></sup></p>
<ul id="mwAhs"><li id="mwAhw">The gradual development of a bony secondary <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hard_palate" title="Hard palate" id="mwAh0">palate</a>.</li>
<li id="mwAh4">Abrupt acquisition of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Endothermy" title="Endothermy" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAh8">endothermy</a> among <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammaliamorpha" title="Mammaliamorpha" id="mwAiA">Mammaliamorpha</a>, thus prior to the origin of mammals by 30-50 millions of years <i id="mwAiE"><b id="mwAiI"><sup about="#mwt321" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-28" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-28"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-28" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 28;" id="mwAiM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAiQ">[28]</span></a></sup></b></i>.</li>
<li id="mwAiU">Progression towards an erect limb posture, which would increase the animals' stamina by avoiding <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carrier's_constraint" title="Carrier's constraint" id="mwAiY">Carrier's constraint</a>. But this process was slow and erratic: for example, all herbivorous nonmammaliaform therapsids retained sprawling limbs (some late forms may have had semierect hind limbs); Permian carnivorous therapsids had sprawling forelimbs, and some late Permian ones also had semisprawling hindlimbs. In fact, modern monotremes still have semisprawling limbs.</li>
<li id="mwAic">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mandible#In_other_vertebrates" title="Mandible" id="mwAig">dentary</a> gradually became the main bone of the lower jaw which, by the Triassic, progressed towards the fully mammalian jaw (the lower consisting only of the dentary) and middle ear (which is constructed by the bones that were previously used to construct the jaws of reptiles).</li></ul>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="8" id="mwAik"><h3 id="First_mammals">First mammals</h3>
<p id="mwAio">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Permian–Triassic_extinction_event" title="Permian–Triassic extinction event" id="mwAis">Permian–Triassic extinction event</a> about 252<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAiw"> </span>million years ago, which was a prolonged event due to the accumulation of several extinction pulses, ended the dominance of carnivorous therapsids.<sup about="#mwt331" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-29" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-29"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-29" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 29;" id="mwAi0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAi4">[29]</span></a></sup> In the early Triassic, most medium to large land carnivore niches were taken over by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Archosaur" title="Archosaur" id="mwAi8">archosaurs</a><sup about="#mwt335" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-30" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-30"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-30" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 30;" id="mwAjA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAjE">[30]</span></a></sup> which, over an extended period (35<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAjI"> </span>million years), came to include the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crocodylomorpha" title="Crocodylomorpha" id="mwAjM">crocodylomorphs</a>,<sup about="#mwt339" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-31" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-31"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-31" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 31;" id="mwAjQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAjU">[31]</span></a></sup> the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pterosaur" title="Pterosaur" id="mwAjY">pterosaurs</a> and the dinosaurs;<sup about="#mwt343" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-32" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-32"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-32" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 32;" id="mwAjc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAjg">[32]</span></a></sup> however, large cynodonts like <i id="mwAjk"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Trucidocynodon" title="Trucidocynodon" id="mwAjo">Trucidocynodon</a></i> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Traversodontidae" title="Traversodontidae" id="mwAjs">traversodontids</a> still occupied large sized carnivorous and herbivorous niches respectively. By the Jurassic, the dinosaurs had come to dominate the large terrestrial herbivore niches as well.<sup about="#mwt347" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-33" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-33"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-33" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 33;" id="mwAjw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAj0">[33]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAj4">The first mammals (in Kemp's sense) appeared in the Late Triassic epoch (about 225<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAj8"> </span>million years ago), 40<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAkA"> </span>million years after the first therapsids. They expanded out of their nocturnal <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Insectivore" title="Insectivore" id="mwAkE">insectivore</a> niche from the mid-Jurassic onwards;<sup about="#mwt356" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-34" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-34"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-34" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 34;" id="mwAkI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAkM">[34]</span></a></sup> The Jurassic <i id="mwAkQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Castorocauda" title="Castorocauda" id="mwAkU">Castorocauda</a></i>, for example, was a close relative of true mammals that had adaptations for swimming, digging and catching fish.<sup about="#mwt360" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-35" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-35"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-35" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 35;" id="mwAkY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAkc">[35]</span></a></sup> Most, if not all, are thought to have remained nocturnal (the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nocturnal_bottleneck" title="Nocturnal bottleneck" id="mwAkg">nocturnal bottleneck</a>), accounting for much of the typical mammalian traits.<sup about="#mwt364" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-36" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-36"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-36" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 36;" id="mwAkk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAko">[36]</span></a></sup> The majority of the mammal species that existed in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mesozoic" title="Mesozoic" id="mwAks">Mesozoic Era</a> were multituberculates, eutriconodonts and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spalacotheriid" title="Spalacotheriid" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAkw">spalacotheriids</a>.<sup about="#mwt368" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Luo2007_37-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Luo2007"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Luo2007-37"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Luo2007-37" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 37;" id="mwAk0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAk4">[37]</span></a></sup> The earliest known <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metatherian" title="Metatherian" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAk8">metatherian</a> is <i id="mwAlA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sinodelphys" title="Sinodelphys" id="mwAlE">Sinodelphys</a></i>, found in 125<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAlI"> </span>million-year-old <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Early_Cretaceous" title="Early Cretaceous" id="mwAlM">Early Cretaceous</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shale" title="Shale" id="mwAlQ">shale</a> in China's northeastern <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Liaoning_Province" title="Liaoning Province" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAlU">Liaoning Province</a>. The fossil is nearly complete and includes tufts of fur and imprints of soft tissues.<sup about="#mwt372" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-38" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-38"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-38" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 38;" id="mwAlY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAlc">[38]</span></a></sup></p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAlg"><a href="./File:Juramaia_NT.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAlk"><img resource="./File:Juramaia_NT.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Juramaia_NT.jpg/220px-Juramaia_NT.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="287" data-file-type="bitmap" height="126" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Juramaia_NT.jpg/330px-Juramaia_NT.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Juramaia_NT.jpg/440px-Juramaia_NT.jpg 2x" id="mwAlo"/></a><figcaption id="mwAls">Restoration of <i id="mwAlw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Juramaia" title="Juramaia" id="mwAl0">Juramaia sinensis</a></i>, the oldest known <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eutheria" title="Eutheria" id="mwAl4">Eutherian</a> (160 M.Y.A.)<sup about="#mwt374" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Juramaia_39-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Juramaia"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Juramaia-39" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 39;" id="mwAl8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAmA">[39]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAmE">The oldest known fossil among the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eutheria" title="Eutheria" id="mwAmI">Eutheria</a> ("true beasts") is the small shrewlike <i id="mwAmM"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Juramaia" title="Juramaia" id="mwAmQ">Juramaia sinensis</a></i>, or "Jurassic mother from China", dated to 160<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAmU"> </span>million years ago in the late Jurassic.<sup about="#mwt382" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Juramaia_39-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Juramaia"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Juramaia-39"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Juramaia-39" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 39;" id="mwAmY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAmc">[39]</span></a></sup> A later eutherian relative, <i id="mwAmg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eomaia" title="Eomaia" id="mwAmk">Eomaia</a></i>, dated to 125<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAmo"> </span>million years ago in the early Cretaceous, possessed some features in common with the marsupials but not with the placentals, evidence that these features were present in the last common ancestor of the two groups but were later lost in the placental lineage.<sup about="#mwt386" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-40" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-40"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-40" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 40;" id="mwAms"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAmw">[40]</span></a></sup> In particular, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Epipubic_bone" title="Epipubic bone" id="mwAm0">epipubic bones</a> extend forwards from the pelvis. These are not found in any modern placental, but they are found in marsupials, monotremes, other nontherian mammals and <i id="mwAm4"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ukhaatherium" title="Ukhaatherium" id="mwAm8">Ukhaatherium</a></i>, an early Cretaceous animal in the eutherian order <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Asioryctitheria" title="Asioryctitheria" id="mwAnA">Asioryctitheria</a>. This also applies to the multituberculates.<sup about="#mwt390" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Epipubic_bones_in_eutherian_mammals_41-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Epipubic bones in eutherian mammals"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Epipubic_bones_in_eutherian_mammals-41"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Epipubic_bones_in_eutherian_mammals-41" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 41;" id="mwAnE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAnI">[41]</span></a></sup> They are apparently an ancestral feature, which subsequently disappeared in the placental lineage. These epipubic bones seem to function by stiffening the muscles during locomotion, reducing the amount of space being presented, which placentals require to contain their <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fetus" title="Fetus" id="mwAnM">fetus</a> during gestation periods. A narrow pelvic outlet indicates that the young were very small at birth and therefore <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pregnancy_(mammals)" title="Pregnancy (mammals)" id="mwAnQ">pregnancy</a> was short, as in modern marsupials. This suggests that the placenta was a later development.<sup about="#mwt394" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-42" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-42"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-42" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 42;" id="mwAnU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAnY">[42]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAnc">One of the earliest known monotremes was <i id="mwAng"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Teinolophos" title="Teinolophos" id="mwAnk">Teinolophos</a></i>, which lived about 120<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAno"> </span>million years ago in Australia.<sup about="#mwt401" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-43" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-43"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-43" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 43;" id="mwAns"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAnw">[43]</span></a></sup> Monotremes have some features which may be inherited from the original amniotes such as the same orifice to urinate, defecate and reproduce (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cloaca" title="Cloaca" id="mwAn0">cloaca</a>)—as lizards and birds also do—<sup about="#mwt405" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-44" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-44"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-44" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 44;" id="mwAn4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAn8">[44]</span></a></sup> and they lay <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Egg_(biology)" title="Egg (biology)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAoA">eggs</a> which are leathery and uncalcified.<sup about="#mwt409" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-45" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-45"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-45" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 45;" id="mwAoE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAoI">[45]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="9" id="mwAoM"><h3 id="Earliest_appearances_of_features">Earliest appearances of features</h3>

<p id="mwAoQ"><i id="mwAoU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hadrocodium" title="Hadrocodium" id="mwAoY">Hadrocodium</a></i>, whose fossils date from approximately 195<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAoc"> </span>million years ago, in the early <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jurassic" title="Jurassic" id="mwAog">Jurassic</a>, provides the first clear evidence of a jaw joint formed solely by the squamosal and dentary bones; there is no space in the jaw for the articular, a bone involved in the jaws of all early synapsids.<sup about="#mwt414" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-jawbone2006_46-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"jawbone2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-jawbone2006-46"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-jawbone2006-46" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 46;" id="mwAok"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAoo">[46]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAos"><a href="./File:Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAow"><img resource="./File:Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg/220px-Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="840" data-file-height="315" data-file-type="bitmap" height="83" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg/330px-Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg/440px-Thrinaxodon_Lionhinus.jpg 2x" id="mwAo0"/></a><figcaption id="mwAo4">Fossil of <i id="mwAo8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thrinaxodon" title="Thrinaxodon" id="mwApA">Thrinaxodon</a></i> at the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./National_Museum_of_Natural_History" title="National Museum of Natural History" id="mwApE">National Museum of Natural History</a></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwApI">The earliest clear evidence of hair or fur is in fossils of <i id="mwApM"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Castorocauda" title="Castorocauda" id="mwApQ">Castorocauda</a></i> and <i id="mwApU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megaconus" title="Megaconus" id="mwApY">Megaconus</a></i>, from 164<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwApc"> </span>million years ago in the mid-Jurassic. In the 1950s, it was suggested that the foramina (passages) in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maxilla" title="Maxilla" id="mwApg">maxillae</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Premaxilla" title="Premaxilla" id="mwApk">premaxillae</a> (bones in the front of the upper jaw) of cynodonts were channels which supplied blood vessels and nerves to vibrissae (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Whiskers" title="Whiskers" id="mwApo">whiskers</a>) and so were evidence of hair or fur;<sup about="#mwt424" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Brink1955_47-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Brink1955"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Brink1955-47"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Brink1955-47" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 47;" id="mwAps"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwApw">[47]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt428" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Kemp1982_48-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Kemp1982"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Kemp1982-48"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Kemp1982-48" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 48;" id="mwAp0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAp4">[48]</span></a></sup> it was soon pointed out, however, that foramina do not necessarily show that an animal had vibrissae, as the modern lizard <i id="mwAp8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tupinambis" title="Tupinambis" id="mwAqA">Tupinambis</a></i> has foramina that are almost identical to those found in the nonmammalian cynodont <i id="mwAqE"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thrinaxodon" title="Thrinaxodon" id="mwAqI">Thrinaxodon</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt432" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Bennett1986_26-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Bennett1986"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Bennett1986-26"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Bennett1986-26" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 26;" id="mwAqM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAqQ">[26]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt436" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-49" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-49"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-49" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 49;" id="mwAqU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAqY">[49]</span></a></sup> Popular sources, nevertheless, continue to attribute whiskers to <i id="mwAqc">Thrinaxodon</i>.<sup about="#mwt440" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-50" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-50"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-50" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 50;" id="mwAqg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAqk">[50]</span></a></sup> Studies on Permian <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coprolites" title="Coprolites" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAqo">coprolites</a> suggest that non-mammalian <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Synapsids" title="Synapsids" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAqs">synapsids</a> of the epoch already had fur, setting the evolution of hairs possibly as far back as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dicynodont" title="Dicynodont" id="mwAqw">dicynodonts</a>.<sup about="#mwt444" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-piotr_51-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"piotr"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-piotr-51"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-piotr-51" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 51;" id="mwAq0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAq4">[51]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAq8">When <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Endothermy" title="Endothermy" class="mw-redirect" id="mwArA">endothermy</a> first appeared in the evolution of mammals is uncertain, though it is generally agreed to have first evolved in non-mammalian <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Therapsids" title="Therapsids" class="mw-redirect" id="mwArE">therapsids</a>.<sup about="#mwt450" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-piotr_51-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"piotr"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-piotr-51" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 51;" id="mwArI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwArM">[51]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt454" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-52" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-52"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-52" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 52;" id="mwArQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwArU">[52]</span></a></sup> Modern monotremes have lower body temperatures and more variable metabolic rates than marsupials and placentals,<sup about="#mwt458" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Paul1988_53-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Paul1988"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Paul1988-53"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Paul1988-53" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 53;" id="mwArY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwArc">[53]</span></a></sup> but there is evidence that some of their ancestors, perhaps including ancestors of the therians, may have had body temperatures like those of modern therians.<sup about="#mwt462" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-54" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-54"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-54" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 54;" id="mwArg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwArk">[54]</span></a></sup> Likewise, some modern therians like afrotheres and xenarthrans have secondarily developed lower body temperatures.<sup about="#mwt466" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-55" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-55"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-55" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 55;" id="mwAro"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwArs">[55]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwArw">The evolution of erect limbs in mammals is incomplete—living and fossil monotremes have sprawling limbs. The parasagittal (nonsprawling) limb posture appeared sometime in the late Jurassic or early Cretaceous; it is found in the eutherian <i id="mwAr0">Eomaia</i> and the metatherian <i id="mwAr4">Sinodelphys</i>, both dated to 125<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAr8"> </span>million years ago.<sup about="#mwt472" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-56" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-56"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-56" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 56;" id="mwAsA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAsE">[56]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Epipubic" title="Epipubic" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAsI">Epipubic</a> bones, a feature that strongly influenced the reproduction of most mammal clades, are first found in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tritylodontidae" title="Tritylodontidae" id="mwAsM">Tritylodontidae</a>, suggesting that it is a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Synapomorphy" title="Synapomorphy" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAsQ">synapomorphy</a> between them and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammaliformes" title="Mammaliformes" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAsU">mammaliformes</a>. They are omnipresent in non-placental mammaliformes, though <i id="mwAsY"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megazostrodon" title="Megazostrodon" id="mwAsc">Megazostrodon</a></i> and <i id="mwAsg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Erythrotherium" title="Erythrotherium" id="mwAsk">Erythrotherium</a></i> appear to have lacked them.<sup about="#mwt476" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-57" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-57"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-57" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 57;" id="mwAso"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAss">[57]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAsw">It has been suggested that the original function of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lactation" title="Lactation" id="mwAs0">lactation</a> (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Milk" title="Milk" id="mwAs4">milk</a> production) was to keep eggs moist. Much of the argument is based on monotremes, the egg-laying mammals.<sup about="#mwt483" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-58" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-58"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-58" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 58;" id="mwAs8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAtA">[58]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt487" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-59" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-59"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-59" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 59;" id="mwAtE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAtI">[59]</span></a></sup> In human females, mammary glands become fully developed during puberty, regardless of pregnancy.<sup about="#mwt491" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-60" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-60"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-60" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 60;" id="mwAtM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAtQ">[60]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="10" id="mwAtU"><h3 id="Rise_of_the_mammals">Rise of the mammals</h3>
<p id="mwAtY">Therian mammals took over the medium- to large-sized ecological niches in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cenozoic" title="Cenozoic" id="mwAtc">Cenozoic</a>, after the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cretaceous–Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event" id="mwAtg">Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event</a> approximately 66<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAtk"> </span>million years ago emptied ecological space once filled by non-avian dinosaurs and other groups of reptiles, as well as various other mammal groups,<sup about="#mwt499" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates_61-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates-61"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates-61" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 61;" id="mwAto"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAts">[61]</span></a></sup> and underwent an exponential increase in body size (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megafauna#In_terrestrial_mammals" title="Megafauna" id="mwAtw">megafauna</a>).<sup about="#mwt503" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-F.A.Smith_62-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"F.A.Smith"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-F.A.Smith-62"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-F.A.Smith-62" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 62;" id="mwAt0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAt4">[62]</span></a></sup> Then mammals diversified very quickly; both birds and mammals show an exponential rise in diversity.<sup about="#mwt504" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates_61-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-SahneyBentonFerry2010LinksDiversityVertebrates-61" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 61;" id="mwAt8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAuA">[61]</span></a></sup> For example, the earliest known bat dates from about 50<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAuE"> </span>million years ago, only 16<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAuI"> </span>million years after the extinction of the non-avian dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt508" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-63" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-63"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-63" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 63;" id="mwAuM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAuQ">[63]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAuU">Molecular phylogenetic studies initially suggested that most placental orders diverged about 100 to 85<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAuY"> </span>million years ago and that modern families appeared in the period from the late <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eocene" title="Eocene" id="mwAuc">Eocene</a> through the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Miocene" title="Miocene" id="mwAug">Miocene</a>.<sup about="#mwt518" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Bininda2007_64-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Bininda2007"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Bininda2007-64"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Bininda2007-64" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 64;" id="mwAuk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAuo">[64]</span></a></sup> However, no placental fossils have been found from before the end of the Cretaceous.<sup about="#mwt519" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Wible2007_65-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Wible2007"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Wible2007-65" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 65;" id="mwAus"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAuw">[65]</span></a></sup> The earliest undisputed fossils of placentals come from the early <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paleocene" title="Paleocene" id="mwAu0">Paleocene</a>, after the extinction of the non-avian dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt523" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Wible2007_65-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Wible2007"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Wible2007-65"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Wible2007-65" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 65;" id="mwAu4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAu8">[65]</span></a></sup> (Scientists identified an early Paleocene animal named <i id="mwAvA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Protungulatum_donnae" title="Protungulatum donnae" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAvE">Protungulatum donnae</a></i> as one of the first placental mammals,<sup about="#mwt527" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-SCI-20130208_66-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"SCI-20130208"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-SCI-20130208-66"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-SCI-20130208-66" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 66;" id="mwAvI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAvM">[66]</span></a></sup> but it has since been reclassified as a non-placental eutherian.)<sup about="#mwt531" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-67" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-67"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-67" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 67;" id="mwAvQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAvU">[67]</span></a></sup> Recalibrations of genetic and morphological diversity rates have suggested a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maastrichtian" title="Maastrichtian" id="mwAvY">Late Cretaceous</a> origin for placentals, and a Paleocene origin for most modern clades.<sup about="#mwt535" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-68" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-68"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-68" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 68;" id="mwAvc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAvg">[68]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAvk">The earliest known ancestor of primates is <i id="mwAvo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Archicebus_achilles" title="Archicebus achilles" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAvs">Archicebus achilles</a></i><sup about="#mwt542" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NTR-20130606_69-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NTR-20130606"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-NTR-20130606-69"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-NTR-20130606-69" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 69;" id="mwAvw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAv0">[69]</span></a></sup> from around 55<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAv4"> </span>million years ago.<sup about="#mwt543" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NTR-20130606_69-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NTR-20130606"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-NTR-20130606-69" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 69;" id="mwAv8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwA">[69]</span></a></sup> This tiny primate weighed 20–30 grams (0.7–1.1 ounce) and could fit within a human palm.<sup about="#mwt544" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NTR-20130606_69-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NTR-20130606"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-NTR-20130606-69" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 69;" id="mwAwE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwI">[69]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAwM"><span class="anchor" id="Anatomy_and_morphology" about="#mwt545" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"anchor","href":"./Template:Anchor"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Anatomy and morphology"}},"i":0}}]}'></span></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="11" id="mwAwQ"><h2 id="Anatomy">Anatomy</h2>

<section data-mw-section-id="12" id="mwAwU"><h3 id="Distinguishing_features">Distinguishing features</h3>
<p id="mwAwY">Living mammal species can be identified by the presence of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sweat_gland" title="Sweat gland" id="mwAwc">sweat glands</a>, including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammary_gland" title="Mammary gland" id="mwAwg">those that are specialized to produce milk</a> to nourish their young.<sup about="#mwt551" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-70" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-70"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-70" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 70;" id="mwAwk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwo">[70]</span></a></sup> In classifying fossils, however, other features must be used, since soft tissue glands and many other features are not visible in fossils.<sup about="#mwt555" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-71" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-71"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-71" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 71;" id="mwAws"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAww">[71]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAw0">Many traits shared by all living mammals appeared among the earliest members of the group:</p>
<ul id="mwAw4"><li id="mwAw8"><b id="mwAxA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jaw" title="Jaw" id="mwAxE">Jaw joint</a></b> – The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dentary" title="Dentary" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAxI">dentary</a> (the lower jaw bone, which carries the teeth) and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Squamosal" title="Squamosal" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAxM">squamosal</a> (a small <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cranium" title="Cranium" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAxQ">cranial</a> bone) meet to form the joint. In most <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gnathostomata" title="Gnathostomata" id="mwAxU">gnathostomes</a>, including early <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Therapsida" title="Therapsida" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAxY">therapsids</a>, the joint consists of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Articular" title="Articular" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAxc">articular</a> (a small bone at the back of the lower jaw) and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Quadrate_bone" title="Quadrate bone" id="mwAxg">quadrate</a> (a small bone at the back of the upper jaw).<sup about="#mwt557" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-jawbone2006_46-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"jawbone2006"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-jawbone2006-46" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 46;" id="mwAxk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAxo">[46]</span></a></sup></li>
<li id="mwAxs"><b id="mwAxw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Middle_ear" title="Middle ear" id="mwAx0">Middle ear</a></b> – In crown-group mammals, sound is carried from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eardrum" title="Eardrum" id="mwAx4">eardrum</a> by a chain of three bones, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Malleus" title="Malleus" id="mwAx8">malleus</a>, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Incus" title="Incus" id="mwAyA">incus</a> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stapes" title="Stapes" id="mwAyE">stapes</a>. Ancestrally, the malleus and the incus are derived from the articular and the quadrate bones that constituted the jaw joint of early therapsids.<sup about="#mwt562" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-72" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-72"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-72" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 72;" id="mwAyI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAyM">[72]</span></a></sup></li>
<li id="mwAyQ"><b id="mwAyU">Tooth replacement</b> – Teeth can be replaced once (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diphyodonty" title="Diphyodonty" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAyY">diphyodonty</a>) or (as in toothed whales and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Muridae" title="Muridae" id="mwAyc">murid</a> rodents) not at all (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dentition" title="Dentition" id="mwAyg">monophyodonty</a>).<sup about="#mwt568" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-73" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-73"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-73" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 73;" id="mwAyk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAyo">[73]</span></a></sup> Elephants, manatees, and kangaroos continually grow new teeth throughout their life (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polyphyodont" title="Polyphyodont" id="mwAys">polyphyodonty</a>).<sup about="#mwt572" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-74" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-74"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-74" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 74;" id="mwAyw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAy0">[74]</span></a></sup></li>
<li id="mwAy4"><b id="mwAy8">Prismatic enamel</b> – The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tooth_enamel" title="Tooth enamel" id="mwAzA">enamel</a> coating on the surface of a tooth consists of prisms, solid, rod-like structures extending from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dentin" title="Dentin" id="mwAzE">dentin</a> to the tooth's surface.<sup about="#mwt577" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-75" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-75"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-75" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 75;" id="mwAzI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAzM">[75]</span></a></sup></li>
<li id="mwAzQ"><b id="mwAzU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Occipital_condyle" title="Occipital condyle" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAzY">Occipital condyles</a></b> – Two knobs at the base of the skull fit into the topmost <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cervical_vertebrae" title="Cervical vertebrae" id="mwAzc">neck vertebra</a>; most other <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tetrapod" title="Tetrapod" id="mwAzg">tetrapods</a>, in contrast, have only one such knob.<sup about="#mwt582" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-76" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-76"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-76" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 76;" id="mwAzk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAzo">[76]</span></a></sup></li></ul>

<p id="mwAzs">For the most part, these characteristics were not present in the Triassic ancestors of the mammals.<sup about="#mwt588" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-77" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-77"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-77" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 77;" id="mwAzw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAz0">[77]</span></a></sup> Nearly all mammaliaforms possess an epipubic bone, the exception being modern placentals.<sup about="#mwt589" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-schulkin_78-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"schulkin"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-schulkin-78" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 78;" id="mwAz4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAz8">[78]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="13" id="mwA0A"><h3 id="Sexual_dimorphism">Sexual dimorphism</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwA0E"><a href="./File:Aurochsfeatures.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwA0I"><img resource="./File:Aurochsfeatures.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aurochsfeatures.jpg/220px-Aurochsfeatures.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1041" data-file-height="776" data-file-type="bitmap" height="164" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aurochsfeatures.jpg/330px-Aurochsfeatures.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Aurochsfeatures.jpg/440px-Aurochsfeatures.jpg 2x" id="mwA0M"/></a><figcaption id="mwA0Q">Sexual dimorphism in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aurochs" title="Aurochs" id="mwA0U">aurochs</a>, the extinct wild ancestor of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cattle" title="Cattle" id="mwA0Y">cattle</a></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwA0c">On average, male mammals are larger than females, with males being at least 10% larger than females in over 45% of investigated species. Most mammalian orders also exhibit male-biased <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sexual_dimorphism" title="Sexual dimorphism" id="mwA0g">sexual dimorphism</a>, although some orders do not show any bias or are significantly female-biased (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lagomorpha" title="Lagomorpha" id="mwA0k">Lagomorpha</a>). Sexual size dimorphism increases with body size across mammals (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rensch's_rule" title="Rensch's rule" id="mwA0o">Rensch's rule</a>), suggesting that there are parallel selection pressures on both male and female size. Male-biased dimorphism relates to sexual selection on males through male–male competition for females, as there is a positive correlation between the degree of sexual selection, as indicated by mating systems, and the degree of male-biased size dimorphism. The degree of sexual selection is also positively correlated with male and female size across mammals. Further, parallel selection pressure on female mass is identified in that age at weaning is significantly higher in more <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polygynous" title="Polygynous" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA0s">polygynous</a> species, even when correcting for body mass. Also, the reproductive rate is lower for larger females, indicating that fecundity selection selects for smaller females in mammals. Although these patterns hold across mammals as a whole, there is considerable variation across orders.<sup about="#mwt594" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-79" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-79"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-79" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 79;" id="mwA0w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA00">[79]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="14" id="mwA04"><h3 id="Biological_systems">Biological systems</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt595" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Biological system"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA08"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt595" id="mwA1A">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biological_system" title="Biological system">Biological system</a></div>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwA1E"><a href="./File:Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif" class="mw-file-description" id="mwA1I"><img resource="./File:Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif/220px-Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif" decoding="async" data-file-width="620" data-file-height="399" data-file-type="bitmap" height="142" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif/330px-Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif/440px-Lung_expansion_simulation_with_Raccoon.gif 2x" id="mwA1M"/></a><figcaption id="mwA1Q"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Raccoon" title="Raccoon" id="mwA1U">Raccoon</a> lungs being inflated manually</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwA1Y">The majority of mammals have seven <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cervical_vertebrae" title="Cervical vertebrae" id="mwA1c">cervical vertebrae</a> (bones in the neck). The exceptions are the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Manatee" title="Manatee" id="mwA1g">manatee</a> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Two-toed_sloth" title="Two-toed sloth" id="mwA1k">two-toed sloth</a>, which have six, and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Three-toed_sloth" title="Three-toed sloth" id="mwA1o">three-toed sloth</a> which has nine.<sup about="#mwt604" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-80" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-80"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-80" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 80;" id="mwA1s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA1w">[80]</span></a></sup> All mammalian brains possess a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neocortex" title="Neocortex" id="mwA10">neocortex</a>, a brain region unique to mammals.<sup about="#mwt608" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-81" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-81"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-81" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 81;" id="mwA14"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA18">[81]</span></a></sup> Placental brains have a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Corpus_callosum" title="Corpus callosum" id="mwA2A">corpus callosum</a>, unlike monotremes and marsupials.<sup about="#mwt612" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-82" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-82"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-82" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 82;" id="mwA2E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA2I">[82]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA2M">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lung" title="Lung" id="mwA2Q">lungs</a> of mammals are spongy and honeycombed. Breathing is mainly achieved with the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diaphragm_(anatomy)" title="Diaphragm (anatomy)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA2U">diaphragm</a>, which divides the thorax from the abdominal cavity, forming a dome convex to the thorax. Contraction of the diaphragm flattens the dome, increasing the volume of the lung cavity. Air enters through the oral and nasal cavities, and travels through the larynx, trachea and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bronchi" title="Bronchi" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA2Y">bronchi</a>, and expands the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pulmonary_alveolus" title="Pulmonary alveolus" id="mwA2c">alveoli</a>. Relaxing the diaphragm has the opposite effect, decreasing the volume of the lung cavity, causing air to be pushed out of the lungs. During exercise, the abdominal wall <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Muscle_contraction" title="Muscle contraction" id="mwA2g">contracts</a>, increasing pressure on the diaphragm, which forces air out quicker and more forcefully. The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rib_cage" title="Rib cage" id="mwA2k">rib cage</a> is able to expand and contract the chest cavity through the action of other respiratory muscles. Consequently, air is sucked into or expelled out of the lungs, always moving down its pressure gradient.<sup about="#mwt619" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-83" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-83"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-83" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 83;" id="mwA2o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA2s">[83]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt620" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bellows_84-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bellows"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-bellows-84" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 84;" id="mwA2w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA20">[84]</span></a></sup> This type of lung is known as a bellows lung due to its resemblance to blacksmith <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bellows" title="Bellows" id="mwA24">bellows</a>.<sup about="#mwt624" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bellows_84-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bellows"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-bellows-84"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-bellows-84" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 84;" id="mwA28"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA3A">[84]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA3E">The mammalian <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Heart" title="Heart" id="mwA3I">heart</a> has four chambers, two upper <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atrium_(heart)" title="Atrium (heart)" id="mwA3M">atria</a>, the receiving chambers, and two lower <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ventricle_(heart)" title="Ventricle (heart)" id="mwA3Q">ventricles</a>, the discharging chambers.<sup about="#mwt630" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-85" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-85"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-85" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 85;" id="mwA3U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA3Y">[85]</span></a></sup> The heart has four valves, which separate its chambers and ensures blood flows in the correct direction through the heart (preventing backflow). After <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gas_exchange" title="Gas exchange" id="mwA3c">gas exchange</a> in the pulmonary capillaries (blood vessels in the lungs), oxygen-rich blood returns to the left atrium via one of the four <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pulmonary_vein" title="Pulmonary vein" id="mwA3g">pulmonary veins</a>. Blood flows nearly continuously back into the atrium, which acts as the receiving chamber, and from here through an opening into the left ventricle. Most blood flows passively into the heart while both the atria and ventricles are relaxed, but toward the end of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diastole" title="Diastole" id="mwA3k">ventricular relaxation period</a>, the left atrium will contract, pumping blood into the ventricle. The heart also requires nutrients and oxygen found in blood like other muscles, and is supplied via <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coronary_circulation" title="Coronary circulation" id="mwA3o">coronary arteries</a>.<sup about="#mwt634" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-86" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-86"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-86" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 86;" id="mwA3s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA3w">[86]</span></a></sup></p>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt635" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"multiple image\n","href":"./Template:Multiple_image"},"params":{"align":{"wt":"center"},"footer":{"wt":"[[Educational toy|Didactic models]] of a //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_02-FMVZ_USP-08.jpeg/178px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_02-FMVZ_USP-08.jpeg 2x"/></a></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:201px;max-width:201px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:133px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg/199px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg" decoding="async" data-file-width="3872" data-file-height="2592" data-file-type="bitmap" height="133" width="199" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg/299px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg/398px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_03--FMVZ_USP-10.jpeg 2x"/></a></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:201px;max-width:201px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:133px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg/199px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg" decoding="async" data-file-width="3872" data-file-height="2592" data-file-type="bitmap" height="133" width="199" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg/299px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg/398px-Didactic_model_of_a_mammal_heart_04--FMVZ_USP-11.jpeg 2x"/></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flow-root"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Educational_toy" title="Educational toy">Didactic models</a> of a mammalian heart</div></div></div></div><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Pages_using_multiple_image_with_auto_scaled_images" about="#mwt635" id="mwA34"/>

<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwA38"><a href="./File:The_skin_of_mammals.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwA4A"><img resource="./File:The_skin_of_mammals.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/The_skin_of_mammals.jpg/235px-The_skin_of_mammals.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="550" data-file-height="700" data-file-type="bitmap" height="299" width="235" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/The_skin_of_mammals.jpg/353px-The_skin_of_mammals.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/The_skin_of_mammals.jpg/470px-The_skin_of_mammals.jpg 2x" id="mwA4E"/></a><figcaption id="mwA4I">Mammal skin: (1) <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hair" title="Hair" id="mwA4M">hair</a>, (2) <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Epidermis" title="Epidermis" id="mwA4Q">epidermis</a>, (3) <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sebaceous_gland" title="Sebaceous gland" id="mwA4U">sebaceous gland</a>, (4) <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arrector_pili_muscle" title="Arrector pili muscle" id="mwA4Y">Arrector pili muscle</a>, (5) <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dermis" title="Dermis" id="mwA4c">dermis</a>, (6) <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hair_follicle" title="Hair follicle" id="mwA4g">hair follicle</a>, (7) <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sweat_gland" title="Sweat gland" id="mwA4k">sweat gland</a>. Not labeled, the bottom layer: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hypodermis" title="Hypodermis" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA4o">hypodermis</a>, showing round <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Adipocytes" title="Adipocytes" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA4s">adipocytes</a></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwA4w">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Skin" title="Skin" id="mwA40">integumentary system</a> (skin) is made up of three layers: the outermost <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Epidermis_(skin)" title="Epidermis (skin)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA44">epidermis</a>, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dermis" title="Dermis" id="mwA48">dermis</a> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hypodermis" title="Hypodermis" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA5A">hypodermis</a>. The epidermis is typically 10 to 30 cells thick; its main function is to provide a waterproof layer. Its outermost cells are constantly lost; its bottommost cells are constantly dividing and pushing upward. The middle layer, the dermis, is 15 to 40 times thicker than the epidermis. The dermis is made up of many components, such as bony structures and blood vessels. The hypodermis is made up of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Adipose_tissue" title="Adipose tissue" id="mwA5E">adipose tissue</a>, which stores lipids and provides cushioning and insulation. The thickness of this layer varies widely from species to species;<sup about="#mwt644" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hair"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-hair-87" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwA5I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA5M">[87]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt641" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"97"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA5Q"><span title="Page / location: 97"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>97<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Marine_mammal" title="Marine mammal" id="mwA5U">marine mammals</a> require a thick hypodermis (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Blubber" title="Blubber" id="mwA5Y">blubber</a>) for insulation, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Right_whale" title="Right whale" id="mwA5c">right whales</a> have the thickest blubber at <span about="#mwt642" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"20"},"2":{"wt":"in"},"3":{"wt":"cm"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA5g">20 inches (51</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt642"> </span><span about="#mwt642">cm)</span>.<sup about="#mwt648" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-88" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-88"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-88" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 88;" id="mwA5k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA5o">[88]</span></a></sup> Although other animals have features such as whiskers, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feathers" title="Feathers" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA5s">feathers</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Setae" title="Setae" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA5w">setae</a>, or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cilia_(entomology)" title="Cilia (entomology)" id="mwA50">cilia</a> that superficially resemble it, no animals other than mammals have <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hair" title="Hair" id="mwA54">hair</a>. It is a definitive characteristic of the class, though some mammals have very little.<sup about="#mwt652" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hair"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-hair-87"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-hair-87" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwA58"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA6A">[87]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt643" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"61"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA6E"><span title="Page / location: 61"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>61<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup></p>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" about="#mwt653" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Multiple image\n","href":"./Template:Multiple_image"},"params":{"align":{"wt":"left"},"image1":{"wt":"Aardwolfskull.jpg"},"image2":{"wt":"Canis lupus 02 MWNH 358.jpg"},"footer":{"wt":"The [[carnassial]]s (teeth in the very back of the mouth) of the [[insectivorous]] [[aardwolf]] (left) vs. that of a [[gray wolf]] (right) which consumes large vertebrates"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA6I"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft" about="#mwt653" id="mwA6M"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:Aardwolfskull.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:Aardwolfskull.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Aardwolfskull.jpg/200px-Aardwolfskull.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="402" data-file-height="284" data-file-type="bitmap" height="141" width="200" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Aardwolfskull.jpg/300px-Aardwolfskull.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Aardwolfskull.jpg/400px-Aardwolfskull.jpg 2x"/></a></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg/200px-Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848" data-file-type="bitmap" height="133" width="200" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg/300px-Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg/400px-Canis_lupus_02_MWNH_358.jpg 2x"/></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnassial" title="Carnassial">carnassials</a> (teeth in the very back of the mouth) of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Insectivorous" title="Insectivorous" class="mw-redirect">insectivorous</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aardwolf" title="Aardwolf">aardwolf</a> (left) vs. that of a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gray_wolf" title="Gray wolf" class="mw-redirect">gray wolf</a> (right) which consumes large vertebrates</div></div></div></div>

<p id="mwA6Q">Herbivores have developed a diverse range of physical structures to facilitate the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Herbivore_adaptations_to_plant_defense" title="Herbivore adaptations to plant defense" id="mwA6U">consumption of plant material</a>. To break up intact plant tissues, mammals have developed <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Teeth" title="Teeth" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA6Y">teeth</a> structures that reflect their feeding preferences. For instance, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Frugivore" title="Frugivore" id="mwA6c">frugivores</a> (animals that feed primarily on fruit) and herbivores that feed on soft foliage have low-crowned teeth specialized for grinding foliage and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Seed" title="Seed" id="mwA6g">seeds</a>. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Grazing" title="Grazing" id="mwA6k">Grazing</a> animals that tend to eat hard, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Silica" title="Silica" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA6o">silica</a>-rich grasses, have high-crowned teeth, which are capable of grinding tough plant tissues and do not wear down as quickly as low-crowned teeth.<sup about="#mwt661" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-89" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-89"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-89" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 89;" id="mwA6s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA6w">[89]</span></a></sup> Most carnivorous mammals have <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnassial" title="Carnassial" id="mwA60">carnassialiforme</a> teeth (of varying length depending on diet), long canines and similar tooth replacement patterns.<sup about="#mwt665" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-90" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-90"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-90" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 90;" id="mwA64"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA68">[90]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA7A">The stomach of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Even-toed_ungulate" title="Even-toed ungulate" id="mwA7E">even-toed ungulates</a> (Artiodactyla) is divided into four sections: the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rumen" title="Rumen" id="mwA7I">rumen</a>, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Reticulum_(anatomy)" title="Reticulum (anatomy)" id="mwA7M">reticulum</a>, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Omasum" title="Omasum" id="mwA7Q">omasum</a> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abomasum" title="Abomasum" id="mwA7U">abomasum</a> (only <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ruminant" title="Ruminant" id="mwA7Y">ruminants</a> have a rumen). After the plant material is consumed, it is mixed with saliva in the rumen and reticulum and separates into solid and liquid material. The solids lump together to form a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bolus_(digestion)" title="Bolus (digestion)" id="mwA7c">bolus</a> (or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cud" title="Cud" id="mwA7g">cud</a>), and is regurgitated. When the bolus enters the mouth, the fluid is squeezed out with the tongue and swallowed again. Ingested food passes to the rumen and reticulum where cellulolytic <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Microbe" title="Microbe" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA7k">microbes</a> (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bacteria" title="Bacteria" id="mwA7o">bacteria</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Protozoa" title="Protozoa" id="mwA7s">protozoa</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fungus" title="Fungus" id="mwA7w">fungi</a>) produce <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cellulase" title="Cellulase" id="mwA70">cellulase</a>, which is needed to break down the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cellulose" title="Cellulose" id="mwA74">cellulose</a> in plants.<sup about="#mwt672" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Comparative_anatomy_of_the_stomach_91-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Comparative anatomy of the stomach"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Comparative_anatomy_of_the_stomach-91"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Comparative_anatomy_of_the_stomach-91" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 91;" id="mwA78"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA8A">[91]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Odd-toed_ungulate" title="Odd-toed ungulate" id="mwA8E">Perissodactyls</a>, in contrast to the ruminants, store digested food that has left the stomach in an enlarged <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cecum" title="Cecum" id="mwA8I">cecum</a>, where it is fermented by bacteria.<sup about="#mwt676" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-92" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-92"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-92" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 92;" id="mwA8M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA8Q">[92]</span></a></sup> Carnivora have a simple stomach adapted to digest primarily meat, as compared to the elaborate digestive systems of herbivorous animals, which are necessary to break down tough, complex plant fibers. The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Caecum" title="Caecum" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA8U">caecum</a> is either absent or short and simple, and the large intestine is not <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sacculation" title="Sacculation" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA8Y">sacculated</a> or much wider than the small intestine.<sup about="#mwt680" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-93" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-93"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-93" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 93;" id="mwA8c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA8g">[93]</span></a></sup></p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwA8k"><a href="./File:Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwA8o"><img resource="./File:Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg/220px-Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="3872" data-file-height="2592" data-file-type="bitmap" height="147" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg/330px-Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg/440px-Glycerination_of_Bovine_kidney.jpg 2x" id="mwA8s"/></a><figcaption id="mwA8w">Bovine kidney</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwA80">The mammalian <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Excretory_system" title="Excretory system" id="mwA84">excretory system</a> involves many components. Like most other land animals, mammals are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ureotelic" title="Ureotelic" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA88">ureotelic</a>, and convert <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ammonia" title="Ammonia" id="mwA9A">ammonia</a> into <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Urea" title="Urea" id="mwA9E">urea</a>, which is done by the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Liver" title="Liver" id="mwA9I">liver</a> as part of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Urea_cycle" title="Urea cycle" id="mwA9M">urea cycle</a>.<sup about="#mwt693" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-94"
