rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-94"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-94" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 94;" id="mwA9Q"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA9U">[94]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bilirubin" title="Bilirubin" id="mwA9Y">Bilirubin</a>, a waste product derived from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Blood_cell" title="Blood cell" id="mwA9c">blood cells</a>, is passed through <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bile" title="Bile" id="mwA9g">bile</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Urine" title="Urine" id="mwA9k">urine</a> with the help of enzymes excreted by the liver.<sup about="#mwt697" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-95" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-95"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-95" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 95;" id="mwA9o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA9s">[95]</span></a></sup> The passing of bilirubin via bile through the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Intestinal_tract" title="Intestinal tract" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA9w">intestinal tract</a> gives mammalian <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feces" title="Feces" id="mwA90">feces</a> a distinctive brown coloration.<sup about="#mwt701" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-96" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-96"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-96" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 96;" id="mwA94"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA98">[96]</span></a></sup> Distinctive features of the mammalian kidney include the presence of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Renal_pelvis" title="Renal pelvis" id="mwA-A">renal pelvis</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Renal_pyramid" title="Renal pyramid" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA-E">renal pyramids</a>, and of a clearly distinguishable <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Renal_cortex" title="Renal cortex" id="mwA-I">cortex</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Renal_medulla" title="Renal medulla" id="mwA-M">medulla</a>, which is due to the presence of elongated <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Loop_of_Henle" title="Loop of Henle" id="mwA-Q">loops of Henle</a>. Only the mammalian kidney has a bean shape, although there are some exceptions, such as the multilobed <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Reniculate_kidney" title="Reniculate kidney" id="mwA-U">reniculate kidneys</a> of pinnipeds, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cetacea" title="Cetacea" id="mwA-Y">cetaceans</a> and bears.<sup about="#mwt705" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-97" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-97"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-97" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 97;" id="mwA-c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA-g">[97]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt706" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-VB_98-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"VB"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-VB-98" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 98;" id="mwA-k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA-o">[98]</span></a></sup> Most adult placental mammals have no remaining trace of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cloaca" title="Cloaca" id="mwA-s">cloaca</a>. In the embryo, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Embryonic_cloaca" title="Embryonic cloaca" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA-w">embryonic cloaca</a> divides into a posterior region that becomes part of the anus, and an anterior region that has different fates depending on the sex of the individual: in females, it develops into the vestibule that receives the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Urethra" title="Urethra" id="mwA-0">urethra</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vagina" title="Vagina" id="mwA-4">vagina</a>, while in males it forms the entirety of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Penile_urethra" title="Penile urethra" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA-8">penile urethra</a>.<sup about="#mwt707" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-VB_98-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"VB"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-VB-98" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 98;" id="mwA_A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA_E">[98]</span></a></sup> However, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tenrec" title="Tenrec" id="mwA_I">tenrecs</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Golden_mole" title="Golden mole" id="mwA_M">golden moles</a>, and some <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shrew" title="Shrew" id="mwA_Q">shrews</a> retain a cloaca as adults.<sup about="#mwt708" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-99" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-99"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-99" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 99;" id="mwA_U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA_Y">[99]</span></a></sup> In marsupials, the genital tract is separate from the anus, but a trace of the original cloaca does remain externally.<sup about="#mwt712" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-VB_98-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"VB"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-VB-98"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-VB-98" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 98;" id="mwA_c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA_g">[98]</span></a></sup> Monotremes, which translates from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek" id="mwA_k">Greek</a> into "single hole", have a true cloaca.<sup about="#mwt716" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-100" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-100"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-100" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 100;" id="mwA_o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA_s">[100]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="15" id="mwA_w"><h3 id="Sound_production">Sound production</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwA_0"><a href="./File:Animal_echolocation.svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwA_4"><img resource="./File:Animal_echolocation.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Animal_echolocation.svg/300px-Animal_echolocation.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="318" data-file-height="245" data-file-type="drawing" height="231" width="300" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Animal_echolocation.svg/450px-Animal_echolocation.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Animal_echolocation.svg/600px-Animal_echolocation.svg.png 2x" id="mwA_8"/></a><figcaption id="mwBAA">A diagram of ultrasonic signals emitted by a bat, and the echo from a nearby object</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBAE">As in all other tetrapods, mammals have a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Larynx" title="Larynx" id="mwBAI">larynx</a> that can quickly open and close to produce sounds, and a supralaryngeal <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vocal_tract" title="Vocal tract" id="mwBAM">vocal tract</a> which filters this sound. The lungs and surrounding musculature provide the air stream and pressure required to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phonate" title="Phonate" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBAQ">phonate</a>. The larynx controls the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pitch_(music)" title="Pitch (music)" id="mwBAU">pitch</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Loudness" title="Loudness" id="mwBAY">volume</a> of sound, but the strength the lungs exert to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Exhale" title="Exhale" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBAc">exhale</a> also contributes to volume. More primitive mammals, such as the echidna, can only hiss, as sound is achieved solely through exhaling through a partially closed larynx. Other mammals phonate using <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vocal_fold" title="Vocal fold" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBAg">vocal folds</a>. The movement or tenseness of the vocal folds can result in many sounds such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Purr" title="Purr" id="mwBAk">purring</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Screaming" title="Screaming" id="mwBAo">screaming</a>. Mammals can change the position of the larynx, allowing them to breathe through the nose while swallowing through the mouth, and to form both oral and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nasalization" title="Nasalization" id="mwBAs">nasal</a> sounds; nasal sounds, such as a dog whine, are generally soft sounds, and oral sounds, such as a dog bark, are generally loud.<sup about="#mwt718" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-fitchbrown2006_101-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"fitchbrown2006"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-fitchbrown2006-101" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 101;" id="mwBAw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBA0">[101]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left mw-default-audio-height" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBA4"><span id="mwBA8"><audio controls="" preload="none" height="32" width="220" resource="./File:Beluga_vocalizations.ogg" id="mwBBA"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9f/Beluga_vocalizations.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"' data-title="Original Ogg file (73 kbps)" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" id="mwBBE"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/9/9f/Beluga_vocalizations.ogg/Beluga_vocalizations.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg" data-title="MP3" data-shorttitle="MP3" id="mwBBI"/></audio></span><figcaption id="mwBBM"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Beluga_whale" title="Beluga whale" id="mwBBQ">Beluga whale</a> echolocation sounds</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBBU">Some mammals have a large larynx and thus a low-pitched voice, namely the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hammer-headed_bat" title="Hammer-headed bat" id="mwBBY">hammer-headed bat</a> (<i id="mwBBc">Hypsignathus monstrosus</i>) where the larynx can take up the entirety of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thoracic_cavity" title="Thoracic cavity" id="mwBBg">thoracic cavity</a> while pushing the lungs, heart, and trachea into the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abdomen" title="Abdomen" id="mwBBk">abdomen</a>.<sup about="#mwt727" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-102" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-102"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-102" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 102;" id="mwBBo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBBs">[102]</span></a></sup> Large vocal pads can also lower the pitch, as in the low-pitched roars of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Big_cat" title="Big cat" id="mwBBw">big cats</a>.<sup about="#mwt731" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-103" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-103"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-103" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 103;" id="mwBB0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBB4">[103]</span></a></sup> The production of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Infrasound" title="Infrasound" id="mwBB8">infrasound</a> is possible in some mammals such as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./African_elephant" title="African elephant" id="mwBCA">African elephant</a> (<i id="mwBCE">Loxodonta</i> spp.) and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Baleen_whale" title="Baleen whale" id="mwBCI">baleen whales</a>.<sup about="#mwt735" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-104" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-104"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-104" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 104;" id="mwBCM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBCQ">[104]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt739" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-105" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-105"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-105" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 105;" id="mwBCU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBCY">[105]</span></a></sup> Small mammals with small larynxes have the ability to produce <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ultrasound" title="Ultrasound" id="mwBCc">ultrasound</a>, which can be detected by modifications to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Middle_ear" title="Middle ear" id="mwBCg">middle ear</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cochlea" title="Cochlea" id="mwBCk">cochlea</a>. Ultrasound is inaudible to birds and reptiles, which might have been important during the Mesozoic, when birds and reptiles were the dominant predators. This private channel is used by some rodents in, for example, mother-to-pup communication, and by bats when echolocating. Toothed whales also use echolocation, but, as opposed to the vocal membrane that extends upward from the vocal folds, they have a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Melon_(cetacean)" title="Melon (cetacean)" id="mwBCo">melon</a> to manipulate sounds. Some mammals, namely the primates, have air sacs attached to the larynx, which may function to lower the resonances or increase the volume of sound.<sup about="#mwt743" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-fitchbrown2006_101-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"fitchbrown2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-fitchbrown2006-101"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-fitchbrown2006-101" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 101;" id="mwBCs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBCw">[101]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBC0">The vocal production system is controlled by the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cranial_nerve_nucleus" title="Cranial nerve nucleus" id="mwBC4">cranial nerve nuclei</a> in the brain, and supplied by the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Recurrent_laryngeal_nerve" title="Recurrent laryngeal nerve" id="mwBC8">recurrent laryngeal nerve</a> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Superior_laryngeal_nerve" title="Superior laryngeal nerve" id="mwBDA">superior laryngeal nerve</a>, branches of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vagus_nerve" title="Vagus nerve" id="mwBDE">vagus nerve</a>. The vocal tract is supplied by the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hypoglossal_nerve" title="Hypoglossal nerve" id="mwBDI">hypoglossal nerve</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Facial_nerve" title="Facial nerve" id="mwBDM">facial nerves</a>. Electrical stimulation of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Periaqueductal_gray" title="Periaqueductal gray" id="mwBDQ">periaqueductal gray</a> (PEG) region of the mammalian <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Midbrain" title="Midbrain" id="mwBDU">midbrain</a> elicit vocalizations. The ability to learn new vocalizations is only exemplified in humans, seals, cetaceans, elephants and possibly bats; in humans, this is the result of a direct connection between the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Motor_cortex" title="Motor cortex" id="mwBDY">motor cortex</a>, which controls movement, and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Motor_neuron" title="Motor neuron" id="mwBDc">motor neurons</a> in the spinal cord.<sup about="#mwt745" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-fitchbrown2006_101-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"fitchbrown2006"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-fitchbrown2006-101" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 101;" id="mwBDg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBDk">[101]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="16" id="mwBDo"><h3 id="Fur">Fur</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt746" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Fur"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBDs"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt746" id="mwBDw">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fur" title="Fur">Fur</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBD0"><a href="./File:Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-épic.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBD4"><img resource="./File:Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-épic.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg/220px-Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="613" data-file-height="269" data-file-type="bitmap" height="97" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg/330px-Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg/440px-Stekelvarken_Aiguilles_Porc-%C3%A9pic.jpg 2x" id="mwBD8"/></a><figcaption id="mwBEA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Porcupine" title="Porcupine" id="mwBEE">Porcupines</a> use their <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spine_(zoology)" title="Spine (zoology)" id="mwBEI">spines</a> for defense.</figcaption></figure>
<!--{{Multiple images
|align=right
|width1=128
|width2=124
|image1=Male White&#x2D;Cheeked Gibbon.jpg
|image2=Female White&#x2D;Cheeked Gibbon.jpg
|footer=Color can be a form of [[sexual dimorphism]] as seen in the male (left) and female (right) [[Northern white&#x2D;cheeked gibbon]]
}}-->

<p id="mwBEM">The primary function of the fur of mammals is <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thermoregulation" title="Thermoregulation" id="mwBEQ">thermoregulation</a>. Others include protection, sensory purposes, waterproofing, and camouflage.<sup about="#mwt755" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-dawson2014_106-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"dawson2014"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-dawson2014-106"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-dawson2014-106" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 106;" id="mwBEU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBEY">[106]</span></a></sup> Different types of fur serve different purposes:<sup about="#mwt756" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hair"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-hair-87" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwBEc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBEg">[87]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt751" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"99"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBEk"><span title="Page / location: 99"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>99<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup></p>
<ul id="mwBEo"><li id="mwBEs">Definitive – which may be <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Moulting" title="Moulting" id="mwBEw">shed</a> after reaching a certain length</li>
<li id="mwBE0">Vibrissae – sensory hairs, most commonly <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Whisker" title="Whisker" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBE4">whiskers</a></li>
<li id="mwBE8">Pelage – guard hairs, under-fur, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Awn_hair" title="Awn hair" id="mwBFA">awn hair</a></li>
<li id="mwBFE"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spine_(zoology)" title="Spine (zoology)" id="mwBFI">Spines</a> – stiff guard hair used for defense (such as in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Porcupine" title="Porcupine" id="mwBFM">porcupines</a>)</li>
<li id="mwBFQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bristle" title="Bristle" id="mwBFU">Bristles</a> – long hairs usually used in visual signals. (such as a lion's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mane_(lion)" title="Mane (lion)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBFY">mane</a>)</li>
<li id="mwBFc"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vellus_hair" title="Vellus hair" id="mwBFg">Velli</a> – often called "down fur" which insulates newborn mammals</li>
<li id="mwBFk"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wool" title="Wool" id="mwBFo">Wool</a> – long, soft and often curly</li></ul>

<section data-mw-section-id="17" id="mwBFs"><h4 id="Thermoregulation">Thermoregulation</h4>
<p id="mwBFw">Hair length is not a factor in thermoregulation: for example, some tropical mammals such as sloths have the same length of fur length as some arctic mammals but with less insulation; and, conversely, other tropical mammals with short hair have the same insulating value as arctic mammals. The denseness of fur can increase an animal's insulation value, and arctic mammals especially have dense fur; for example, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Musk_ox" title="Musk ox" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBF0">musk ox</a> has guard hairs measuring <span about="#mwt760" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"30"},"2":{"wt":"cm"},"3":{"wt":"in"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBF4">30</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt760"> </span><span about="#mwt760">cm (12</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt760"> </span><span about="#mwt760">in)</span> as well as a dense underfur, which forms an airtight coat, allowing them to survive in temperatures of <span about="#mwt761" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"-40"},"2":{"wt":"C"},"3":{"wt":"F"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBF8">−40</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt761"> </span><span about="#mwt761">°C (−40</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt761"> </span><span about="#mwt761">°F)</span>.<sup about="#mwt767" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-3" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hair"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-hair-87" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwBGA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBGE">[87]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt762" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"162–163"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBGI"><span title="Page / location: 162–163"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>162–163<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> Some desert mammals, such as camels, use dense fur to prevent solar heat from reaching their skin, allowing the animal to stay cool; a camel's fur may reach <span about="#mwt763" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"70"},"2":{"wt":"C"},"3":{"wt":"F"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBGM">70</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt763"> </span><span about="#mwt763">°C (158</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt763"> </span><span about="#mwt763">°F)</span> in the summer, but the skin stays at <span about="#mwt764" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"40"},"2":{"wt":"C"},"3":{"wt":"F"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBGQ">40</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt764"> </span><span about="#mwt764">°C (104</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt764"> </span><span about="#mwt764">°F)</span>.<sup about="#mwt768" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-4" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hair"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-hair-87" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwBGU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBGY">[87]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt765" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"188"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBGc"><span title="Page / location: 188"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>188<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aquatic_mammal" title="Aquatic mammal" id="mwBGg">Aquatic mammals</a>, conversely, trap air in their fur to conserve heat by keeping the skin dry.<sup about="#mwt769" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-5" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hair"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-hair-87" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwBGk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBGo">[87]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt766" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"162–163"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBGs"><span title="Page / location: 162–163"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>162–163<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBGw"><a href="./File:Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBG0"><img resource="./File:Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG/220px-Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG" decoding="async" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1400" data-file-type="bitmap" height="154" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG/330px-Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG/440px-Great_male_Leopard_in_South_Afrika-JD.JPG 2x" id="mwBG4"/></a><figcaption id="mwBG8">A <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Leopard" title="Leopard" id="mwBHA">leopard</a>'s <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Disruptive_coloration" title="Disruptive coloration" id="mwBHE">disruptively colored</a> coat provides <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Camouflage" title="Camouflage" id="mwBHI">camouflage</a> for this <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ambush_predator" title="Ambush predator" id="mwBHM">ambush predator</a>.</figcaption></figure>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="18" id="mwBHQ"><h4 id="Coloration">Coloration</h4>
<p id="mwBHU">Mammalian coats are colored for a variety of reasons, the major selective pressures including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Camouflage" title="Camouflage" id="mwBHY">camouflage</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sexual_selection" title="Sexual selection" id="mwBHc">sexual selection</a>, communication, and thermoregulation. Coloration in both the hair and skin of mammals is mainly determined by the type and amount of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Melanin" title="Melanin" id="mwBHg">melanin</a>; <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eumelanin" title="Eumelanin" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBHk">eumelanins</a> for brown and black colors and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pheomelanin" title="Pheomelanin" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBHo">pheomelanin</a> for a range of yellowish to reddish colors, giving mammals an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth_tone" title="Earth tone" id="mwBHs">earth tone</a>.<sup about="#mwt777" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-107" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-107"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-107" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 107;" id="mwBHw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBH0">[107]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt781" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-HiltonPond_108-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"HiltonPond"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-HiltonPond-108"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-HiltonPond-108" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 108;" id="mwBH4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBH8">[108]</span></a></sup> Some mammals have more vibrant colors; certain monkeys such <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mandrill" title="Mandrill" id="mwBIA">mandrills</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vervet_monkey" title="Vervet monkey" id="mwBIE">vervet monkeys</a>, and opossums such as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mexican_mouse_opossum" title="Mexican mouse opossum" id="mwBII">Mexican mouse opossums</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Derby's_woolly_opossum" title="Derby's woolly opossum" id="mwBIM">Derby's woolly opossums</a>, have blue skin due to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Structural_coloration" title="Structural coloration" id="mwBIQ">light diffraction</a> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Collagen" title="Collagen" id="mwBIU">collagen</a> fibers.<sup about="#mwt782" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Prum2004_109-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Prum2004"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Prum2004-109" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 109;" id="mwBIY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBIc">[109]</span></a></sup> Many sloths appear green because their fur hosts green <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Algae" title="Algae" id="mwBIg">algae</a>; this may be a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Symbiosis" title="Symbiosis" id="mwBIk">symbiotic</a> relation that affords <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Camouflage" title="Camouflage" id="mwBIo">camouflage</a> to the sloths.<sup about="#mwt786" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-110" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-110"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-110" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 110;" id="mwBIs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBIw">[110]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBI0">Camouflage is a powerful influence in a large number of mammals, as it helps to conceal individuals from predators or prey.<sup about="#mwt793" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bioscience.oxfordjournals.org_111-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bioscience.oxfordjournals.org"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-bioscience.oxfordjournals.org-111"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-bioscience.oxfordjournals.org-111" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 111;" id="mwBI4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBI8">[111]</span></a></sup> In arctic and subarctic mammals such as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arctic_fox" title="Arctic fox" id="mwBJA">arctic fox</a> (<i id="mwBJE">Alopex lagopus</i>), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Collared_lemming" title="Collared lemming" id="mwBJI">collared lemming</a> (<i id="mwBJM">Dicrostonyx groenlandicus</i>), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stoat" title="Stoat" id="mwBJQ">stoat</a> (<i id="mwBJU">Mustela erminea</i>), and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Snowshoe_hare" title="Snowshoe hare" id="mwBJY">snowshoe hare</a> (<i id="mwBJc">Lepus americanus</i>), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Seasonal_polyphenism" title="Seasonal polyphenism" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBJg">seasonal color change</a> between brown in summer and white in winter is driven largely by camouflage.<sup about="#mwt797" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-112" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-112"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-112" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 112;" id="mwBJk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBJo">[112]</span></a></sup> Some arboreal mammals, notably primates and marsupials, have shades of violet, green, or blue skin on parts of their bodies, indicating some distinct advantage in their largely <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arboreal" title="Arboreal" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBJs">arboreal</a> habitat due to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Convergent_evolution" title="Convergent evolution" id="mwBJw">convergent evolution</a>.<sup about="#mwt801" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Prum2004_109-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Prum2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Prum2004-109"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Prum2004-109" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 109;" id="mwBJ0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBJ4">[109]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBJ8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aposematism" title="Aposematism" id="mwBKA">Aposematism</a>, warning off possible predators, is the most likely explanation of the black-and-white pelage of many mammals which are able to defend themselves, such as in the foul-smelling <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Skunk" title="Skunk" id="mwBKE">skunk</a> and the powerful and aggressive <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Honey_badger" title="Honey badger" id="mwBKI">honey badger</a>.<sup about="#mwt812" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-113" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-113"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-113" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 113;" id="mwBKM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBKQ">[113]</span></a></sup> Coat color is sometimes <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sexual_dimorphism" title="Sexual dimorphism" id="mwBKU">sexually dimorphic</a>, as in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sexual_dimorphism_in_non-human_primates#Pelage_color_and_markings" title="Sexual dimorphism in non-human primates" id="mwBKY">many primate species</a>.<sup about="#mwt816" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-114" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-114"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-114" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 114;" id="mwBKc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBKg">[114]</span></a></sup> Differences in female and male coat color may indicate nutrition and hormone levels, important in mate selection.<sup about="#mwt820" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-eva.mpg.de_115-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"eva.mpg.de"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-eva.mpg.de-115"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-eva.mpg.de-115" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 115;" id="mwBKk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBKo">[115]</span></a></sup> Coat color may influence the ability to retain heat, depending on how much light is reflected. Mammals with a darker colored coat can absorb more heat from solar radiation, and stay warmer, and some smaller mammals, such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vole" title="Vole" id="mwBKs">voles</a>, have darker fur in the winter. The white, pigmentless fur of arctic mammals, such as the polar bear, may reflect more solar radiation directly onto the skin.<sup about="#mwt821" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-6" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hair"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-hair-87" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwBKw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBK0">[87]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt808" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"166–167"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBK4"><span title="Page / location: 166–167"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>166–167<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup><sup about="#mwt822" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-dawson2014_106-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"dawson2014"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-dawson2014-106" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 106;" id="mwBK8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBLA">[106]</span></a></sup> The dazzling black-and-white striping of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Zebra" title="Zebra" id="mwBLE">zebras</a> appear to provide some protection from biting flies.<sup about="#mwt826" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Caro_116-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Caro"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Caro-116"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Caro-116" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 116;" id="mwBLI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBLM">[116]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="19" id="mwBLQ"><h3 id="Reproductive_system">Reproductive system</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt827" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Mammalian reproduction"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBLU"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt827" id="mwBLY">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammalian_reproduction" title="Mammalian reproduction">Mammalian reproduction</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBLc"><a href="./File:Goat_family.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBLg"><img resource="./File:Goat_family.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Goat_family.jpg/220px-Goat_family.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1067" data-file-type="bitmap" height="147" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Goat_family.jpg/330px-Goat_family.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Goat_family.jpg/440px-Goat_family.jpg 2x" id="mwBLk"/></a><figcaption id="mwBLo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Goat" title="Goat" id="mwBLs">Goat</a> kids stay with their mother until they are weaned.</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBLw">Mammals are solely <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gonochorism" title="Gonochorism" id="mwBL0">gonochoric</a> (an animal is born with either male or female genitalia, as opposed to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hermaphrodite" title="Hermaphrodite" id="mwBL4">hermaphrodites</a> where there is no such schism).<sup about="#mwt841" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-117" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-117"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-117" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 117;" id="mwBL8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBMA">[117]</span></a></sup> In male placentals, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Penis" title="Penis" id="mwBME">penis</a> is used both for urination and copulation. Depending on the species, an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Erection" title="Erection" id="mwBMI">erection</a> may be fueled by blood flow into vascular, spongy tissue or by muscular action. A penis may be contained in a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Penile_sheath" title="Penile sheath" id="mwBMM">prepuce</a> when not erect, and some placentals also have a penis bone (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Baculum" title="Baculum" id="mwBMQ">baculum</a>).<sup about="#mwt845" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Lombardi1998_118-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Lombardi1998"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Lombardi1998-118"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Lombardi1998-118" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 118;" id="mwBMU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBMY">[118]</span></a></sup> Marsupials typically have forked penises,<sup about="#mwt849" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Tyndale-BiscoeRenfree1987_119-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Tyndale-BiscoeRenfree1987"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Tyndale-BiscoeRenfree1987-119"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Tyndale-BiscoeRenfree1987-119" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 119;" id="mwBMc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBMg">[119]</span></a></sup> while the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Echidna" title="Echidna" id="mwBMk">echidna</a> penis generally has four heads with only two functioning.<sup about="#mwt853" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-120" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-120"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-120" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 120;" id="mwBMo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBMs">[120]</span></a></sup> The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Testes" title="Testes" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBMw">testes</a> of most mammals descend into the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scrotum" title="Scrotum" id="mwBM0">scrotum</a> which is typically posterior to the penis but is often anterior in marsupials. Female mammals generally have a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Clitoris" title="Clitoris" id="mwBM4">clitoris</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Labia_majora" title="Labia majora" id="mwBM8">labia majora</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Labia_minora" title="Labia minora" id="mwBNA">labia minora</a> on the outside, while the internal system contains paired <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oviduct" title="Oviduct" id="mwBNE">oviducts</a>, 1–2 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Uteri" title="Uteri" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBNI">uteri</a>, 1–2 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cervix" title="Cervix" id="mwBNM">cervices</a> and a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vagina" title="Vagina" id="mwBNQ">vagina</a>. Marsupials have two lateral vaginas and a medial vagina. The "vagina" of monotremes is better understood as a "urogenital sinus". The uterine systems of placental mammals can vary between a duplex, where there are two uteri and cervices which open into the vagina, a bipartite, where two <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Uterine_horn" title="Uterine horn" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBNU">uterine horns</a> have a single cervix that connects to the vagina, a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bicornuate" title="Bicornuate" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBNY">bicornuate</a>, which consists where two uterine horns that are connected distally but separate medially creating a Y-shape, and a simplex, which has a single uterus.<sup about="#mwt857" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-121" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-121"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-121" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 121;" id="mwBNc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBNg">[121]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt861" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-122" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-122"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-122" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 122;" id="mwBNk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBNo">[122]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt862" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-7" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hair"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-hair-87" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwBNs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBNw">[87]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt837" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"220–221, 247"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBN0"><span title="Page / location: 220–221, 247"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>220–221,<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>247<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup></p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBN4"><a href="./File:Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBN8"><img resource="./File:Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg/220px-Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="746" data-file-type="bitmap" height="205" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg/330px-Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg/440px-Dendrolagus_matschiei_1.jpg 2x" id="mwBOA"/></a><figcaption id="mwBOE"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Matschie's_tree-kangaroo" title="Matschie's tree-kangaroo" id="mwBOI">Matschie's tree-kangaroo</a> with young in pouch</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBOM">The ancestral condition for mammal reproduction is the birthing of relatively undeveloped, either through direct <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vivipary" title="Vivipary" id="mwBOQ">vivipary</a> or a short period as soft-shelled eggs. This is likely due to the fact that the torso could not expand due to the presence of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Epipubic_bones" title="Epipubic bones" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBOU">epipubic bones</a>. The oldest demonstration of this reproductive style is with <i id="mwBOY"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kayentatherium" title="Kayentatherium" id="mwBOc">Kayentatherium</a></i>, which produced undeveloped <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Perinate" title="Perinate" id="mwBOg">perinates</a>, but at much higher litter sizes than any modern mammal, 38 specimens.<sup about="#mwt869" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Hoffman&amp;Rowe_123-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Hoffman&amp;Rowe"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Hoffman&amp;Rowe-123"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Hoffman&amp;Rowe-123" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 123;" id="mwBOk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBOo">[123]</span></a></sup> Most modern mammals are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Viviparity" title="Viviparity" id="mwBOs">viviparous</a>, giving birth to live young. However, the five species of monotreme, the platypus and the four species of echidna, lay eggs. The monotremes have a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sex_determination_system" title="Sex determination system" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBOw">sex determination system</a> different from that of most other mammals.<sup about="#mwt873" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-124" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-124"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-124" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 124;" id="mwBO0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBO4">[124]</span></a></sup> In particular, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sex_chromosome" title="Sex chromosome" id="mwBO8">sex chromosomes</a> of a platypus are more like those of a chicken than those of a therian mammal.<sup about="#mwt877" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-125" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-125"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-125" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 125;" id="mwBPA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBPE">[125]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBPI">Viviparous mammals are in the subclass Theria; those living today are in the marsupial and placental infraclasses. Marsupials have a short <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gestation" title="Gestation" id="mwBPM">gestation</a> period, typically shorter than its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Estrous_cycle" title="Estrous cycle" id="mwBPQ">estrous cycle</a> and generally giving birth to a number of undeveloped newborns that then undergo further development; in many species, this takes place within a pouch-like sac, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pouch_(marsupial)" title="Pouch (marsupial)" id="mwBPU">marsupium</a>, located in the front of the mother's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abdomen" title="Abdomen" id="mwBPY">abdomen</a>. This is the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Symplesiomorphy" title="Symplesiomorphy" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBPc">plesiomorphic</a> condition among viviparous mammals; the presence of epipubic bones in all non-placental mammals prevents the expansion of the torso needed for full pregnancy.<sup about="#mwt886" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-schulkin_78-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"schulkin"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-schulkin-78"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-schulkin-78" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 78;" id="mwBPg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBPk">[78]</span></a></sup> Even non-placental eutherians probably reproduced this way.<sup about="#mwt887" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Epipubic_bones_in_eutherian_mammals_41-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Epipubic bones in eutherian mammals"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Epipubic_bones_in_eutherian_mammals-41" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 41;" id="mwBPo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBPs">[41]</span></a></sup> The placentals give birth to relatively complete and developed young, usually after long gestation periods.<sup about="#mwt891" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-126" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-126"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-126" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 126;" id="mwBPw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBP0">[126]</span></a></sup> They get their name from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Placenta" title="Placenta" id="mwBP4">placenta</a>, which connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall to allow nutrient uptake.<sup about="#mwt895" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-127" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-127"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-127" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 127;" id="mwBP8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBQA">[127]</span></a></sup> In placental mammals, the epipubic is either completely lost or converted into the baculum; allowing the torso to be able to expand and thus birth developed offspring.<sup about="#mwt896" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Hoffman&amp;Rowe_123-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Hoffman&amp;Rowe"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Hoffman&amp;Rowe-123" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 123;" id="mwBQE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBQI">[123]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBQM">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammary_gland" title="Mammary gland" id="mwBQQ">mammary glands</a> of mammals are specialized to produce milk, the primary source of nutrition for newborns. The monotremes branched early from other mammals and do not have the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nipple" title="Nipple" id="mwBQU">nipples</a> seen in most mammals, but they do have mammary glands. The young lick the milk from a mammary patch on the mother's belly.<sup about="#mwt904" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-128" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-128"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-128" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 128;" id="mwBQY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBQc">[128]</span></a></sup> Compared to placental mammals, the milk of marsupials changes greatly in both production rate and in nutrient composition, due to the underdeveloped young. In addition, the mammary glands have more autonomy allowing them to supply separate milks to young at different development stages.<sup about="#mwt908" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-129" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-129"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-129" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 129;" id="mwBQg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBQk">[129]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lactose" title="Lactose" id="mwBQo">Lactose</a> is the main sugar in placental mammal milk while monotreme and marsupial milk is dominated by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oligosaccharide" title="Oligosaccharide" id="mwBQs">oligosaccharides</a>.<sup about="#mwt912" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-130" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-130"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-130" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 130;" id="mwBQw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBQ0">[130]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Weaning" title="Weaning" id="mwBQ4">Weaning</a> is the process in which a mammal becomes less dependent on their mother's milk and more on solid food.<sup about="#mwt916" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-131" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-131"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-131" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 131;" id="mwBQ8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBRA">[131]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="20" id="mwBRE"><h3 id="Endothermy">Endothermy</h3>
<p id="mwBRI">Nearly all mammals are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Endothermy" title="Endothermy" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBRM">endothermic</a> ("warm-blooded"). Most mammals also have hair to help keep them warm. Like birds, mammals can forage or hunt in weather and climates too cold for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ectotherm" title="Ectotherm" id="mwBRQ">ectothermic</a> ("cold-blooded") reptiles and insects. Endothermy requires plenty of food energy, so mammals eat more food per unit of body weight than most reptiles.<sup about="#mwt923" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-132" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-132"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-132" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 132;" id="mwBRU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBRY">[132]</span></a></sup> Small insectivorous mammals eat prodigious amounts for their size. A rare exception, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Naked_mole-rat" title="Naked mole-rat" id="mwBRc">naked mole-rat</a> produces little metabolic heat, so it is considered an operational <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Poikilotherm" title="Poikilotherm" id="mwBRg">poikilotherm</a>.<sup about="#mwt927" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-133" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-133"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-133" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 133;" id="mwBRk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBRo">[133]</span></a></sup> Birds are also endothermic, so endothermy is not unique to mammals.<sup about="#mwt931" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-134" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-134"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-134" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 134;" id="mwBRs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBRw">[134]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="21" id="mwBR0"><h3 id="Species_lifespan">Species lifespan</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt932" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Life expectancy"},"2":{"wt":"Maximum life span"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBR4"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt932" id="mwBR8">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">Life expectancy</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maximum_life_span" title="Maximum life span">Maximum life span</a></div>
<p id="mwBSA">Among mammals, species maximum lifespan varies significantly (for example the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shrew" title="Shrew" id="mwBSE">shrew</a> has a lifespan of two years, whereas the oldest <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bowhead_whale" title="Bowhead whale" id="mwBSI">bowhead whale</a> is recorded to be 211 years).<sup about="#mwt946" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pmid19896964_135-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pmid19896964"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pmid19896964-135"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-pmid19896964-135" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 135;" id="mwBSM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBSQ">[135]</span></a></sup> Although the underlying basis for these lifespan differences is still uncertain, numerous studies indicate that the ability to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./DNA_repair" title="DNA repair" id="mwBSU">repair DNA damage</a> is an important determinant of mammalian lifespan. In a 1974 study by Hart and Setlow,<sup about="#mwt950" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pmid4526202_136-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pmid4526202"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pmid4526202-136"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-pmid4526202-136" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 136;" id="mwBSY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBSc">[136]</span></a></sup> it was found that DNA excision repair capability increased systematically with species lifespan among seven mammalian species. Species lifespan was observed to be robustly correlated with the capacity to recognize DNA double-strand breaks as well as the level of the DNA repair protein <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ku80" title="Ku80" id="mwBSg">Ku80</a>.<sup about="#mwt951" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pmid19896964_135-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pmid19896964"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-pmid19896964-135" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 135;" id="mwBSk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBSo">[135]</span></a></sup> In a study of the cells from sixteen mammalian species, genes employed in DNA repair were found to be <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Downregulation_and_upregulation" title="Downregulation and upregulation" id="mwBSs">up-regulated</a> in the longer-lived species.<sup about="#mwt955" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pmid27874830_137-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pmid27874830"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pmid27874830-137"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-pmid27874830-137" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 137;" id="mwBSw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBS0">[137]</span></a></sup> The cellular level of the DNA repair enzyme <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Poly_ADP_ribose_polymerase" title="Poly ADP ribose polymerase" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBS4">poly ADP ribose polymerase</a> was found to correlate with species lifespan in a study of 13 mammalian species.<sup about="#mwt959" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pmid1465394_138-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pmid1465394"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pmid1465394-138"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-pmid1465394-138" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 138;" id="mwBS8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBTA">[138]</span></a></sup> Three additional studies of a variety of mammalian species also reported a correlation between species lifespan and DNA repair capability.<sup about="#mwt963" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pmid7266079_139-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pmid7266079"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pmid7266079-139"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-pmid7266079-139" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 139;" id="mwBTE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBTI">[139]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt967" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pmid7060140_140-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pmid7060140"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pmid7060140-140"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-pmid7060140-140" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 140;" id="mwBTM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBTQ">[140]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt971" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pmid3974310_141-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pmid3974310"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pmid3974310-141"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-pmid3974310-141" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 141;" id="mwBTU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBTY">[141]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="22" id="mwBTc"><h3 id="Locomotion">Locomotion</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt972" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Animal locomotion"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBTg"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt972" id="mwBTk">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_locomotion" title="Animal locomotion">Animal locomotion</a></div>

<section data-mw-section-id="23" id="mwBTo"><h4 id="Terrestrial">Terrestrial</h4>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt975" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Terrestrial locomotion"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBTs"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt975" id="mwBTw">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Terrestrial_locomotion" title="Terrestrial locomotion">Terrestrial locomotion</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBT0"><a href="./File:Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBT4"><img resource="./File:Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif/220px-Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif" decoding="async" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="200" data-file-type="bitmap" height="147" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dd/Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dd/Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif 2x" id="mwBT8"/></a><figcaption id="mwBUA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Running" title="Running" id="mwBUE">Running gait</a>. Photographs by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eadweard_Muybridge" title="Eadweard Muybridge" id="mwBUI">Eadweard Muybridge</a>, 1887</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBUM">Most vertebrates—the amphibians, the reptiles and some mammals such as humans and bears—are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Plantigrade" title="Plantigrade" id="mwBUQ">plantigrade</a>, walking on the whole of the underside of the foot. Many mammals, such as cats and dogs, are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Digitigrade" title="Digitigrade" id="mwBUU">digitigrade</a>, walking on their toes, the greater stride length allowing more speed. Digitigrade mammals are also often adept at quiet movement.<link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:All_articles_with_unsourced_statements" about="#mwt983" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"cn","href":"./Template:Cn"},"params":{"date":{"wt":"January 2023"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBUY"/><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_with_unsourced_statements_from_January_2023" about="#mwt983"/><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;" about="#mwt983" id="mwBUc"><span typeof="mw:Entity">[</span><i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2023)">citation needed</span></a></i><span typeof="mw:Entity">]</span></sup> Some animals such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Horse" title="Horse" id="mwBUg">horses</a> are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Unguligrade" title="Unguligrade" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBUk">unguligrade</a>, walking on the tips of their toes. This even further increases their stride length and thus their speed.<sup about="#mwt987" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-142" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-142"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-142" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 142;" id="mwBUo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBUs">[142]</span></a></sup> A few mammals, namely the great apes, are also known to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Knuckle-walking" title="Knuckle-walking" id="mwBUw">walk on their knuckles</a>, at least for their front legs. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Giant_anteater" title="Giant anteater" id="mwBU0">Giant anteaters</a><sup about="#mwt991" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-143" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-143"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-143" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 143;" id="mwBU4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBU8">[143]</span></a></sup> and platypuses<sup about="#mwt995" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-144" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-144"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-144" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 144;" id="mwBVA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBVE">[144]</span></a></sup> are also knuckle-walkers. Some mammals are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bipedalism" title="Bipedalism" id="mwBVI">bipeds</a>, using only two limbs for locomotion, which can be seen in, for example, humans and the great apes. Bipedal species have a larger field of vision than quadrupeds, conserve more energy and have the ability to manipulate objects with their hands, which aids in foraging. Instead of walking, some bipeds hop, such as kangaroos and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kangaroo_rat" title="Kangaroo rat" id="mwBVM">kangaroo rats</a>.<sup about="#mwt999" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-145" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-145"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-145" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 145;" id="mwBVQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBVU">[145]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1003" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-146" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-146"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-146" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 146;" id="mwBVY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBVc">[146]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBVg">Animals will use different gaits for different speeds, terrain and situations. For example, horses show four natural gaits, the slowest <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Horse_gait" title="Horse gait" id="mwBVk">horse gait</a> is the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Horse_gait#Walk" title="Horse gait" id="mwBVo">walk</a>, then there are three faster gaits which, from slowest to fastest, are the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Trot_(horse_gait)" title="Trot (horse gait)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBVs">trot</a>, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Canter" title="Canter" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBVw">canter</a> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Horse_gait#Gallop" title="Horse gait" id="mwBV0">gallop</a>. Animals may also have unusual gaits that are used occasionally, such as for moving sideways or backwards. For example, the main <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gait_(human)" title="Gait (human)" id="mwBV4">human gaits</a> are bipedal <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Walking" title="Walking" id="mwBV8">walking</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Running" title="Running" id="mwBWA">running</a>, but they employ many other gaits occasionally, including a four-legged <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crawling_(human)" title="Crawling (human)" id="mwBWE">crawl</a> in tight spaces.<sup about="#mwt1010" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-dagg_147-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"dagg"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-dagg-147"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-dagg-147" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 147;" id="mwBWI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBWM">[147]</span></a></sup> Mammals show a vast range of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gait" title="Gait" id="mwBWQ">gaits</a>, the order that they place and lift their appendages in locomotion. Gaits can be grouped into categories according to their patterns of support sequence. For quadrupeds, there are three main categories: walking gaits, running gaits and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Leaping_gaits" title="Leaping gaits" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBWU">leaping gaits</a>.<sup about="#mwt1014" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-148" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-148"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-148" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 148;" id="mwBWY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBWc">[148]</span></a></sup> Walking is the most common gait, where some feet are on the ground at any given time, and found in almost all legged animals. Running is considered to occur when at some points in the stride all feet are off the ground in a moment of suspension.<sup about="#mwt1015" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-dagg_147-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"dagg"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-dagg-147" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 147;" id="mwBWg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBWk">[147]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="24" id="mwBWo"><h4 id="Arboreal">Arboreal</h4>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1016" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Arboreal locomotion"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBWs"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1016" id="mwBWw">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arboreal_locomotion" title="Arboreal locomotion">Arboreal locomotion</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBW0"><a href="./File:Brachiating_Gibbon_(Some_rights_reserved).jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBW4"><img resource="./File:Brachiating_Gibbon_(Some_rights_reserved).jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Brachiating_Gibbon_%28Some_rights_reserved%29.jpg/170px-Brachiating_Gibbon_%28Some_rights_reserved%29.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="333" data-file-height="500" data-file-type="bitmap" height="255" width="170" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Brachiating_Gibbon_%28Some_rights_reserved%29.jpg/255px-Brachiating_Gibbon_%28Some_rights_reserved%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d2/Brachiating_Gibbon_%28Some_rights_reserved%29.jpg 2x" id="mwBW8"/></a><figcaption id="mwBXA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gibbon" title="Gibbon" id="mwBXE">Gibbons</a> are very good <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Brachiation" title="Brachiation" id="mwBXI">brachiators</a> because their elongated limbs enable them to easily swing and grasp on to branches.</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBXM">Arboreal animals frequently have elongated limbs that help them cross gaps, reach fruit or other resources, test the firmness of support ahead and, in some cases, to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Brachiation" title="Brachiation" id="mwBXQ">brachiate</a> (swing between trees).<sup about="#mwt1026" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Cartmill_149-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Cartmill"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Cartmill-149"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Cartmill-149" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 149;" id="mwBXU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBXY">[149]</span></a></sup> Many arboreal species, such as tree porcupines, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Silky_anteater" title="Silky anteater" id="mwBXc">silky anteaters</a>, spider monkeys, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phalangeriformes" title="Phalangeriformes" id="mwBXg">possums</a>, use <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Prehensile_tail" title="Prehensile tail" id="mwBXk">prehensile tails</a> to grasp branches. In the spider monkey, the tip of the tail has either a bare patch or adhesive pad, which provides increased friction. Claws can be used to interact with rough substrates and reorient the direction of forces the animal applies. This is what allows <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Squirrel" title="Squirrel" id="mwBXo">squirrels</a> to climb tree trunks that are so large to be essentially flat from the perspective of such a small animal. However, claws can interfere with an animal's ability to grasp very small branches, as they may wrap too far around and prick the animal's own paw. Frictional gripping is used by primates, relying upon hairless fingertips. Squeezing the branch between the fingertips generates frictional force that holds the animal's hand to the branch. However, this type of grip depends upon the angle of the frictional force, thus upon the diameter of the branch, with larger branches resulting in reduced gripping ability. To control descent, especially down large diameter branches, some arboreal animals such as squirrels have evolved highly mobile ankle joints that permit rotating the foot into a 'reversed' posture. This allows the claws to hook into the rough surface of the bark, opposing the force of gravity. Small size provides many advantages to arboreal species: such as increasing the relative size of branches to the animal, lower center of mass, increased stability, lower mass (allowing movement on smaller branches) and the ability to move through more cluttered habitat.<sup about="#mwt1027" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Cartmill_149-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Cartmill"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Cartmill-149" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 149;" id="mwBXs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBXw">[149]</span></a></sup> Size relating to weight affects gliding animals such as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sugar_glider" title="Sugar glider" id="mwBX0">sugar glider</a>.<sup about="#mwt1031" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-150" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-150"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-150" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 150;" id="mwBX4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBX8">[150]</span></a></sup> Some species of primate, bat and all species of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sloth" title="Sloth" id="mwBYA">sloth</a> achieve passive stability by hanging beneath the branch. Both pitching and tipping become irrelevant, as the only method of failure would be losing their grip.<sup about="#mwt1032" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Cartmill_149-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Cartmill"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Cartmill-149" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 149;" id="mwBYE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBYI">[149]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="25" id="mwBYM"><h4 id="Aerial">Aerial</h4>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1033" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Aerial locomotion"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBYQ"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1033" id="mwBYU">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aerial_locomotion" title="Aerial locomotion" class="mw-redirect">Aerial locomotion</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBYY"><span id="mwBYc"><video poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/300px--Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.jpg" controls="" preload="none" height="169" width="300" resource="./File:Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm" id="mwBYg"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8"' data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="1080" data-title="Original WebM file, 1,920 × 1,080 (4.85 Mbps)" data-shorttitle="WebM source" id="mwBYk"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.120p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="214" data-height="120" data-title="Lowest bandwidth VP9 (120P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 120P" id="mwBYo"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.160p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="284" data-height="160" data-title="Low bandwidth WebM (160P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 160P" id="mwBYs"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.180p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="320" data-height="180" data-title="Low bandwidth VP9 (180P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 180P" id="mwBYw"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.240p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="426" data-height="240" data-title="Small VP9 (240P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 240P" id="mwBY0"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.240p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="426" data-height="240" data-title="Small WebM (240P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 240P" id="mwBY4"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.360p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="640" data-height="360" data-title="VP9 (360P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 360P" id="mwBY8"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.360p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="640" data-height="360" data-title="WebM (360P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 360P" id="mwBZA"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.480p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="854" data-height="480" data-title="SD VP9 (480P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 480P" id="mwBZE"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.480p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="854" data-height="480" data-title="SD WebM (480P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 480P" id="mwBZI"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.720p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="1280" data-height="720" data-title="HD VP9 (720P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 720P" id="mwBZM"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.720p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="1280" data-height="720" data-title="HD WebM (720P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 720P" id="mwBZQ"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.1080p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="1920" data-height="1080" data-title="Full HD VP9 (1080P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 1080P" id="mwBZU"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/52/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm/Israeli_Bats_-_26_September_2015.webm.1080p.webm" type='video/webm;
