codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="1920" data-height="1080" data-title="Full HD WebM (1080P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 1080P" id="mwBZY"/></video></span><figcaption id="mwBZc">Slow-motion and normal speed of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Egyptian_fruit_bat" title="Egyptian fruit bat" id="mwBZg">Egyptian fruit bats</a> flying</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBZk">Bats are the only mammals that can truly fly. They fly through the air at a constant speed by moving their wings up and down (usually with some fore-aft movement as well). Because the animal is in motion, there is some airflow relative to its body which, combined with the velocity of the wings, generates a faster airflow moving over the wing. This generates a lift force vector pointing forwards and upwards, and a drag force vector pointing rearwards and upwards. The upwards components of these counteract gravity, keeping the body in the air, while the forward component provides thrust to counteract both the drag from the wing and from the body as a whole.<sup about="#mwt1040" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-151" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-151"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-151" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 151;" id="mwBZo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBZs">[151]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBZw">The wings of bats are much thinner and consist of more bones than those of birds, allowing bats to maneuver more accurately and fly with more lift and less drag.<sup about="#mwt1049" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-152" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-152"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-152" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 152;" id="mwBZ0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBZ4">[152]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1053" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-anders_153-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"anders"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-anders-153"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-anders-153" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 153;" id="mwBZ8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBaA">[153]</span></a></sup> By folding the wings inwards towards their body on the upstroke, they use 35% less energy during flight than birds.<sup about="#mwt1057" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-154" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-154"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-154" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 154;" id="mwBaE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBaI">[154]</span></a></sup> The membranes are delicate, ripping easily; however, the tissue of the bat's membrane is able to regrow, such that small tears can heal quickly.<sup about="#mwt1061" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-155" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-155"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-155" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 155;" id="mwBaM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBaQ">[155]</span></a></sup> The surface of their wings is equipped with touch-sensitive receptors on small bumps called <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Merkel_cell" title="Merkel cell" id="mwBaU">Merkel cells</a>, also found on human fingertips. These sensitive areas are different in bats, as each bump has a tiny hair in the center, making it even more sensitive and allowing the bat to detect and collect information about the air flowing over its wings, and to fly more efficiently by changing the shape of its wings in response.<sup about="#mwt1065" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-156" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-156"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-156" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 156;" id="mwBaY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBac">[156]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="26" id="mwBag"><h4 id="Fossorial_and_subterranean">Fossorial and subterranean</h4>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" about="#mwt1066" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Multiple image","href":"./Template:Multiple_image"},"params":{"align":{"wt":"right"},"image1":{"wt":"Wombat3.jpg"},"image2":{"wt":"ScalopusAquaticus.jpg"},"total_width":{"wt":"400"},"footer":{"wt":"Semi-fossorial [[Southern hairy-nosed wombat|wombat]] (left) vs. fully fossorial [[eastern mole]] (right)"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBak"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright" about="#mwt1066"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:187px;max-width:187px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:138px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:Wombat3.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:Wombat3.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Wombat3.jpg/185px-Wombat3.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200" data-file-type="bitmap" height="139" width="185" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Wombat3.jpg/278px-Wombat3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Wombat3.jpg/370px-Wombat3.jpg 2x"/></a></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:201px;max-width:201px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:138px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:ScalopusAquaticus.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:ScalopusAquaticus.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/ScalopusAquaticus.jpg/199px-ScalopusAquaticus.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1042" data-file-type="bitmap" height="138" width="199" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/ScalopusAquaticus.jpg/299px-ScalopusAquaticus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/ScalopusAquaticus.jpg/398px-ScalopusAquaticus.jpg 2x"/></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Semi-fossorial <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Southern_hairy-nosed_wombat" title="Southern hairy-nosed wombat">wombat</a> (left) vs. fully fossorial <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eastern_mole" title="Eastern mole">eastern mole</a> (right)</div></div></div></div><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Pages_using_multiple_image_with_auto_scaled_images" about="#mwt1066" id="mwBao"/>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1069" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Fossorial"},"2":{"wt":"Burrow"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBas"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1069" id="mwBaw">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fossorial" title="Fossorial">Fossorial</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Burrow" title="Burrow">Burrow</a></div>
<p id="mwBa0">A fossorial (from Latin <i id="mwBa4">fossor</i>, meaning "digger") is an animal adapted to digging which lives primarily, but not solely, underground. Some examples are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Badger" title="Badger" id="mwBa8">badgers</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Naked_mole-rat" title="Naked mole-rat" id="mwBbA">naked mole-rats</a>. Many <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rodent" title="Rodent" id="mwBbE">rodent</a> species are also considered fossorial because they live in burrows for most but not all of the day. Species that live exclusively underground are subterranean, and those with limited adaptations to a fossorial lifestyle sub-fossorial. Some organisms are fossorial to aid in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Temperature_regulation" title="Temperature regulation" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBbI">temperature regulation</a> while others use the underground habitat for protection from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Predator" title="Predator" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBbM">predators</a> or for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Food_storage" title="Food storage" id="mwBbQ">food storage</a>.<sup about="#mwt1073" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-:2_157-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":":2"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-:2-157"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-:2-157" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 157;" id="mwBbU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBbY">[157]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBbc">Fossorial mammals have a fusiform body, thickest at the shoulders and tapering off at the tail and nose. Unable to see in the dark burrows, most have degenerated eyes, but degeneration varies between species; <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pocket_gopher" title="Pocket gopher" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBbg">pocket gophers</a>, for example, are only semi-fossorial and have very small yet functional eyes, in the fully fossorial <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Marsupial_mole" title="Marsupial mole" id="mwBbk">marsupial mole</a> the eyes are degenerated and useless, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Talpa_(genus)" title="Talpa (genus)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBbo">talpa moles</a> have <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vestigial" title="Vestigial" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBbs">vestigial</a> eyes and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cape_golden_mole" title="Cape golden mole" id="mwBbw">cape golden mole</a> has a layer of skin covering the eyes. External ears flaps are also very small or absent. Truly fossorial mammals have short, stout legs as strength is more important than speed to a burrowing mammal, but semi-fossorial mammals have <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cursorial" title="Cursorial" id="mwBb0">cursorial</a> legs. The front paws are broad and have strong claws to help in loosening dirt while excavating burrows, and the back paws have webbing, as well as claws, which aids in throwing loosened dirt backwards. Most have large incisors to prevent dirt from flying into their mouth.<sup about="#mwt1078" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-158" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-158"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-158" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 158;" id="mwBb4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBb8">[158]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBcA">Many fossorial mammals such as shrews, hedgehogs, and moles were classified under the now obsolete order <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Insectivora" title="Insectivora" id="mwBcE">Insectivora</a>.<sup about="#mwt1083" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-159" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-159"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-159" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 159;" id="mwBcI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBcM">[159]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="27" id="mwBcQ"><h4 id="Aquatic">Aquatic</h4>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1084" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Aquatic locomotion"},"2":{"wt":"Marine mammal"},"3":{"wt":"Aquatic mammal"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBcU"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1084" id="mwBcY">Main articles: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aquatic_locomotion" title="Aquatic locomotion">Aquatic locomotion</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Marine_mammal" title="Marine mammal">Marine mammal</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aquatic_mammal" title="Aquatic mammal">Aquatic mammal</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBcc"><span id="mwBcg"><video poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv/220px--Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv.jpg" controls="" preload="none" height="147" width="220" resource="./File:Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv" id="mwBck"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv" type='video/ogg; codecs="theora, vorbis"' data-file-width="720" data-file-height="480" data-title="Original Ogg file, 720 × 480 (1.69 Mbps)" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" id="mwBco"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv.120p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="180" data-height="120" data-title="Lowest bandwidth VP9 (120P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 120P" id="mwBcs"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv.160p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="240" data-height="160" data-title="Low bandwidth WebM (160P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 160P" id="mwBcw"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv.180p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="270" data-height="180" data-title="Low bandwidth VP9 (180P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 180P" id="mwBc0"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv.240p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="360" data-height="240" data-title="Small VP9 (240P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 240P" id="mwBc4"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv.240p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="360" data-height="240" data-title="Small WebM (240P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 240P" id="mwBc8"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv.360p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="540" data-height="360" data-title="VP9 (360P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 360P" id="mwBdA"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv.360p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="540" data-height="360" data-title="WebM (360P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 360P" id="mwBdE"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv.480p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="720" data-height="480" data-title="SD VP9 (480P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 480P" id="mwBdI"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a0/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv/Living-on-the-Edge-Settlement-Patterns-by-the-Symbiotic-Barnacle-Xenobalanus-globicipitis-on-Small-pone.0127367.s001.ogv.480p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="720" data-height="480" data-title="SD WebM (480P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 480P" id="mwBdM"/></video></span><figcaption id="mwBdQ">A pod of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Short-beaked_common_dolphin" title="Short-beaked common dolphin" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBdU">short-beaked common dolphins</a> swimming</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBdY">Fully aquatic mammals, the cetaceans and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sirenia" title="Sirenia" id="mwBdc">sirenians</a>, have lost their legs and have a tail fin to propel themselves through the water. Flipper movement is continuous. Whales swim by moving their tail fin and lower body up and down, propelling themselves through vertical movement, while their flippers are mainly used for steering. Their skeletal anatomy allows them to be fast swimmers. Most species have a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dorsal_fin" title="Dorsal fin" id="mwBdg">dorsal fin</a> to prevent themselves from turning upside-down in the water.<sup about="#mwt1093" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-160" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-160"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-160" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 160;" id="mwBdk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBdo">[160]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1097" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-161" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-161"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-161" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 161;" id="mwBds"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBdw">[161]</span></a></sup> The flukes of sirenians are raised up and down in long strokes to move the animal forward, and can be twisted to turn. The forelimbs are paddle-like flippers which aid in turning and slowing.<sup about="#mwt1102" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-162" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-162"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-162" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 162;" id="mwBd0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBd4">[162]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBd8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Semi-aquatic" title="Semi-aquatic" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBeA">Semi-aquatic</a> mammals, like pinnipeds, have two pairs of flippers on the front and back, the fore-flippers and hind-flippers. The elbows and ankles are enclosed within the body.<sup about="#mwt1116" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Berta63_163-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Berta63"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Berta63-163"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Berta63-163" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 163;" id="mwBeE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBeI">[163]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1120" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Fish_2003_164-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Fish 2003"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Fish_2003-164"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Fish_2003-164" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 164;" id="mwBeM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBeQ">[164]</span></a></sup> Pinnipeds have several adaptions for reducing <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Drag_(physics)" title="Drag (physics)" id="mwBeU">drag</a>. In addition to their streamlined bodies, they have smooth networks of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Muscle_fascicle" title="Muscle fascicle" id="mwBeY">muscle bundles</a> in their skin that may increase <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Laminar_flow" title="Laminar flow" id="mwBec">laminar flow</a> and make it easier for them to slip through water. They also lack <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arrector_pili_muscle" title="Arrector pili muscle" id="mwBeg">arrector pili</a>, so their fur can be streamlined as they swim.<sup about="#mwt1121" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Riedman3_165-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Riedman3"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Riedman3-165" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 165;" id="mwBek"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBeo">[165]</span></a></sup> They rely on their fore-flippers for locomotion in a wing-like manner similar to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Penguin" title="Penguin" id="mwBes">penguins</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sea_turtles" title="Sea turtles" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBew">sea turtles</a>.<sup about="#mwt1125" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Fish1996_166-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Fish1996"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Fish1996-166"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Fish1996-166" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 166;" id="mwBe0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBe4">[166]</span></a></sup> Fore-flipper movement is not continuous, and the animal glides between each stroke.<sup about="#mwt1126" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Fish_2003_164-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Fish 2003"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Fish_2003-164" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 164;" id="mwBe8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBfA">[164]</span></a></sup> Compared to terrestrial carnivorans, the fore-limbs are reduced in length, which gives the locomotor muscles at the shoulder and elbow joints greater mechanical advantage;<sup about="#mwt1127" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Berta63_163-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Berta63"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Berta63-163" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 163;" id="mwBfE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBfI">[163]</span></a></sup> the hind-flippers serve as stabilizers.<sup about="#mwt1131" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Riedman3_165-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Riedman3"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Riedman3-165"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Riedman3-165" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 165;" id="mwBfM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBfQ">[165]</span></a></sup> Other semi-aquatic mammals include beavers, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hippopotamus" title="Hippopotamus" id="mwBfU">hippopotamuses</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Otter" title="Otter" id="mwBfY">otters</a> and platypuses.<sup about="#mwt1135" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-167" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-167"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-167" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 167;" id="mwBfc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBfg">[167]</span></a></sup> Hippos are very large semi-aquatic mammals, and their barrel-shaped bodies have <a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/graviportal" title="wikt:graviportal" class="extiw" id="mwBfk">graviportal</a> skeletal structures,<sup about="#mwt1139" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-168" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-168"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-168" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 168;" id="mwBfo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBfs">[168]</span></a></sup> adapted to carrying their enormous weight, and their <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Specific_gravity" title="Specific gravity" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBfw">specific gravity</a> allows them to sink and move along the bottom of a river.<sup about="#mwt1143" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-169" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-169"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-169" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 169;" id="mwBf0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBf4">[169]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section></section><section data-mw-section-id="28" id="mwBf8"><h2 id="Behavior">Behavior</h2>

<section data-mw-section-id="29" id="mwBgA"><h3 id="Communication_and_vocalization">Communication and vocalization</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1144" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Further","href":"./Template:Further"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Animal communication"},"2":{"wt":"Animal echolocation"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBgE"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1144" id="mwBgI">Further information: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_communication" title="Animal communication">Animal communication</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_echolocation" title="Animal echolocation">Animal echolocation</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBgM"><a href="./File:Monkey_&amp;_Baby.JPG" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBgQ"><img resource="./File:Monkey_&amp;_Baby.JPG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG/170px-Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG" decoding="async" data-file-width="2348" data-file-height="2448" data-file-type="bitmap" height="177" width="170" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG/255px-Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG/340px-Monkey_%26_Baby.JPG 2x" id="mwBgU"/></a><figcaption id="mwBgY"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vervet_monkey" title="Vervet monkey" id="mwBgc">Vervet monkeys</a> use at least four distinct <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Alarm_signal" title="Alarm signal" id="mwBgg">alarm calls</a> for different <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Predator" title="Predator" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBgk">predators</a>.<sup about="#mwt1148" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Seyfarth_170-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Seyfarth"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Seyfarth-170" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 170;" id="mwBgo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBgs">[170]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBgw">Many mammals communicate by vocalizing. Vocal communication serves many purposes, including in mating rituals, as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Alarm_signal" title="Alarm signal" id="mwBg0">warning calls</a>,<sup about="#mwt1161" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-171" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-171"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-171" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 171;" id="mwBg4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBg8">[171]</span></a></sup> to indicate food sources, and for social purposes. Males often call during mating rituals to ward off other males and to attract females, as in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Roar_(vocalization)" title="Roar (vocalization)" id="mwBhA">roaring</a> of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lion" title="Lion" id="mwBhE">lions</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Red_deer" title="Red deer" id="mwBhI">red deer</a>.<sup about="#mwt1165" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-172" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-172"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-172" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 172;" id="mwBhM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBhQ">[172]</span></a></sup> The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Whale_song" title="Whale song" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBhU">songs</a> of the humpback whale may be signals to females;<sup about="#mwt1169" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-173" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-173"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-173" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 173;" id="mwBhY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBhc">[173]</span></a></sup> they have different dialects in different regions of the ocean.<sup about="#mwt1173" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-174" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-174"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-174" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 174;" id="mwBhg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBhk">[174]</span></a></sup> Social vocalizations include the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Territory_(animal)" title="Territory (animal)" id="mwBho">territorial</a> calls of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gibbon" title="Gibbon" id="mwBhs">gibbons</a>, and the use of frequency in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Greater_spear-nosed_bat" title="Greater spear-nosed bat" id="mwBhw">greater spear-nosed bats</a> to distinguish between groups.<sup about="#mwt1177" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-175" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-175"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-175" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 175;" id="mwBh0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBh4">[175]</span></a></sup> The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vervet_monkey" title="Vervet monkey" id="mwBh8">vervet monkey</a> gives a distinct alarm call for each of at least four different predators, and the reactions of other monkeys vary according to the call. For example, if an alarm call signals a python, the monkeys climb into the trees, whereas the eagle alarm causes monkeys to seek a hiding place on the ground.<sup about="#mwt1181" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Seyfarth_170-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Seyfarth"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Seyfarth-170"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Seyfarth-170" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 170;" id="mwBiA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBiE">[170]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Prairie_dogs" title="Prairie dogs" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBiI">Prairie dogs</a> similarly have complex calls that signal the type, size, and speed of an approaching predator.<sup about="#mwt1185" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-176" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-176"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-176" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 176;" id="mwBiM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBiQ">[176]</span></a></sup> Elephants communicate socially with a variety of sounds including snorting, screaming, trumpeting, roaring and rumbling. Some of the rumbling calls are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Infrasound" title="Infrasound" id="mwBiU">infrasonic</a>, below the hearing range of humans, and can be heard by other elephants up to <span about="#mwt1157" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"6"},"2":{"wt":"mi"},"3":{"wt":"km"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBiY">6 miles (9.7</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1157"> </span><span about="#mwt1157">km)</span> away at still times near sunrise and sunset.<sup about="#mwt1189" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-177" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-177"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-177" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 177;" id="mwBic"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBig">[177]</span></a></sup></p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left mw-default-audio-height" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBik"><span id="mwBio"><audio controls="" preload="none" height="32" width="220" resource="./File:Killer_whale.ogg" id="mwBis"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/79/Killer_whale.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"' data-title="Original Ogg file (74 kbps)" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" id="mwBiw"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/79/Killer_whale.ogg/Killer_whale.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg" data-title="MP3" data-shorttitle="MP3" id="mwBi0"/></audio></span><figcaption id="mwBi4">Orca calling including occasional echolocation clicks</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBi8">Mammals signal by a variety of means. Many give visual <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Anti-predator_adaptation" title="Anti-predator adaptation" id="mwBjA">anti-predator signals</a>, as when deer and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gazelle" title="Gazelle" id="mwBjE">gazelle</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stotting" title="Stotting" id="mwBjI">stot</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Honest_signal" title="Honest signal" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBjM">honestly indicating</a> their fit condition and their ability to escape,<sup about="#mwt1202" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-178" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-178"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-178" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 178;" id="mwBjQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBjU">[178]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1206" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-179" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-179"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-179" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 179;" id="mwBjY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBjc">[179]</span></a></sup> or when <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./White-tailed_deer" title="White-tailed deer" id="mwBjg">white-tailed deer</a> and other prey mammals flag with conspicuous tail markings when alarmed, informing the predator that it has been detected.<sup about="#mwt1210" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-180" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-180"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-180" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 180;" id="mwBjk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBjo">[180]</span></a></sup> Many mammals make use of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scent-marking" title="Scent-marking" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBjs">scent-marking</a>, sometimes possibly to help defend territory, but probably with a range of functions both within and between species.<sup about="#mwt1214" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-181" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-181"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-181" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 181;" id="mwBjw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBj0">[181]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1218" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-182" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-182"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-182" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 182;" id="mwBj4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBj8">[182]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1222" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-183" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-183"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-183" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 183;" id="mwBkA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBkE">[183]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Microbat" title="Microbat" id="mwBkI">Microbats</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Toothed_whale" title="Toothed whale" id="mwBkM">toothed whales</a> including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oceanic_dolphin" title="Oceanic dolphin" id="mwBkQ">oceanic dolphins</a> vocalize both socially and in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_echolocation" title="Animal echolocation" id="mwBkU">echolocation</a>.<sup about="#mwt1226" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-184" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-184"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-184" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 184;" id="mwBkY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBkc">[184]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1230" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-185" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-185"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-185" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 185;" id="mwBkg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBkk">[185]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1234" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-186" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-186"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-186" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 186;" id="mwBko"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBks">[186]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="30" id="mwBkw"><h3 id="Feeding">Feeding</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBk0"><span id="mwBk4"><video poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/220px--Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.jpg" controls="" preload="none" height="124" width="220" resource="./File:Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm" id="mwBk8"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9"' data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="720" data-title="Original WebM file, 1,280 × 720 (2 Mbps)" data-shorttitle="WebM source" id="mwBlA"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.120p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="214" data-height="120" data-title="Lowest bandwidth VP9 (120P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 120P" id="mwBlE"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.160p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="284" data-height="160" data-title="Low bandwidth WebM (160P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 160P" id="mwBlI"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.180p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="320" data-height="180" data-title="Low bandwidth VP9 (180P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 180P" id="mwBlM"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.240p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="426" data-height="240" data-title="Small VP9 (240P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 240P" id="mwBlQ"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.240p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="426" data-height="240" data-title="Small WebM (240P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 240P" id="mwBlU"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.360p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="640" data-height="360" data-title="VP9 (360P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 360P" id="mwBlY"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.360p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="640" data-height="360" data-title="WebM (360P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 360P" id="mwBlc"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.480p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="854" data-height="480" data-title="SD VP9 (480P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 480P" id="mwBlg"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.480p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="854" data-height="480" data-title="SD WebM (480P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 480P" id="mwBlk"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.720p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"' data-width="1280" data-height="720" data-title="HD VP9 (720P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 720P" id="mwBlo"/><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a6/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm/Short-beaked_echidna_in_suburban-Sydney_backyard.webm.720p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"' data-width="1280" data-height="720" data-title="HD WebM (720P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 720P" id="mwBls"/></video></span><figcaption id="mwBlw">A <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Short-beaked_echidna" title="Short-beaked echidna" id="mwBl0">short-beaked echidna</a> foraging for insects</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBl4">To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive—mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species have since adapted to meet their dietary requirements in a variety of ways. Some eat other animals—this is a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnivore" title="Carnivore" id="mwBl8">carnivorous</a> diet (and includes insectivorous diets). Other mammals, called <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Herbivore" title="Herbivore" id="mwBmA">herbivores</a>, eat plants, which contain <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Complex_carbohydrate" title="Complex carbohydrate" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBmE">complex carbohydrates</a> such as cellulose. An herbivorous diet includes subtypes such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Granivory" title="Granivory" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBmI">granivory</a> (seed eating), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Folivory" title="Folivory" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBmM">folivory</a> (leaf eating), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Frugivory" title="Frugivory" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBmQ">frugivory</a> (fruit eating), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nectarivory" title="Nectarivory" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBmU">nectarivory</a> (nectar eating), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gummivory" title="Gummivory" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBmY">gummivory</a> (gum eating) and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mycophagy" title="Mycophagy" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBmc">mycophagy</a> (fungus eating). The digestive tract of an herbivore is host to bacteria that ferment these complex substances, and make them available for digestion, which are either housed in the multichambered <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stomach" title="Stomach" id="mwBmg">stomach</a> or in a large cecum.<sup about="#mwt1239" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Comparative_anatomy_of_the_stomach_91-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Comparative anatomy of the stomach"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Comparative_anatomy_of_the_stomach-91" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 91;" id="mwBmk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBmo">[91]</span></a></sup> Some mammals are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coprophagous" title="Coprophagous" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBms">coprophagous</a>, consuming <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feces" title="Feces" id="mwBmw">feces</a> to absorb the nutrients not digested when the food was first ingested.<sup about="#mwt1240" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hair_87-8" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hair"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-hair-87" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwBm0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBm4">[87]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt1238" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"131–137"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBm8"><span title="Page / location: 131–137"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>131–137<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> An <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Omnivore" title="Omnivore" id="mwBnA">omnivore</a> eats both prey and plants. Carnivorous mammals have a simple <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Digestive_system" title="Digestive system" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBnE">digestive tract</a> because the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Protein" title="Protein" id="mwBnI">proteins</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lipid" title="Lipid" id="mwBnM">lipids</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mineral" title="Mineral" id="mwBnQ">minerals</a> found in meat require little in the way of specialized digestion. Exceptions to this include <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Baleen_whale" title="Baleen whale" id="mwBnU">baleen whales</a> who also house <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gut_flora" title="Gut flora" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBnY">gut flora</a> in a multi-chambered stomach, like terrestrial herbivores.<sup about="#mwt1244" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-187" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-187"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-187" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 187;" id="mwBnc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBng">[187]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBnk">The size of an animal is also a factor in determining diet type (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Allen's_rule" title="Allen's rule" id="mwBno">Allen's rule</a>). Since small mammals have a high ratio of heat-losing surface area to heat-generating volume, they tend to have high energy requirements and a high <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metabolism" title="Metabolism" id="mwBns">metabolic rate</a>. Mammals that weigh less than about <span about="#mwt1247" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"18"},"2":{"wt":"oz"},"3":{"wt":"g+lb"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBnw">18 ounces (510</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1247"> </span><span about="#mwt1247">g; 1.1</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1247"> </span><span about="#mwt1247">lb)</span> are mostly insectivorous because they cannot tolerate the slow, complex digestive process of an herbivore. Larger animals, on the other hand, generate more heat and less of this heat is lost. They can therefore tolerate either a slower collection process (carnivores that feed on larger vertebrates) or a slower digestive process (herbivores).<sup about="#mwt1252" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-188" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-188"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-188" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 188;" id="mwBn0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBn4">[188]</span></a></sup> Furthermore, mammals that weigh more than <span about="#mwt1248" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"18"},"2":{"wt":"oz"},"3":{"wt":"g+lb"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBn8">18 ounces (510</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1248"> </span><span about="#mwt1248">g; 1.1</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1248"> </span><span about="#mwt1248">lb)</span> usually cannot collect enough insects during their waking hours to sustain themselves. The only large insectivorous mammals are those that feed on huge colonies of insects (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ant" title="Ant" id="mwBoA">ants</a> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Termite" title="Termite" id="mwBoE">termites</a>).<sup about="#mwt1253" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Smithsonian_Animal_189-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Smithsonian_Animal"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Smithsonian_Animal-189" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 189;" id="mwBoI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBoM">[189]</span></a></sup></p>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" about="#mwt1255" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" narwhal whale (Monodon monoceros) carcass - journal.pone.0060797.g001-A.png"},"footer":{"wt":"The [[hypocarnivore|hypocarnivorous]] [[American black bear]] (&apos;&apos;Ursus americanus&apos;&apos;) href="./File:A_polar_bear_(Ursus_maritimus)_scavenging_a_narwhal_whale_(Monodon_monoceros)_carcass_-_journal.pone.0060797.g001-A.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" 2x"/></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hypocarnivore" title="Hypocarnivore">hypocarnivorous</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./American_black_bear" title="American black bear">American black bear</a> (<i>Ursus americanus</i>) vs. the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hypercarnivorous" title="Hypercarnivorous" class="mw-redirect">hypercarnivorous</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polar_bear" title="Polar bear">polar bear</a> (<i>Ursus maritimus</i>)<sup about="#mwt1259" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-valkenburgh2007_190-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"valkenburgh2007"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-valkenburgh2007-190" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 190;" id="mwBoY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBoc">[190]</span></a></sup></div></div></div></div>
<p id="mwBog">Some mammals are omnivores and display varying degrees of carnivory and herbivory, generally leaning in favor of one more than the other. Since plants and meat are digested differently, there is a preference for one over the other, as in bears where some species may be mostly carnivorous and others mostly herbivorous.<sup about="#mwt1265" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-191" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-191"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-191" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 191;" id="mwBok"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBoo">[191]</span></a></sup> They are grouped into three categories: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mesocarnivore" title="Mesocarnivore" id="mwBos">mesocarnivory</a> (50–70% meat), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hypercarnivore" title="Hypercarnivore" id="mwBow">hypercarnivory</a> (70% and greater of meat), and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hypocarnivore" title="Hypocarnivore" id="mwBo0">hypocarnivory</a> (50% or less of meat). The dentition of hypocarnivores consists of dull, triangular carnassial teeth meant for grinding food. Hypercarnivores, however, have conical teeth and sharp carnassials meant for slashing, and in some cases strong jaws for bone-crushing, as in the case of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hyena" title="Hyena" id="mwBo4">hyenas</a>, allowing them to consume bones; some extinct groups, notably the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Machairodontinae" title="Machairodontinae" id="mwBo8">Machairodontinae</a>, had saber-shaped <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maxillary_canine" title="Maxillary canine" id="mwBpA">canines</a>.<sup about="#mwt1269" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-valkenburgh2007_190-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"valkenburgh2007"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-valkenburgh2007-190"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-valkenburgh2007-190" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 190;" id="mwBpE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBpI">[190]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBpM">Some physiological carnivores consume plant matter and some physiological herbivores consume meat. From a behavioral aspect, this would make them omnivores, but from the physiological standpoint, this may be due to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Zoopharmacognosy" title="Zoopharmacognosy" id="mwBpQ">zoopharmacognosy</a>. Physiologically, animals must be able to obtain both energy and nutrients from plant and animal materials to be considered omnivorous. Thus, such animals are still able to be classified as carnivores and herbivores when they are just obtaining nutrients from materials originating from sources that do not seemingly complement their classification.<sup about="#mwt1276" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-192" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-192"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-192" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 192;" id="mwBpU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBpY">[192]</span></a></sup> For example, it is well documented that some ungulates such as giraffes, camels, and cattle, will gnaw on bones to consume particular minerals and nutrients.<sup about="#mwt1280" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-193" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-193"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-193" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 193;" id="mwBpc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBpg">[193]</span></a></sup> Also, cats, which are generally regarded as obligate carnivores, occasionally eat grass to regurgitate indigestible material (such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hairball" title="Hairball" id="mwBpk">hairballs</a>), aid with hemoglobin production, and as a laxative.<sup about="#mwt1284" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-194" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-194"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-194" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 194;" id="mwBpo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBps">[194]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBpw">Many mammals, in the absence of sufficient food requirements in an environment, suppress their metabolism and conserve energy in a process known as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hibernation" title="Hibernation" id="mwBp0">hibernation</a>.<sup about="#mwt1294" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-195" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-195"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-195" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 195;" id="mwBp4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBp8">[195]</span></a></sup> In the period preceding hibernation, larger mammals, such as bears, become <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polyphagic" title="Polyphagic" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBqA">polyphagic</a> to increase fat stores, whereas smaller mammals prefer to collect and stash food.<sup about="#mwt1298" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-196" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-196"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-196" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 196;" id="mwBqE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBqI">[196]</span></a></sup> The slowing of the metabolism is accompanied by a decreased heart and respiratory rate, as well as a drop in internal temperatures, which can be around ambient temperature in some cases. For example, the internal temperatures of hibernating <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arctic_ground_squirrel" title="Arctic ground squirrel" id="mwBqM">arctic ground squirrels</a> can drop to <span about="#mwt1289" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"-2.9"},"2":{"wt":"C"},"3":{"wt":"F"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBqQ">−2.9</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1289"> </span><span about="#mwt1289">°C (26.8</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1289"> </span><span about="#mwt1289">°F)</span>, however the head and neck always stay above <span about="#mwt1290" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"0"},"2":{"wt":"C"},"3":{"wt":"F"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBqU">0</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1290"> </span><span about="#mwt1290">°C (32</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1290"> </span><span about="#mwt1290">°F)</span>.<sup about="#mwt1302" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-197" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-197"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-197" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 197;" id="mwBqY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBqc">[197]</span></a></sup> A few mammals in hot environments <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aestivate" title="Aestivate" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBqg">aestivate</a> in times of drought or extreme heat, for example the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fat-tailed_dwarf_lemur" title="Fat-tailed dwarf lemur" id="mwBqk">fat-tailed dwarf lemur</a> (<i id="mwBqo">Cheirogaleus medius</i>).<sup about="#mwt1306" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-198" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-198"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-198" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 198;" id="mwBqs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBqw">[198]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="31" id="mwBq0"><h3 id="Intelligence">Intelligence</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1307" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Animal cognition"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBq4"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1307" id="mwBq8">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_cognition" title="Animal cognition">Animal cognition</a></div>
<p id="mwBrA">In intelligent mammals, such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Primate" title="Primate" id="mwBrE">primates</a>, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cerebrum" title="Cerebrum" id="mwBrI">cerebrum</a> is larger relative to the rest of the brain. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Intelligence" title="Intelligence" id="mwBrM">Intelligence</a> itself is not easy to define, but indications of intelligence include the ability to learn, matched with behavioral flexibility. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rat_IQ" title="Rat IQ" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBrQ">Rats</a>, for example, are considered to be highly intelligent, as they can learn and perform new tasks, an ability that may be important when they first colonize a fresh <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biome" title="Biome" id="mwBrU">habitat</a>. In some mammals, food gathering appears to be related to intelligence: a deer feeding on plants has a brain smaller than a cat, which must think to outwit its prey.<sup about="#mwt1314" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Smithsonian_Animal_189-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Smithsonian_Animal"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Smithsonian_Animal-189"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Smithsonian_Animal-189" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 189;" id="mwBrY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBrc">[189]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBrg"><a href='./File:A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_"fishing"_for_termites.jpg' class="mw-file-description" id="mwBrk"><img resource='./File:A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_"fishing"_for_termites.jpg' src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg/220px-A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="2608" data-file-height="1952" data-file-type="bitmap" height="165" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg/330px-A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg/440px-A_Bonobo_at_the_San_Diego_Zoo_%22fishing%22_for_termites.jpg 2x" id="mwBro"/></a><figcaption id="mwBrs">A <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bonobo" title="Bonobo" id="mwBrw">bonobo</a> fishing for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Termite" title="Termite" id="mwBr0">termites</a> with a stick</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBr4"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tool_use_by_animals" title="Tool use by animals" id="mwBr8">Tool use by animals</a> may indicate different levels of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Learning" title="Learning" id="mwBsA">learning</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_cognition" title="Animal cognition" id="mwBsE">cognition</a>. The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tool_use_by_sea_otters" title="Tool use by sea otters" id="mwBsI">sea otter</a> uses rocks as essential and regular parts of its foraging behaviour (smashing <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abalone" title="Abalone" id="mwBsM">abalone</a> from rocks or breaking open shells), with some populations spending 21% of their time making tools.<sup about="#mwt1322" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-199" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-199"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-199" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 199;" id="mwBsQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBsU">[199]</span></a></sup> Other tool use, such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chimpanzee" title="Chimpanzee" id="mwBsY">chimpanzees</a> using twigs to "fish" for termites, may be developed by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Observational_learning" title="Observational learning" id="mwBsc">watching others use tools</a> and may even be a true example of animal teaching.<sup about="#mwt1326" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-200" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-200"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-200" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 200;" id="mwBsg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBsk">[200]</span></a></sup> Tools may even be used in solving puzzles in which the animal appears to experience a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eureka_effect" title="Eureka effect" id="mwBso">"Eureka moment"</a>.<sup about="#mwt1330" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-201" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-201"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-201" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 201;" id="mwBss"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBsw">[201]</span></a></sup> Other mammals that do not use tools, such as dogs, can also experience a Eureka moment.<sup about="#mwt1334" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-202" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-202"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-202" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 202;" id="mwBs0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBs4">[202]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBs8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Brain_size" title="Brain size" id="mwBtA">Brain size</a> was previously considered a major indicator of the intelligence of an animal. Since most of the brain is used for maintaining bodily functions, greater ratios of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Brain-to-body_mass_ratio" title="Brain-to-body mass ratio" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBtE">brain to body mass</a> may increase the amount of brain mass available for more complex cognitive tasks. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Allometric" title="Allometric" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBtI">Allometric</a> analysis indicates that mammalian brain size scales at approximately the <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt1337" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"frac","href":"./Template:Frac"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"2"},"2":{"wt":"3"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBtM">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style><span class="frac" role="math" about="#mwt1337" id="mwBtQ"><span class="num">2</span><span typeof="mw:Entity">⁄</span><span class="den">3</span></span> or <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1020198016" about="#mwt1340" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"frac","href":"./Template:Frac"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"3"},"2":{"wt":"4"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBtU"/><span class="frac" role="math" about="#mwt1340" id="mwBtY"><span class="num">3</span><span typeof="mw:Entity">⁄</span><span class="den">4</span></span> exponent of the body mass. Comparison of a particular animal's brain size with the expected brain size based on such allometric analysis provides an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Encephalization_quotient" title="Encephalization quotient" id="mwBtc">encephalisation quotient</a> that can be used as another indication of animal intelligence.<sup about="#mwt1348" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-203" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-203"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-203" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 203;" id="mwBtg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBtk">[203]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sperm_whale" title="Sperm whale" id="mwBto">Sperm whales</a> have the largest brain mass of any animal on earth, averaging <span about="#mwt1343" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"8,000"},"2":{"wt":"cm3"},"3":{"wt":"in3"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBts">8,000 cubic centimetres (490</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1343"> </span><span about="#mwt1343">in</span><sup about="#mwt1343">3</sup><span about="#mwt1343">)</span> and <span about="#mwt1344" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"7.8"},"2":{"wt":"kg"},"3":{"wt":"lbs"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBtw">7.8 kilograms (17</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1344"> </span><span about="#mwt1344">lb)</span> in mature males.<sup about="#mwt1352" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-204" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-204"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-204" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 204;" id="mwBt0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBt4">[204]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBt8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Self-awareness" title="Self-awareness" id="mwBuA">Self-awareness</a> appears to be a sign of abstract thinking. Self-awareness, although not well-defined, is believed to be a precursor to more advanced processes such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metacognition" title="Metacognition" id="mwBuE">metacognitive reasoning</a>. The traditional method for measuring this is the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mirror_test" title="Mirror test" id="mwBuI">mirror test</a>, which determines if an animal possesses the ability of self-recognition.<sup about="#mwt1371" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-205" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-205"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-205" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 205;" id="mwBuM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBuQ">[205]</span></a></sup> Mammals that have passed the mirror test include Asian elephants (some pass, some do not);<sup about="#mwt1375" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-206" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-206"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-206" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 206;" id="mwBuU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBuY">[206]</span></a></sup> chimpanzees;<sup about="#mwt1379" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-robert_207-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"robert"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-robert-207"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-robert-207" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 207;" id="mwBuc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBug">[207]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bonobo" title="Bonobo" id="mwBuk">bonobos</a>;<sup about="#mwt1383" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-208" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-208"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-208" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 208;" id="mwBuo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBus">[208]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Orangutan" title="Orangutan" id="mwBuw">orangutans</a>;<sup about="#mwt1387" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-orangutan_209-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"orangutan"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-orangutan-209"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-orangutan-209" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 209;" id="mwBu0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBu4">[209]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Human" title="Human" id="mwBu8">humans</a>, from 18 months (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mirror_stage" title="Mirror stage" id="mwBvA">mirror stage</a>);<sup about="#mwt1391" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-archer_210-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"archer"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-archer-210"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-archer-210" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 210;" id="mwBvE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBvI">[210]</span></a></sup> bottlenose dolphins<sup about="#mwt1363" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-212" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Transclusion mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"efn","href":"./Template:Efn"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Decreased latency to approach the mirror, repetitious head circling and close viewing of the marked areas were considered signs of self-recognition since they do not have arms and cannot touch the marked areas.&lt;ref name=parker95/>"}},"i":0}}]}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-212" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 1;" data-mw-group="lower-alpha" id="mwBvM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBvQ">[lower-alpha 1]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1395" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-parker95_211-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"parker95"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-parker95-211"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-parker95-211" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 211;" id="mwBvU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBvY">[211]</span></a></sup> killer whales;<sup about="#mwt1399" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Delfour_213-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Delfour"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Delfour-213"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Delfour-213" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 212;" id="mwBvc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBvg">[212]</span></a></sup> and false killer whales.<sup about="#mwt1400" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Delfour_213-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Delfour"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Delfour-213" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 212;" id="mwBvk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBvo">[212]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="32" id="mwBvs"><h3 id="Social_structure">Social structure</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1401" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":" Social animal"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBvw"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1401" id="mwBv0">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Social_animal" title="Social animal" class="mw-redirect">Social animal</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBv4"><a href="./File:Borneo_elephants.png" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBv8"><img resource="./File:Borneo_elephants.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Borneo_elephants.png/220px-Borneo_elephants.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="650" data-file-height="650" data-file-type="bitmap" height="220" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Borneo_elephants.png/330px-Borneo_elephants.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Borneo_elephants.png/440px-Borneo_elephants.png 2x" id="mwBwA"/></a><figcaption id="mwBwE">Female elephants live in stable groups, along with their offspring.</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBwI"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eusociality" title="Eusociality" id="mwBwM">Eusociality</a> is the highest level of social organization. These societies have an overlap of adult generations, the division of reproductive labor and cooperative caring of young. Usually insects, such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bee" title="Bee" id="mwBwQ">bees</a>, ants and termites, have eusocial behavior, but it is demonstrated in two rodent species: the naked mole-rat<sup about="#mwt1409" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-214" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-214"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-214" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 213;" id="mwBwU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBwY">[213]</span></a></sup> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Damaraland_mole-rat" title="Damaraland mole-rat" id="mwBwc">Damaraland mole-rat</a>.<sup about="#mwt1413" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-215" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-215"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-215" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 214;" id="mwBwg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBwk">[214]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBwo">Presociality is when animals exhibit more than just sexual interactions with members of the same species, but fall short of qualifying as eusocial. That is, presocial animals can display communal living, cooperative care of young, or primitive division of reproductive labor, but they do not display all of the three essential traits of eusocial animals. Humans and some species of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Callitrichidae" title="Callitrichidae" id="mwBws">Callitrichidae</a> (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Marmoset" title="Marmoset" id="mwBww">marmosets</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tamarin" title="Tamarin" id="mwBw0">tamarins</a>) are unique among primates in their degree of cooperative care of young.<sup about="#mwt1419" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-216" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-216"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-216" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 215;" id="mwBw4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBw8">[215]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Harry_Harlow" title="Harry Harlow" id="mwBxA">Harry Harlow</a> set up an experiment with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rhesus_monkey" title="Rhesus monkey" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBxE">rhesus monkeys</a>, presocial primates, in 1958; the results from this study showed that social encounters are necessary in order for the young monkeys to develop both mentally and sexually.<sup about="#mwt1423" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Harlow71_217-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Harlow71"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Harlow71-217"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Harlow71-217" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 216;" id="mwBxI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBxM">[216]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBxQ">A <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fission-fusion_society" title="Fission-fusion society" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBxU">fission-fusion society</a> is a society that changes frequently in its size and composition, making up a permanent social group called the "parent group". Permanent social networks consist of all individual members of a community and often varies to track changes in their environment. In a fission–fusion society, the main parent group can fracture (fission) into smaller stable subgroups or individuals to adapt to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Social_environment" title="Social environment" id="mwBxY">environmental</a> or social circumstances. For example, a number of males may break off from the main group in order to hunt or forage for food during the day, but at night they may return to join (fusion) the primary group to share food and partake in other activities.
