Many mammals exhibit this, such as primates (for example orangutans and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spider_monkey" title="Spider monkey" id="mwBxc">spider monkeys</a>),<sup about="#mwt1432" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-218" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-218"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-218" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 217;" id="mwBxg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBxk">[217]</span></a></sup> elephants,<sup about="#mwt1436" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-219" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-219"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-219" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 218;" id="mwBxo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBxs">[218]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spotted_hyena" title="Spotted hyena" id="mwBxw">spotted hyenas</a>,<sup about="#mwt1440" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-220" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-220"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-220" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 219;" id="mwBx0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBx4">[219]</span></a></sup> lions,<sup about="#mwt1444" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-221" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-221"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-221" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 220;" id="mwBx8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwByA">[220]</span></a></sup> and dolphins.<sup about="#mwt1448" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-222" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-222"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-222" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 221;" id="mwByE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwByI">[221]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwByM">Solitary animals defend a territory and avoid social interactions with the members of its species, except during breeding season. This is to avoid resource competition, as two individuals of the same species would occupy the same niche, and to prevent depletion of food.<sup about="#mwt1454" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-223" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-223"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-223" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 222;" id="mwByQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwByU">[222]</span></a></sup> A solitary animal, while foraging, can also be less conspicuous to predators or prey.<sup about="#mwt1458" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-224" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-224"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-224" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 223;" id="mwByY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwByc">[223]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwByg"><a href="./File:Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwByk"><img resource="./File:Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg/220px-Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="2250" data-file-height="1710" data-file-type="bitmap" height="167" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg/330px-Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg/440px-Fighting_red_kangaroos_2.jpg 2x" id="mwByo"/></a><figcaption id="mwBys"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Red_kangaroo" title="Red kangaroo" id="mwByw">Red kangaroos</a> "boxing" for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dominance_hierarchy" title="Dominance hierarchy" id="mwBy0">dominance</a></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBy4">In a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dominance_hierarchy" title="Dominance hierarchy" id="mwBy8">hierarchy</a>, individuals are either dominant or submissive. A despotic hierarchy is where one individual is dominant while the others are submissive, as in wolves and lemurs,<sup about="#mwt1466" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-225" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-225"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-225" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 224;" id="mwBzA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBzE">[224]</span></a></sup> and a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pecking_order" title="Pecking order" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBzI">pecking order</a> is a linear ranking of individuals where there is a top individual and a bottom individual. Pecking orders may also be ranked by sex, where the lowest individual of a sex has a higher ranking than the top individual of the other sex, as in hyenas.<sup about="#mwt1470" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-226" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-226"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-226" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 225;" id="mwBzM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBzQ">[225]</span></a></sup> Dominant individuals, or alphas, have a high chance of reproductive success, especially in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Harem_(zoology)" title="Harem (zoology)" id="mwBzU">harems</a> where one or a few males (resident males) have exclusive breeding rights to females in a group.<sup about="#mwt1474" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-227" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-227"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-227" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 226;" id="mwBzY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBzc">[226]</span></a></sup> Non-resident males can also be accepted in harems, but some species, such as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Common_vampire_bat" title="Common vampire bat" id="mwBzg">common vampire bat</a> (<i id="mwBzk">Desmodus rotundus</i>), may be more strict.<sup about="#mwt1478" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-228" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-228"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-228" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 227;" id="mwBzo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBzs">[227]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBzw">Some mammals are perfectly <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Monogamy_in_animals" title="Monogamy in animals" id="mwBz0">monogamous</a>, meaning that they <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pair_bond" title="Pair bond" id="mwBz4">mate for life</a> and take no other partners (even after the original mate's death), as with wolves, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eurasian_beaver" title="Eurasian beaver" id="mwBz8">Eurasian beavers</a>, and otters.<sup about="#mwt1486" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-229" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-229"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-229" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 228;" id="mwB0A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB0E">[228]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1490" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-230" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-230"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-230" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 229;" id="mwB0I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB0M">[229]</span></a></sup> There are three types of polygamy: either one or multiple dominant males have breeding rights (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polygyny_in_animals" title="Polygyny in animals" id="mwB0Q">polygyny</a>), multiple males that females mate with (polyandry), or multiple males have exclusive relations with multiple females (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Polygynandry" title="Polygynandry" id="mwB0U">polygynandry</a>). It is much more common for polygynous mating to happen, which, excluding <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lek_mating" title="Lek mating" id="mwB0Y">leks</a>, are estimated to occur in up to 90% of mammals.<sup about="#mwt1494" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-231" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-231"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-231" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 230;" id="mwB0c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB0g">[230]</span></a></sup> Lek mating occurs when males congregate around females and try to attract them with various <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Courtship_display" title="Courtship display" id="mwB0k">courtship displays</a> and vocalizations, as in harbor seals.<sup about="#mwt1498" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-232" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-232"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-232" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 231;" id="mwB0o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB0s">[231]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwB0w">All <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Higher_mammal" title="Higher mammal" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB00">higher mammals</a> (excluding monotremes) share two major adaptations for care of the young: live birth and lactation. These imply a group-wide choice of a degree of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Parental_care" title="Parental care" id="mwB04">parental care</a>. They may build nests and dig burrows to raise their young in, or feed and guard them often for a prolonged period of time. Many mammals are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./K-selected" title="K-selected" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB08">K-selected</a>, and invest more time and energy into their young than do <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./R-selected" title="R-selected" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB1A">r-selected</a> animals. When two animals mate, they both share an interest in the success of the offspring, though often to different extremes. Mammalian females exhibit some degree of maternal aggression, another example of parental care, which may be targeted against other females of the species or the young of other females; however, some mammals may "aunt" the infants of other females, and care for them. Mammalian males may play a role in child rearing, as with tenrecs, however this varies species to species, even within the same genus. For example, the males of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Southern_pig-tailed_macaque" title="Southern pig-tailed macaque" id="mwB1E">southern pig-tailed macaque</a> (<i id="mwB1I">Macaca nemestrina</i>) do not participate in child care, whereas the males of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Japanese_macaque" title="Japanese macaque" id="mwB1M">Japanese macaque</a> (<i id="mwB1Q">M. fuscata</i>) do.<sup about="#mwt1503" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-233" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-233"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-233" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 232;" id="mwB1U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB1Y">[232]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="33" id="mwB1c"><h2 id="Humans_and_other_mammals">Humans and other mammals</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1504" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Human uses of mammals"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwB1g"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1504" id="mwB1k">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Human_uses_of_mammals" title="Human uses of mammals">Human uses of mammals</a></div>

<section data-mw-section-id="34" id="mwB1o"><h3 id="In_human_culture">In human culture</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwB1s"><a href="./File:Lascaux_painting.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwB1w"><img resource="./File:Lascaux_painting.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Lascaux_painting.jpg/220px-Lascaux_painting.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="472" data-file-type="bitmap" height="144" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Lascaux_painting.jpg/330px-Lascaux_painting.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Lascaux_painting.jpg/440px-Lascaux_painting.jpg 2x" id="mwB10"/></a><figcaption id="mwB14"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Upper_Paleolithic" title="Upper Paleolithic" id="mwB18">Upper Paleolithic</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cave_painting" title="Cave painting" id="mwB2A">cave painting</a> of a variety of large mammals, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lascaux" title="Lascaux" id="mwB2E">Lascaux</a>, <abbr title="circa" about="#mwt1507" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"circa","href":"./Template:Circa"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"17,300"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwB2I">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;" about="#mwt1507" id="mwB2M"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>17,300</span> years old.</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwB2Q">Non-human mammals play a wide variety of roles in human culture. They are the most popular of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pet" title="Pet" id="mwB2U">pets</a>, with tens of millions of dogs, cats and other animals including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rabbit" title="Rabbit" id="mwB2Y">rabbits</a> and mice kept by families around the world.<sup about="#mwt1529" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-234" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-234"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-234" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 233;" id="mwB2c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB2g">[233]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1533" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-235" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-235"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-235" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 234;" id="mwB2k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB2o">[234]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1537" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-236" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-236"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-236" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 235;" id="mwB2s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB2w">[235]</span></a></sup> Mammals such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammoth" title="Mammoth" id="mwB20">mammoths</a>, horses and deer are among the earliest subjects of art, being found in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Upper_Paleolithic" title="Upper Paleolithic" id="mwB24">Upper Paleolithic</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cave_painting" title="Cave painting" id="mwB28">cave paintings</a> such as at <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lascaux" title="Lascaux" id="mwB3A">Lascaux</a>.<sup about="#mwt1541" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-237" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-237"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-237" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 236;" id="mwB3E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB3I">[236]</span></a></sup> Major artists such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Albrecht_Dürer" title="Albrecht Dürer" id="mwB3M">Albrecht Dürer</a><!--rhino-->, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./George_Stubbs" title="George Stubbs" id="mwB3Q">George Stubbs</a><!--horses--> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Edwin_Landseer" title="Edwin Landseer" id="mwB3U">Edwin Landseer</a><!--red deer--> are known for their portraits of mammals.<sup about="#mwt1545" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Jones_238-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Jones"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Jones-238"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Jones-238" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 237;" id="mwB3Y"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB3c">[237]</span></a></sup> Many species of mammals have been <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hunting" title="Hunting" id="mwB3g">hunted</a> for sport and for food; deer and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wild_boar" title="Wild boar" id="mwB3k">wild boar</a> are especially popular as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Game_(hunting)" title="Game (hunting)" id="mwB3o">game animals</a>.<sup about="#mwt1549" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-239" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-239"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-239" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 238;" id="mwB3s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB3w">[238]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1553" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-240" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-240"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-240" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 239;" id="mwB30"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB34">[239]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1557" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-241" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-241"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-241" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 240;" id="mwB38"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB4A">[240]</span></a></sup> Mammals such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Horse_racing" title="Horse racing" id="mwB4E">horses</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Greyhound_racing" title="Greyhound racing" id="mwB4I">dogs</a> are widely raced for sport, often combined with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gambling" title="Gambling" id="mwB4M">betting on the outcome</a>.<sup about="#mwt1561" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-242" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-242"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-242" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 241;" id="mwB4Q"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB4U">[241]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1565" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-243" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-243"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-243" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 242;" id="mwB4Y"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB4c">[242]</span></a></sup> There is a tension between the role of animals as companions to humans, and their existence as individuals with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_rights" title="Animal rights" id="mwB4g">rights of their own</a>.<sup about="#mwt1569" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-244" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-244"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-244" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 243;" id="mwB4k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB4o">[243]</span></a></sup> Mammals further play a wide variety of roles in literature,<sup about="#mwt1573" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-245" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-245"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-245" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 244;" id="mwB4s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB4w">[244]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1577" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-246" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-246"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-246" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 245;" id="mwB40"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB44">[245]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1581" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-247" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-247"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-247" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 246;" id="mwB48"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB5A">[246]</span></a></sup> film,<sup about="#mwt1585" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-248" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-248"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-248" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 247;" id="mwB5E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB5I">[247]</span></a></sup> mythology, and religion.<sup about="#mwt1589" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-249" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-249"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-249" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 248;" id="mwB5M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB5Q">[248]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1593" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-250" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-250"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-250" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 249;" id="mwB5U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB5Y">[249]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1597" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-251" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-251"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-251" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 250;" id="mwB5c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB5g">[250]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="35" id="mwB5k"><h3 id="Uses_and_importance">Uses and importance</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1598" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Livestock"},"2":{"wt":"Laboratory animal"},"3":{"wt":"Pack animal"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwB5o"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1598" id="mwB5s">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Livestock" title="Livestock">Livestock</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Laboratory_animal" title="Laboratory animal" class="mw-redirect">Laboratory animal</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pack_animal" title="Pack animal">Pack animal</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwB5w"><a href="./File:Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwB50"><img resource="./File:Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg/170px-Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="1200" data-file-type="bitmap" height="227" width="170" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg/255px-Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg/340px-Hand_milking_a_cow_at_Cobbes_Farm_Museum.jpg 2x" id="mwB54"/></a><figcaption id="mwB58"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cattle" title="Cattle" id="mwB6A">Cattle</a> have been <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dairy_farming" title="Dairy farming" id="mwB6E">kept for milk</a> for thousands of years.</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwB6I">The domestication of mammals was instrumental in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neolithic_Revolution" title="Neolithic Revolution" id="mwB6M">Neolithic development of agriculture</a> and of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Civilization" title="Civilization" id="mwB6Q">civilization</a>, causing farmers to replace <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer" id="mwB6U">hunter-gatherers</a> around the world.<sup about="#mwt1604" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-253" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Transclusion mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"efn","href":"./Template:Efn"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Diamond discussed this matter further in his 1997 book &apos;&apos;[[Guns, Germs, and Steel]]&apos;&apos;.&lt;ref>{{cite book | vauthors = Diamond JM |author-link=Jared Diamond |year=1997 |title=Guns, Germs, and Steel: the Fates of Human Societies|chapter=Part 2: The rise and spread of food production |edition=1 |location=New York |publisher=W.W. Norton &amp; Company|isbn=978-0-393-03891-0 |oclc=35792200 |chapter-url={{Google books|plainurl=yes |id=PWnWRFEGoeUC |page=176 }}}}&lt;/ref>"}},"i":0}}]}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-253" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 2;" data-mw-group="lower-alpha" id="mwB6Y"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB6c">[lower-alpha 2]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1615" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Larson_254-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Larson"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Larson-254"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Larson-254" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 252;" id="mwB6g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB6k">[252]</span></a></sup> This transition from hunting and gathering to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pastoralism" title="Pastoralism" id="mwB6o">herding flocks</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Agriculture" title="Agriculture" id="mwB6s">growing crops</a> was a major step in human history. The new agricultural economies, based on domesticated mammals, caused "radical restructuring of human societies, worldwide alterations in biodiversity, and significant changes in the Earth's landforms and its atmosphere... momentous outcomes".<sup about="#mwt1619" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-255" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-255"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-255" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 253;" id="mwB6w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB60">[253]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwB64"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Domestication" title="Domestication" id="mwB68">Domestic</a> mammals form a large part of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Livestock" title="Livestock" id="mwB7A">livestock</a> raised for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Meat" title="Meat" id="mwB7E">meat</a> across the world. They include (2009) around 1.4<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwB7I"> </span>billion <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cattle" title="Cattle" id="mwB7M">cattle</a>, 1<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwB7Q"> </span>billion <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sheep" title="Sheep" id="mwB7U">sheep</a>, 1<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwB7Y"> </span>billion <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Domestic_pig" title="Domestic pig" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB7c">domestic pigs</a>,<sup about="#mwt1629" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-256" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-256"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-256" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 254;" id="mwB7g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB7k">[254]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1633" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-257" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-257"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-257" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 255;" id="mwB7o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB7s">[255]</span></a></sup> and (1985) over 700<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwB7w"> </span>million rabbits.<sup about="#mwt1637" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-258" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-258"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-258" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 256;" id="mwB70"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB74">[256]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Working_animal" title="Working animal" id="mwB78">Working domestic animals</a> including cattle and horses have been used for work and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Transport" title="Transport" id="mwB8A">transport</a> from the origins of agriculture, their numbers declining with the arrival of mechanised transport and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Agricultural_machinery" title="Agricultural machinery" id="mwB8E">agricultural machinery</a>. In 2004 they still provided some 80% of the power for the mainly small farms in the third world, and some 20% of the world's transport, again mainly in rural areas. In mountainous regions unsuitable for wheeled vehicles, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pack_animal" title="Pack animal" id="mwB8I">pack animals</a> continue to transport goods.<sup about="#mwt1641" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Pond2004_259-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Pond2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Pond2004-259"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Pond2004-259" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 257;" id="mwB8M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB8Q">[257]</span></a></sup> Mammal skins provide <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Leather" title="Leather" id="mwB8U">leather</a> for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shoe" title="Shoe" id="mwB8Y">shoes</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Clothing" title="Clothing" id="mwB8c">clothing</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Upholstery" title="Upholstery" id="mwB8g">upholstery</a>. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wool" title="Wool" id="mwB8k">Wool</a> from mammals including sheep, goats and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Alpaca" title="Alpaca" id="mwB8o">alpacas</a> has been used for centuries for clothing.<sup about="#mwt1645" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-260" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-260"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-260" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 258;" id="mwB8s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB8w">[258]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1649" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-261" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-261"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-261" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 259;" id="mwB80"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB84">[259]</span></a></sup></p>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwB88"><a href="./File:Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png" class="mw-file-description" id="mwB9A"><img resource="./File:Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png/432px-Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="2454" data-file-height="2360" data-file-type="bitmap" height="415" width="432" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png/648px-Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png/864px-Distribution-of-earths-mammals.png 2x" id="mwB9E"/></a><figcaption id="mwB9I">Wild mammals make up only 4% of all mammals, while humans and their livestock represent 96% of all mammals in terms of biomass.<sup about="#mwt1651" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Bar-On_2018_262-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Bar-On_2018"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Bar-On_2018-262" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 260;" id="mwB9M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB9Q">[260]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwB9U">Mammals serve a major role in science as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_model" title="Animal model" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB9Y">experimental animals</a>, both in fundamental biological research, such as in genetics,<sup about="#mwt1662" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-263" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-263"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-263" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 261;" id="mwB9c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB9g">[261]</span></a></sup> and in the development of new medicines, which must be tested exhaustively to demonstrate their <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pharmacovigilance" title="Pharmacovigilance" id="mwB9k">safety</a>.<sup about="#mwt1666" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-264" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-264"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-264" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 262;" id="mwB9o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB9s">[262]</span></a></sup> Millions of mammals, especially mice and rats, are used in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_testing" title="Animal testing" id="mwB9w">experiments</a> each year.<sup about="#mwt1670" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-EUstatistics2013_265-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"EUstatistics2013"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-EUstatistics2013-265"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-EUstatistics2013-265" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 263;" id="mwB90"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB94">[263]</span></a></sup> A <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Knockout_mouse" title="Knockout mouse" id="mwB98">knockout mouse</a> is a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genetically_modified_mouse" title="Genetically modified mouse" id="mwB-A">genetically modified mouse</a> with an inactivated <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gene" title="Gene" id="mwB-E">gene</a>, replaced or disrupted with an artificial piece of DNA. They enable the study of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sequencing" title="Sequencing" id="mwB-I">sequenced</a> genes whose functions are unknown.<sup about="#mwt1674" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-266" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-266"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-266" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 264;" id="mwB-M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB-Q">[264]</span></a></sup> A small percentage of the mammals are non-human primates, used in research for their similarity to humans.<sup about="#mwt1678" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-267" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-267"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-267" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 265;" id="mwB-U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB-Y">[265]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1682" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Carlsson2004_268-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Carlsson2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Carlsson2004-268"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Carlsson2004-268" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 266;" id="mwB-c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB-g">[266]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1686" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Weatherall_etal2006_269-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Weatherall_etal2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Weatherall_etal2006-269"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Weatherall_etal2006-269" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 267;" id="mwB-k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB-o">[267]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwB-s">Despite the benefits domesticated mammals had for human development, humans have an increasingly detrimental effect on wild mammals across the world. It has been estimated that the mass of all <i id="mwB-w">wild</i> mammals has declined to only 4% of all mammals, with 96% of mammals being humans and their livestock now (see figure). In fact, terrestrial wild mammals make up only 2% of all mammals.<sup about="#mwt1692" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-270" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-270"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-270" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 268;" id="mwB-0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB-4">[268]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1696" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Bar-On_2018_262-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Bar-On_2018"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Bar-On_2018-262"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Bar-On_2018-262" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 260;" id="mwB-8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB_A">[260]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="36" id="mwB_E"><h3 id="Hybrids">Hybrids</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1697" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Hybrid (biology)"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwB_I"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1697" id="mwB_M">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hybrid_(biology)" title="Hybrid (biology)">Hybrid (biology)</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" about="#mwt1700" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Multiple image\n","href":"./Template:Multiple_image"},"params":{"image1":{"wt":"Equus quagga quagga, coloured.jpg"},"image2":{"wt":"Rau Quagga on Devils Peak.jpg"},"width":{"wt":"200"},"footer":{"wt":"A true [[quagga]], 1870 (left) vs. a [[Quagga Project|bred-back quagga]], 2014 (right)"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwB_Q"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright" about="#mwt1700" id="mwB_U"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:Equus_quagga_quagga,_coloured.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:Equus_quagga_quagga,_coloured.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Equus_quagga_quagga%2C_coloured.jpg/200px-Equus_quagga_quagga%2C_coloured.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1138" data-file-height="798" data-file-type="bitmap" height="140" width="200" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Equus_quagga_quagga%2C_coloured.jpg/300px-Equus_quagga_quagga%2C_coloured.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Equus_quagga_quagga%2C_coloured.jpg/400px-Equus_quagga_quagga%2C_coloured.jpg 2x"/></a></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg/200px-Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="904" data-file-type="bitmap" height="129" width="200" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg/300px-Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg/400px-Rau_Quagga_on_Devils_Peak.jpg 2x"/></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">A true <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Quagga" title="Quagga">quagga</a>, 1870 (left) vs. a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Quagga_Project" title="Quagga Project">bred-back quagga</a>, 2014 (right)</div></div></div></div>

<p id="mwB_Y">Hybrids are offspring resulting from the breeding of two genetically distinct individuals, which usually will result in a high degree of heterozygosity, though hybrid and heterozygous are not synonymous. The deliberate or accidental hybridizing of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown for economic purposes.<sup about="#mwt1709" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-271" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-271"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-271" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 269;" id="mwB_c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB_g">[269]</span></a></sup> Hybrids between different subspecies within a species (such as between the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bengal_tiger" title="Bengal tiger" id="mwB_k">Bengal tiger</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Siberian_tiger" title="Siberian tiger" id="mwB_o">Siberian tiger</a>) are known as intra-specific hybrids. Hybrids between different species within the same genus (such as between lions and tigers) are known as interspecific hybrids or crosses. Hybrids between different genera (such as between sheep and goats) are known as intergeneric hybrids.<sup about="#mwt1713" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-272" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-272"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-272" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 270;" id="mwB_s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB_w">[270]</span></a></sup> Natural hybrids will occur in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hybrid_zone" title="Hybrid zone" id="mwB_0">hybrid zones</a>, where two populations of species within the same genera or species living in the same or adjacent areas will interbreed with each other. Some hybrids have been recognized as species, such as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Red_wolf" title="Red wolf" id="mwB_4">red wolf</a> (though this is controversial).<sup about="#mwt1717" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-273" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-273"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-273" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 271;" id="mwB_8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCAA">[271]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCAE"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Artificial_selection" title="Artificial selection" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCAI">Artificial selection</a>, the deliberate <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Selective_breeding" title="Selective breeding" id="mwCAM">selective breeding</a> of domestic animals, is being used to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Breeding_back" title="Breeding back" id="mwCAQ">breed back</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Holocene_extinction" title="Holocene extinction" id="mwCAU">recently extinct</a> animals in an attempt to achieve an animal breed with a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phenotype" title="Phenotype" id="mwCAY">phenotype</a> that resembles that extinct <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wildtype" title="Wildtype" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCAc">wildtype</a> ancestor. A breeding-back (intraspecific) hybrid may be very similar to the extinct wildtype in appearance, ecological niche and to some extent genetics, but the initial <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gene_pool" title="Gene pool" id="mwCAg">gene pool</a> of that wild type is lost forever with its <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Extinction" title="Extinction" id="mwCAk">extinction</a>. As a result, bred-back breeds are at best vague look-alikes of extinct wildtypes, as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Heck_cattle" title="Heck cattle" id="mwCAo">Heck cattle</a> are of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aurochs" title="Aurochs" id="mwCAs">aurochs</a>.<sup about="#mwt1722" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-vanVuure_274-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"vanVuure"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-vanVuure-274"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-vanVuure-274" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 272;" id="mwCAw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCA0">[272]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCA4"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Purebred" title="Purebred" id="mwCA8">Purebred</a> wild species evolved to a specific ecology can be threatened with extinction<sup about="#mwt1731" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-275" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-275"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-275" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 273;" id="mwCBA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCBE">[273]</span></a></sup> through the process of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genetic_pollution" title="Genetic pollution" id="mwCBI">genetic pollution</a>, the uncontrolled hybridization, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Introgression" title="Introgression" id="mwCBM">introgression</a> genetic swamping which leads to homogenization or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fitness_(biology)" title="Fitness (biology)" id="mwCBQ">out-competition</a> from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Heterosis" title="Heterosis" id="mwCBU">heterosic</a> hybrid species.<sup about="#mwt1735" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-276" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-276"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-276" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 274;" id="mwCBY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCBc">[274]</span></a></sup> When new populations are imported or selectively bred by people, or when habitat modification brings previously isolated species into contact, extinction in some species, especially rare varieties, is possible.<sup about="#mwt1739" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-277" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-277"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-277" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 275;" id="mwCBg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCBk">[275]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Interbreeding" title="Interbreeding" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCBo">Interbreeding</a> can swamp the rarer gene pool and create hybrids, depleting the purebred gene pool. For example, the endangered <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wild_water_buffalo" title="Wild water buffalo" id="mwCBs">wild water buffalo</a> is most threatened with extinction by genetic pollution from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Water_buffalo" title="Water buffalo" id="mwCBw">domestic water buffalo</a>. Such extinctions are not always apparent from a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Morphology_(biology)" title="Morphology (biology)" id="mwCB0">morphological</a> standpoint. Some degree of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gene_flow" title="Gene flow" id="mwCB4">gene flow</a> is a normal evolutionary process, nevertheless, hybridization threatens the existence of rare species.<sup about="#mwt1743" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-278" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-278"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-278" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 276;" id="mwCB8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCCA">[276]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1747" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-279" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-279"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-279" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 277;" id="mwCCE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCCI">[277]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="37" id="mwCCM"><h3 id="Threats">Threats</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1748" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"See also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Holocene extinction"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCCQ"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1748" id="mwCCU">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Holocene_extinction" title="Holocene extinction">Holocene extinction</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwCCY"><a href="./File:Extinctions_Africa_Austrailia_NAmerica_Madagascar.gif" class="mw-file-description" id="mwCCc"><img resource="./File:Extinctions_Africa_Austrailia_NAmerica_Madagascar.gif" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Extinctions_Africa_Austrailia_NAmerica_Madagascar.gif/310px-Extinctions_Africa_Austrailia_NAmerica_Madagascar.gif" decoding="async" data-file-width="441" data-file-height="452" data-file-type="bitmap" height="318" width="310" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/ad/Extinctions_Africa_Austrailia_NAmerica_Madagascar.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/ad/Extinctions_Africa_Austrailia_NAmerica_Madagascar.gif 2x" id="mwCCg"/></a><figcaption id="mwCCk">Biodiversity of large mammal species per continent before and after humans arrived there</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwCCo">The loss of species from ecological communities, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Defaunation" title="Defaunation" id="mwCCs">defaunation</a>, is primarily driven by human activity.<sup about="#mwt1759" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-dirzo_280-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"dirzo"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-dirzo-280" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 278;" id="mwCCw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCC0">[278]</span></a></sup> This has resulted in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Empty_forest" title="Empty forest" id="mwCC4">empty forests</a>, ecological communities depleted of large vertebrates.<sup about="#mwt1763" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-primack2014_281-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"primack2014"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-primack2014-281"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-primack2014-281" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 279;" id="mwCC8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCDA">[279]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1767" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-282" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-282"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-282" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 280;" id="mwCDE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCDI">[280]</span></a></sup> In the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Quaternary_extinction_event" title="Quaternary extinction event" id="mwCDM">Quaternary extinction event</a>, the mass die-off of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megafauna" title="Megafauna" id="mwCDQ">megafaunal</a> variety coincided with the appearance of humans, suggesting a human influence. One hypothesis is that humans hunted large mammals, such as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Woolly_mammoth" title="Woolly mammoth" id="mwCDU">woolly mammoth</a>, into extinction.<sup about="#mwt1772" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-283" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-283"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-283" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 281;" id="mwCDY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCDc">[281]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1776" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-284" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-284"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-284" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 282;" id="mwCDg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCDk">[282]</span></a></sup> The 2019 <i id="mwCDo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Global_Assessment_Report_on_Biodiversity_and_Ecosystem_Services" title="Global Assessment Report on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services" id="mwCDs">Global Assessment Report on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services</a></i> by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./IPBES" title="IPBES" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCDw">IPBES</a> states that the total <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biomass_(ecology)" title="Biomass (ecology)" id="mwCD0">biomass</a> of wild mammals has declined by 82 percent since the beginning of human civilization.<sup about="#mwt1780" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-285" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-285"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-285" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 283;" id="mwCD4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCD8">[283]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1784" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-286" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-286"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-286" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 284;" id="mwCEA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCEE">[284]</span></a></sup> Wild animals make up just 4% of mammalian <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biomass_(ecology)" title="Biomass (ecology)" id="mwCEI">biomass</a> on earth, while humans and their domesticated animals make up 96%.<sup about="#mwt1785" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Bar-On_2018_262-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Bar-On_2018"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-Bar-On_2018-262" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 260;" id="mwCEM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCEQ">[260]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCEU">Various species are predicted to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_critically_endangered_species" title="List of critically endangered species" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCEY">become extinct in the near future</a>,<sup about="#mwt1806" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-287" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-287"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-287" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 285;" id="mwCEc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCEg">[285]</span></a></sup> among them the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rhinoceros" title="Rhinoceros" id="mwCEk">rhinoceros</a>,<sup about="#mwt1810" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-288" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-288"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-288" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 286;" id="mwCEo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCEs">[286]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Giraffes" title="Giraffes" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCEw">giraffes</a>,<sup about="#mwt1814" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-289" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-289"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-289" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 287;" id="mwCE0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCE4">[287]</span></a></sup> and species of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Primates" title="Primates" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCE8">primates</a><sup about="#mwt1818" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-primates_290-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"primates"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-primates-290"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-primates-290" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 288;" id="mwCFA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCFE">[288]</span></a></sup> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pangolins" title="Pangolins" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCFI">pangolins</a>.<sup about="#mwt1823" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-291" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-291"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-291" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 289;" id="mwCFM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCFQ">[289]</span></a></sup> According to the WWF's 2020 <i id="mwCFU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Living_Planet_Report" title="Living Planet Report" id="mwCFY">Living Planet Report</a></i>, vertebrate <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wildlife" title="Wildlife" id="mwCFc">wildlife</a> populations have declined by 68% since 1970 as a result of human activities, particularly <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Overconsumption" title="Overconsumption" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCFg">overconsumption</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Population_growth" title="Population growth" id="mwCFk">population growth</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Intensive_farming" title="Intensive farming" id="mwCFo">intensive farming</a>, which is evidence that humans have triggered a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sixth_mass_extinction" title="Sixth mass extinction" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCFs">sixth mass extinction</a> event.<sup about="#mwt1827" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-292" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-292"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-292" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 290;" id="mwCFw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCF0">[290]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1831" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-293" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-293"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-293" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 291;" id="mwCF4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCF8">[291]</span></a></sup> Hunting alone threatens hundreds of mammalian species around the world.<sup about="#mwt1835" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-294" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-294"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-294" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 292;" id="mwCGA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCGE">[292]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1839" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-295" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-295"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-295" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 293;" id="mwCGI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCGM">[293]</span></a></sup> Scientists claim that the growing demand for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Meat" title="Meat" id="mwCGQ">meat</a> is contributing to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biodiversity_loss" title="Biodiversity loss" id="mwCGU">biodiversity loss</a> as this is a significant driver of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deforestation" title="Deforestation" id="mwCGY">deforestation</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Habitat_destruction" title="Habitat destruction" id="mwCGc">habitat destruction</a>; species-rich habitats, such as significant portions of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Amazon_rainforest" title="Amazon rainforest" id="mwCGg">Amazon rainforest</a>, are being converted to agricultural land for meat production.<sup about="#mwt1843" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-296" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-296"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-296" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 294;" id="mwCGk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCGo">[294]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1847" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-297" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-297"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-297" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 295;" id="mwCGs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCGw">[295]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1851" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-298" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-298"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-298" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 296;" id="mwCG0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCG4">[296]</span></a></sup> Another influence is over-hunting and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Species_affected_by_poaching" title="Species affected by poaching" id="mwCG8">poaching</a>, which can reduce the overall population of game animals,<sup about="#mwt1855" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-299" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-299"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-299" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 297;" id="mwCHA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCHE">[297]</span></a></sup> especially those located near villages,<sup about="#mwt1859" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-peres2006_300-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"peres2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-peres2006-300"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-peres2006-300" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 298;" id="mwCHI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCHM">[298]</span></a></sup> as in the case of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Peccary" title="Peccary" id="mwCHQ">peccaries</a>.<sup about="#mwt1863" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-301" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-301"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-301" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 299;" id="mwCHU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCHY">[299]</span></a></sup> The effects of poaching can especially be seen in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ivory_trade" title="Ivory trade" id="mwCHc">ivory trade</a> with African elephants.<sup about="#mwt1867" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-302" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-302"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-302" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 300;" id="mwCHg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCHk">[300]</span></a></sup> Marine mammals are at risk from entanglement from fishing gear, notably <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cetacean_bycatch" title="Cetacean bycatch" id="mwCHo">cetaceans</a>, with discard mortalities ranging from 65,000 to 86,000 individuals annually.<sup about="#mwt1871" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-303" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-303"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-303" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 301;" id="mwCHs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCHw">[301]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCH0">Attention is being given to endangered species globally, notably through the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Convention_on_Biological_Diversity" title="Convention on Biological Diversity" id="mwCH4">Convention on Biological Diversity</a>, otherwise known as the Rio Accord, which includes 189 signatory countries that are focused on identifying endangered species and habitats.<sup about="#mwt1877" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-304" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-304"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-304" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 302;" id="mwCH8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCIA">[302]</span></a></sup> Another notable conservation organization is the IUCN, which has a membership of over 1,200 governmental and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Non-governmental_organization" title="Non-governmental organization" id="mwCIE">non-governmental</a> organizations.<sup about="#mwt1881" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-305" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-305"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-305" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 303;" id="mwCII"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCIM">[303]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCIQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./List_of_recently_extinct_mammals" title="List of recently extinct mammals" id="mwCIU">Recent extinctions</a> can be directly attributed to human influences.<sup about="#mwt1895" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ceballos_306-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ceballos"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-ceballos-306"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-ceballos-306" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 304;" id="mwCIY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCIc">[304]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1899" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-dirzo_280-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"dirzo"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-dirzo-280"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-dirzo-280" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 278;" id="mwCIg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCIk">[278]</span></a></sup> The IUCN characterizes 'recent' extinction as those that have occurred past the cut-off point of 1500,<sup about="#mwt1903" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-307" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-307"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-307" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 305;" id="mwCIo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCIs">[305]</span></a></sup> and around 80 mammal species have gone extinct since that time and 2015.<sup about="#mwt1907" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-308" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-308"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-308" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 306;" id="mwCIw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCI0">[306]</span></a></sup> Some species, such as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Père_David's_deer" title="Père David's deer" id="mwCI4">Père David's deer</a><sup about="#mwt1911" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-309" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-309"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-309" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 307;" id="mwCI8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCJA">[307]</span></a></sup> are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Extinct_in_the_wild" title="Extinct in the wild" id="mwCJE">extinct in the wild</a>, and survive solely in captive populations. Other species, such as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Florida_panther" title="Florida panther" id="mwCJI">Florida panther</a>, are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ecological_extinction" title="Ecological extinction" id="mwCJM">ecologically extinct</a>, surviving in such low numbers that they essentially have no impact on the ecosystem.<sup about="#mwt1915" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-mckinney2013_310-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"mckinney2013"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-mckinney2013-310"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-mckinney2013-310" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 308;" id="mwCJQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCJU">[308]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt1890" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"318"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCJY"><span title="Page / location: 318"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>318<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> Other populations are only <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Local_extinction" title="Local extinction" id="mwCJc">locally extinct</a> (extirpated), still existing elsewhere, but reduced in distribution,<sup about="#mwt1916" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-mckinney2013_310-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"mckinney2013"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-mckinney2013-310" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 308;" id="mwCJg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCJk">[308]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap" about="#mwt1891" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"rp","href":"./Template:Rp"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"75–77"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCJo"><span title="Page / location: 75–77"><span typeof="mw:Entity">:</span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>75–77<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span></sup> as with the extinction of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gray_whale" title="Gray whale" id="mwCJs">gray whales</a> in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean" id="mwCJw">Atlantic</a>.<sup about="#mwt1920" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-311" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-311"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-311" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 309;" id="mwCJ0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCJ4">[309]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="38" id="mwCJ8"><h2 id="Notes">Notes</h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt1921" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Notelist","href":"./Template:Notelist"},"params":{},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCKA">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist  reflist-lower-alpha " about="#mwt1921" id="mwCKE">
<div class="mw-references-wrap" typeof="mw:Extension/references" about="#mwt1925" data-mw='{"name":"references","attrs":{"group":"lower-alpha","responsive":"1"},"body":{"html":""}}' id="mwCKI"><ol class="mw-references references" data-mw-group="lower-alpha" id="mwCKM"><li about="#cite_note-212" id="cite_note-212"><a href="./Mammal#cite_ref-212" data-mw-group="lower-alpha" rel="mw:referencedBy" id="mwCKQ"><span class="mw-linkback-text" id="mwCKU">↑ </span></a> <span id="mw-reference-text-cite_note-212" class="mw-reference-text">Decreased latency to approach the mirror, repetitious head circling and close viewing of the marked areas were considered signs of self-recognition since they do not have arms and cannot touch the marked areas.<sup about="#mwt1366" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-parker95_211-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"parker95"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-parker95-211" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 211;" id="mwCKY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCKc">[211]</span></a></sup></span></li><li about="#cite_note-253" id="cite_note-253"><a href="./Mammal#cite_ref-253" data-mw-group="lower-alpha" rel="mw:referencedBy" id="mwCKg"><span class="mw-linkback-text" id="mwCKk">↑ </span></a> <span id="mw-reference-text-cite_note-253" class="mw-reference-text">Diamond discussed this matter further in his 1997 book <i id="mwCKo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Guns,_Germs,_and_Steel" title="Guns, Germs, and Steel" id="mwCKs">Guns, Germs, and Steel</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt1610" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-252" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-252"}}'><a href="./Mammal#cite_note-252" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 251;" id="mwCKw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCK0">[251]</span></a></sup></span></li></ol></div></div>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="39" id="mwCK4"><h2 id="See_also">See also</h2>

"Classification of mammals above the species level: Review". <i id="mwCNg">Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology</i>. <b id="mwCNk">19</b> (1): 191–195. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCNo">doi</a>:<a rel="mw:ExtLink nofollow" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F02724634.1999.10011133" class="external text" </div>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="43" id="mwGN8"><h2 id="External_links">External links</h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1134653256" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt1967" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Wikibooks","href":"./Template:Wikibooks"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Dichotomous Key"},"2":{"wt":"Mammalia"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwGOA">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:#f9f9f9;display:flow-root}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><div class="side-box side-box-right plainlinks sistersitebox" about="#mwt1967" id="mwGOE"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1126788409" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles" about="#mwt1971" data-mw='{"name":"templatestyles","attrs":{"src":"Plainlist/styles.css"},"body":{"extsrc":""}}'>.mw-parser-output .plainlist ol,.mw-parser-output .plainlist ul{line-height:inherit;list-style:none;margin:0;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .plainlist ol li,.mw-parser-output .plainlist ul li{margin-bottom:0}</style>

<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wikisource" title="Wikisource">Wikisource</a> has the text of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Encyclopædia_Britannica_Eleventh_Edition" title="Encyclopædia Britannica Eleventh Edition">1911 <i>Encyclopædia Britannica</i></a> article "<span style=" font-weight:bold; "><a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/1911%20Encyclopædia%20Britannica/Mammalia" title="wikisource:1911 Encyclopædia Britannica/Mammalia" class="extiw">Mammalia</a></span>".</div></div>

<li id="mwGOs"><a rel="mw:ExtLink nofollow" href="http://www.enchantedlearning.com/subjects/mammals/Evolution.shtml" class="external text" id="mwGOw">Evolution of Mammals</a>, a brief introduction to early mammals, enchantedlearning.com</li>

</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;line-height:1.0em;"><span style="margin:-29px;display: inline-block;-webkit-transform: rotate(270deg);-moz-transform: rotate(270deg);-ms-transform: rotate(270deg);-o-transform: rotate(270deg);transform: rotate(270deg);"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tetrapod" title="Tetrapod">Tetrapoda</a></span></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;line-height:1.0em;"><span style="margin:-25px;display: inline-block;-webkit-transform: rotate(270deg);-moz-transform: rotate(270deg);-ms-transform: rotate(270deg);-o-transform: rotate(270deg);transform: rotate(270deg);"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Amniote" title="Amniote">Amniota</a></span></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

id="mwGP8"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129693374" about="#mwt2027" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles" data-mw='{"name":"templatestyles","attrs":{"src":"Hlist/styles.css"},"body":{"extsrc":""}}'/><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1061467846" about="#mwt2028"
